text: Introduction by Dar Al-Falah: Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the most honorable of all creation. To proceed: This is the section on the Sciences of Hadith according to the revered Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, from the Blessed Comprehensive Encyclopedia of the Sciences of the Revered Imam. Naturally, it does not include what the Imam narrated with his own chains of transmission (Musnad), as that is outside the scope of this encyclopedia. We had begun working on this section, but we found that the virtuous brother Ibrahim Al-Nahhas had preceded us to it, so we preferred to include him in the work rather than duplicating the effort. He performed his work—may Allah reward him well—with efficiency, although he has a slight difference from our method. He does not commit here to mentioning the narrator reporting from Imam Ahmad, and we addressed this in some places. Additionally, the matter is clear in some places from the source, but in other places, the researcher will need to refer to the original source if he needs the name of the narrator. Furthermore, he did not commit to the presence of the narrator in the source from which he quoted, which is something we adhered to in the rest of the encyclopedia. It is necessary here to point out that many of the issues found in this section were repeated in places within the Jurisprudence (Fiqh) section, which makes mentioning the narrator here less critical. He also added some jurisprudential comments in the footnotes, which is something we did not do in the rest of the work except rarely. There are also differences in other technical matters rather than scientific ones. We have adjusted most of the attributions to the editions approved by us, and we modified the arrangement of some issues, with slight additions. The brother Ibrahim prefaced his work with an introduction in which he clarified his methodology, touched upon matters related to the science of Hadith, gave a glimpse of Imam Ahmad's methodology in criticism and praise (Jarh wa Ta'dil), and then mentioned the sources of Imam Ahmad's statements upon which he relied.

text: Author's Introduction "Ibrahim Al-Nahhas": Praise be to Allah, the Creator of creation and the Forgiver of sins, the One who is aware of consciences and intentions. He encompassed everything in knowledge, and embraced everything in mercy and forbearance, and subdued every creature with might and wisdom. Visions cannot perceive Him, eras cannot change Him, and thoughts cannot imagine Him. He perfected what He made and consolidated it, and He counted everything and knew it. He raised the status of knowledge and magnified it, and out of His generosity, He singled out for it whom He willed from His creation. He urged His believing servants to mobilize to gain understanding in the religion, and He summoned them to warn His creation, just as He summoned the people of His Message to that. He granted them the inheritance of the people of His Prophethood, and accepted them to uphold His proof, and to deputize for Him in informing about His Sharia, and distinguished them from among His servants with fearing Him. Then He commanded the rest of the people to ask them and to refer to their sayings, and He made the sign of their deviation and misguidance the disappearance of their scholars. Among these acting scholars is Imam Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him, the Mufti of the Ummah. Allah singled him out with abundant virtue, a fragrant mind, and perfect knowledge. The regions resounded with his mention, and the eras were stingy with the likes of him; he was the most fulfilling of them in virtue, the most following of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the most knowledgeable of him, the most ascetic in this world, and the most obedient to his Lord. Ibn al-Qayyim (1) said: 'In the City of Peace (Baghdad), the Imam of Ahl al-Sunnah without exception was Ahmad Ibn Hanbal, who filled the earth with knowledge, Hadith, and Sunnah, such that the Imams of Hadith and Sunnah after him are his followers until the Day of Judgment. He, may Allah be pleased with him, had a severe dislike for authoring books and loved the stripping of Hadith (writing Hadith only), and he disliked that his speech be written down, and this was very hard on him. So Allah knew...
foot_note: 1. (1) "I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in" (1/28) with adaptation.

text: ...the goodness of his intention and his purpose from his speech, and his Fatwas are more than thirty volumes, and Allah, Glory be to Him, bestowed most of them upon us, so we missed only a little of them. Al-Khallal collected his texts in "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir" (The Great Collection), reaching about twenty volumes or more. His Fatwas and issues were narrated and spoken of century after century, becoming a leader and a model for the people of the Sunnah across their various classes. Even those who differed with his school of thought through Ijtihad (independent reasoning) and those who imitated others venerated his texts and Fatwas, acknowledging their right and their closeness to the texts and Fatwas of the Companions. Whoever contemplates his Fatwas and the Fatwas of the Companions will see the conformity of each to the other, seeing all of them as if they emerge from a single niche. Even when the Companions differed on two opinions, two narrations would come from him on the issue. His investigation of the Fatwas of the Companions was like his companions' investigation of his Fatwas and texts, or even greater, such that he would prioritize their Fatwas over the Mursal (disconnected) Hadith. Ishaq bin Ibrahim Ibn Hani said in his "Masa'il" (Issues): I said to Abu Abdillah: Is a Mursal Hadith from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with confirmed narrators, more beloved to you, or a Hadith from the Companions and Tabi'in that is connected with confirmed narrators? Abu Abdillah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: From the Companions is more pleasing to me.' I say: This indicates Imam Ahmad's strong adherence to Hadith and Athar. Abdullah mentioned in his "Masa'il" (1) to his father, saying: I heard my father - and he mentioned the writing of books - say: 'I dislike them. This Abu Hanifa wrote a book, then came Abu Yusuf and wrote a book, then came Ibn al-Hasan and wrote a book; so this has no end. Whenever a man comes, he writes a book. And this Malik wrote a book, and Al-Shafi'i also came, and this one came - meaning Abu Thawr - and the writing of these books is an innovation. Whenever a man comes, he writes a book and abandons the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and his Companions.' Or as my father said this or something similar.
foot_note: 1. (1) "Masa'il Abdullah" (437).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: He faulted the writing of books and disliked it with severe dislike. My father used to dislike the "Jami' of Sufyan" and denounced it, disliking it severely, and he said: 'Who heard this from Sufyan?' I never saw him validate anyone's hearing from Sufyan, nor was my father pleased to hear Hadith from anyone [via these books]. Know that among the most important investigations of this science and the most critical for achieving the desired goal of the science of Hadith is the knowledge of the Defects of Hadith ('Ilal al-Hadith). It is a precise art; for through it, the points of entry for illusion and error in the narrations of trustworthy narrators (Thiqat), whose transmission is predominantly sound and upright, are revealed. Due to its precision, it has not been realized except by a small group of scholars who thereby became leaders to be followed and authorities to be referred to. Deriving this noble science comes from the speech of these Imams and their methodologies. By studying and contemplating that, the student of the science of Hadith acquires the eligibility to speak in this precise art. Hafiz Ibn Rajab, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'There must be in this science long practice and frequent discussion. If discussion of it is lacking, then its seeker should increase his reading of the speech of the knowledgeable Imams like Yahya al-Qattan, and those who received from him like Ahmad, Ali bin al-Madini, and others. Whoever is granted the reading of that and understands it, and his soul comprehends it, will develop a strength of soul and a faculty suitable for him to speak in it' (1). May Allah have mercy on Abu Abdillah for his strong adherence to Hadiths and Athar and his abandonment of other news. For this reason, our choice fell upon his sayings regarding the judgment of Hadiths, for he is the forerunner of its knights, and in jurisprudence (Fiqh) the forerunner of its field, and the most knowledgeable of people in Fatwa in his time, and rarely does time allow for the likes of him.
foot_note: 1. (1) Quoted from the book "I'lal al-Hadith 'inda al-Imam Ahmad" by Dr. Al-Bashir.

text: He is from the best of generations that have been testified for, as the Prophet, peace be upon him, praised the first generations, saying: "The best of generations is my generation, then those who follow them." He also disparaged the generations after that, saying: "No time comes except that the one after it is worse than it." Therefore, I have undertaken, with the help and strength of Allah, to collect the sayings of Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding Hadiths, so that those who follow his traces may know this, and I clarify much for those who desire his school of thought and choose it. I point to his saying by way of summary, and I attribute what I can of the reports to the books of the Imams among the scholars of Athar; so that confidence in their meaning may be obtained, and the distinction between their authentic and defective ones may be made.

text: My Methodology in Research: In my research, I adhered as much as possible to the following methodology: - The Hadiths mentioned are all Marfu' (attributed to the Prophet) or what has the ruling of Marfu', except for what is excluded from the sayings of the Companions in interpretation (Tafsir) and tribulations (Fitan), similar to the practice of the two Sahihs at times. - I turned away from his sayings, may Allah have mercy on him, on Hadiths using phrases like: "I go with this," or "I use this as proof," or "The practice is upon this according to us," or similar phrases; because the predominant aspect of these with Imam Ahmad is jurisprudential, unless the context required it, in which case I mention it and draw attention to it. - A Hadith might be established and authentic, indeed in the two Sahihs, but the criticism is of the mentioned chain of transmission, so I clarify it and mention the correct alternative. - I did not address the Hadiths with all their paths, but only the sayings of Imam Ahmad regarding the mentioned chains, as is the custom of the scholars of Defects ('Ilal) in this art. - If the Hadith is in the two Sahihs or one of them and Imam Ahmad authenticated it, I do not mention it unless the context requires it. However, if he spoke of it with criticism, I mention it. - The paths I mentioned in the extraction (Takhrij) are the same paths mentioned by Imam Ahmad regarding this text. You may find in the Takhrij: "I did not find it"; meaning: among the paths mentioned by Imam Ahmad, even though the text might be preserved. - I arranged the chapters in a jurisprudential (Fiqh) order, seeking help from the method of the authors of the two Sahihs, even in what I used to title the chapter. - I may address some jurisprudential issues in some chapters in the footnotes; to complete the benefit and increase utility.

text: Imam Ahmad's Methodology and Terminology in Criticism and Praise (Jarh wa Ta'dil): Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, was the divine scholar of the Ummah in his time, its knowledgeable one, its jurist, its memorizer, its worshiper, and its ascetic. The fame of his virtues and merits makes it unnecessary to elaborate on them. Scholars have devoted individual compositions to his merits; some were lengthy and some concise. Whoever wants more should refer to his biography detailed in known sources. What concerns us here is his methodology and knowing the meanings of his terminologies which his companions knew and which this Imam, may Allah have mercy on him, followed. As is known, Imam Ahmad's methodology in jurisprudential issues relies on the Book, the Sunnah, Consensus, and the practice of the Companions and Tabi'in. Imam Ahmad often relies in his methodology on acting upon the Hadith even if it is not authentic (Sahih). Ibn Rajab, Ibn Taymiyyah, and others said: Imam Ahmad takes the weak Hadith, if there is nothing else in the chapter, as more beloved to him than opinion (Ra'y), and this is apparent. However, I found through induction and tracking of Imam Ahmad's books that he, may Allah have mercy on him, may adopt a weak Hadith for jurisprudential practice, even if there is an authentic Hadith in the chapter, so he adopts that as well, and thus has two narrations regarding it. Al-Khallal said (1): 'Abu Abdillah requires anyone who imitates his school of thought to know it from the narration of a group; because a group might narrate a single issue from him until his saying on it becomes ten [variations] or so. This is because a group might ask him about a single issue until he says "I do not know," meaning only: "I do not know what I choose." He is asked about that very issue, and answers with the difference [of opinion] to those who said no and yes, and no [single] opinion is executed for him. And he is asked about that issue...
foot_note: 1. (1) "Ahkam Ahl al-Milal" (1/214).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: ...also at another time, so he argues for all sides and suspends his [final] view. And he is asked about it also at a time, and he answers with his view without arguing for the issue if the matter has become clear to him. And he is asked about that also and arguments are presented against him. And he is asked about his view and what he has adopted, so he answers them. Thus, his view on that issue at that time becomes [established]. And in his issues, may Allah have mercy on him, are matters that a man needs to understand and not hasten. He has said: "Perhaps I remained on an issue - some of them mentioned - from ten years to three years." I have clarified all of this in this topic. I mean: for anyone who imitates anything from the school of Abu Abdillah, not to hasten and to verify. May Allah benefit us and you, and we ask Him for success, for He is Kind. For Abu Abdillah was a man who did not proceed except according to the Book, the Sunnah, and the saying of the Companions and Tabi'in. He loved safety and verification in what he said, and he would withhold the answer. If he answered, he would not answer except with what is correct.' I say: Imam Ahmad's methodology in jurisprudential issues relies on the Book, the Sunnah, Consensus, and the practice of the Companions and Tabi'in. He often relies in his methodology on acting upon the Hadith even if it is not authentic. Al-Athram said: 'Abu Abdillah might find a Hadith from the Prophet, peace be upon him, with something [weakness] in its chain, yet he adopts it if nothing contradictory to it is more established than it, like the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'ayb and Ibrahim al-Hajari. And he might adopt the Mursal (disconnected) Hadith if nothing contradictory to it comes.' Ibn Rajab mentioned in "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" (1) saying: 'The apparent meaning of Ahmad's speech is that the Mursal, according to him, is a type of weak [Hadith], but he adopts the Hadith even if there is weakness in it, as long as nothing contradictory comes from the Prophet, peace be upon him, or from the Companions.'

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Therefore, it was mandatory for anyone seeking Fiqh (jurisprudence) according to the school of Imam Ahmad to first study Hadith comprehensively to understand the books of 'Ilal (defects) and the expressions of Imam Ahmad and others. This is because Imam Ahmad might use a Hadith as proof and act upon it, saying: (I go with it), while in another place he weakens it and describes it as Munkar (denounced). Example: Ibn Rajab quoted in "Sharh al-Bukhari" (1): Imam Ahmad said regarding the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "Women are the twin halves of men." He said: This is Munkar. And he [also] said: I go with it. Also, Ibn Rajab quoted in "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" (2), and Al-Khallal in "Al-Jami' li-Ahkam Ahl al-Dhimmah" (3): The saying of Imam Ahmad regarding the Hadith of Ma'mar, from Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from Ibn Omar, that Ghailan accepted Islam while he had ten wives. He said: It is not Sahih (authentic), but the practice is based upon it. Abdul-Razzaq used to say: From Ma'mar, from Al-Zuhri, as Mursal (hurried/disconnected). Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Al-Farusiyyah" (4): Imam Ahmad narrated the Hadith of Ali: That Al-Abbas asked the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding expediting his charity (Zakat) before it was due, and he granted him a concession in that (5). Al-Athram said: I heard Abu Abdullah, when this Hadith was mentioned to him, weaken it and say: That is nothing. This is despite the fact that his school (Madhab) allows the expediting of Zakat. Also, Ibn al-Qayyim quoted Imam Ahmad regarding the Hadith of Aisha: "There is no vow in

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: disobedience, and its expiation is the expiation of an oath." He said: This is a Munkar Hadith, even though he narrated it, built his Madhab upon it, and used it as proof. I say: Ibn Qudamah mentioned in "Al-Mughni" (1) the saying of Imam Ahmad regarding the Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Arabs are equals to one another, except a weaver or a cupper." It was said to Imam Ahmad: How do you take this while you weaken it? He said: The practice is based upon it. More severe than this is that he may weaken a Hadith merely by turning away from it, even if he does not speak about it, and he goes to the Athar (traditions) of the Companions. An example of that: In the issue of shortening prayer (Qasr) during travel: Ibn Qudamah quoted in "Al-Mughni" (2): Al-Athram said: It was said to Abu Abdullah: In how much [distance] is the prayer shortened? He said: In four Burud. It was said to him: A full day's journey? He said: No, four Burud - sixteen Farsakhs - a journey of two days. Ibn Qudamah said: And this is the view of Ibn Abbas and Ibn Omar, and it is the view held by Malik, Al-Layth, Al-Shafi'i, and Ishaq. I say: In this chapter, there is a Hadith narrated by Muslim (3) via the path of Shu'bah, from Yahya bin Yazid Al-Huna'i, who said: I asked Anas bin Malik about shortening the prayer? He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he went out for a distance of three miles - or three Farsakhs, Shu'bah was in doubt - would pray two Rak'ahs. I say: Yahya bin Yazid Al-Huna'i is not among the companions of Anas, and he has very few narrations, or he has nothing in the Six Books except this Hadith from Anas. Ibn Ma'in said about him:

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: "Suwaylih" (little righteous/acceptable). And Abu Hatim said: "Sheikh" [Often used by Abu Hatim to imply being unknown]. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib": Maqbul (Acceptable). Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mizan": There is no harm in him. I say: Such a narrator does not bear [the weight of] Hadiths of rulings (Ahkam), regarding which Imam Ahmad said: "If they [narrations of Halal and Haram] come, we want men like this," and he closed his hand and raised his thumb; implying trustworthy, firm narrators. Among those who weakened the Hadith because of Yahya bin Yazid Al-Huna'i was Ibn Abd al-Barr in "Al-Istidhkar" (1), for he said: Yahya bin Yazid Al-Huna'i is a Sheikh from the people of Basra; one like him cannot carry this meaning which contradicts the majority of the Companions and the Tabi'in, nor is he one to be trusted in preserving this principle. From the foregoing, it becomes clear to you that Imam Ahmad did not use this Hadith as proof for the reasons you know, and he turned away from it and took the traditions of the Companions. Sometimes the traditions of the Companions may also be weak, yet Imam Ahmad acts upon them, so one must pay attention to that. Thus, legal practice may coincide with the authenticity of a Hadith, and it may not coincide in the school of Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him. Another example: Imam Ahmad said, when asked about the Hadith of Malik bin al-Huwayrith: That he saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, praying, and when he was in an odd-numbered Rak'ah of his prayer, he did not rise until he sat up straight (2). Imam Ahmad said: Sahih. And he said once: This Hadith has no second. Meaning: This sitting was not narrated in other than this. And he said once: Most Hadiths do not mention anything of that. I say: Imam Ahmad is pointing out that the sitting of rest (Jalsat al-Istirahah) was not narrated in a Hadith other than

text: this. But it has been narrated - i.e., the sitting of rest - in the Hadith of "the one who prayed badly" (Al-Musi' Salatahu). So when he turned away from it and did not mention it, can it be said: That he did not come across the Hadith of the one who prayed badly? This matter is unlikely; due to the fame of this Hadith among the common people, so how about the Imam of Ahl al-Sunnah. Furthermore, there was disagreement over Ubaydullah Al-Umari regarding this Hadith. Al-Qattan and Abu Usamah narrated it without it [the sitting], while Ibn Numair narrated it from him affirming it. The most likely view, and Allah knows best, is that it is not established; Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" (1): Al-Bukhari indicated that this phrase is a delusion (Wahm), for he said following the Hadith: Abu Usamah said at the end: 'Until you stand up straight.' And it is possible to interpret it, if it is preserved, as sitting for the Tashahhud. Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath": This phrase has been disputed in the Hadith of Abu Huraira; some narrators mentioned that he ordered him to sit after the two prostrations, and some mentioned that he ordered him to stand after them, and this is what is more likely. For this Hadith, no one mentioned in it that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, taught him any of the agreed-upon Sunan of prayer, so how could he have ordered him with this sitting? This is very remote (2). He said: Then I found that Al-Bayhaqi mentioned this, and mentioned that there was disagreement regarding Abu Usamah about mentioning this second sitting after the two prostrations. He said: The correct narration from him is that he said after mentioning the two prostrations: "Then rise until you stand up straight." Al-Bayhaqi said: Al-Bukhari narrated it in his "Sahih" from Ishaq bin Mansur from Abu Usamah, and mentioned the narration of Ibn Numair but did not mention Al-Bukhari's extraction of it, and Yahya bin Sa'id did not mention in his narration the second prostration nor what followed it of sitting or standing. He said: And standing is more similar to what the report was driven for, which is counting the pillars (Arkan) not the Sunan. And Allah knows best.

text: Ibn Rajab said: This indicates that the mention of the second sitting is not preserved from Yahya. [I say]: From the foregoing, the reason for Imam Ahmad's turning away from this addition becomes clear, which is its weakness and lack of establishment. Thus he said regarding the Hadith of Malik bin al-Huwayrith that this sitting was not narrated in other than this. So Imam Ahmad's turning away from this Hadith and negating it indicates its weakness according to him, even if he did not weaken it explicitly. Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Al-Farusiyyah" (1): His methodology - meaning Imam Ahmad - is that he does not prioritize anything over a Sahih Hadith whatsoever, neither practice, nor analogy (Qiyas), nor the opinion of a Companion. If there is no Sahih Hadith in the issue, and there is a weak Hadith in it, and there is nothing in the chapter to refute it, he acts upon it. But if something stronger opposes it, he leaves it for the stronger opponent. And if there is a weak Hadith and an analogy in the issue, he prioritizes the weak Hadith over the analogy. The "weak" in his terminology is not the "weak" in the terminology of the later scholars. Rather, he and the early scholars divided Hadith into Sahih and Da'if (Weak), and the Hasan (Good) according to them fell within the Weak according to its ranks. The first one known to have divided it into three sections was Abu Isa Al-Tirmidhi, then people followed him after that. So Ahmad prioritizes the Weak, which is Hasan (2) according to him, over analogy, and does not pay attention to the flimsy Weak (Al-Wahi) which cannot serve as proof; rather, he disapproves of anyone who uses it as proof or follows it. text: a Hadith in the issue, he takes the opinions of the Companions and does not oppose them. If they differed, he selects from their opinions and does not go outside of them. If the Companions differed on an issue, his answer regarding it usually varies, and two or more narrations (opinions) emerge from him regarding it. So for every issue where there are two narrations from the Companions, there are two or more narrations from him. He is the most following of Allah's creation of the Sunan, both the Marfu' (elevated to Prophet) and Mawquf (stopped at Companion). End quote. Much discussion has revolved around Imam Ahmad's use of the term "Munkar". A group of later and contemporary scholars held that "Nakarah" (being Munkar) according to Imam Ahmad refers to mere singularity (Tafarrud). Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in "Hady al-Sari" in the biography of Muhammad bin Ibrahim Al-Taimi - the narrator of the Hadith "Actions are but by intentions" - after mentioning Imam Ahmad's saying: "He narrates Munkar Hadiths." He said: Munkar is used by Ahmad bin Hanbal and a group [of scholars] for a singular Hadith that has no corroborator. Al-Hafiz's opinion becomes clearer in "Al-Nukat" (1), he said: Imam Ahmad, Al-Nasa'i, and more than one of the critics have applied the term Munkar to mere singularity, but [this applies] where the singularity is not of the weight of one whose Hadith is judged as Sahih without a supporter to support it. Al-Hafiz's statement here is close to Imam Ahmad's method, but for Imam Ahmad, even if the solitary narrator is among the trustworthy or the senior trustworthy ones, [it is Munkar] due to indicators, the most important of which are delusion (Wahm) and error.

text: For Imam Ahmad paused regarding the addition: (from the Muslims) in Zakat al-Fitr, which Al-Bukhari extracted (1) from the Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, enjoined Zakat al-Fitr, a Sa' of dates or a Sa' of barley, upon every free person or slave, male or female, from the Muslims. The one unique in narrating it was Malik bin Anas, so he did not accept it, until Imam Malik was corroborated, then he accepted it. This is the school of Yahya bin Sa'id and more than one of the critics. Muslim said in the introduction to the "Sahih": The sign of the Munkar in the Hadith of a narrator is: if his narration of the Hadith is compared to the narration of others from the people of preservation and satisfaction, his narration contradicts their narration, or it hardly matches it. If the majority of his Hadith is like that: he is abandoned in Hadith (Mahjur al-Hadith), not accepted nor used. Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Muwqizah" (2): A group of the Hafizs might call a Hadith in which someone like Hushaym bin Ghiyath is alone as Munkar. If the solitary narrator is from the rank of the Sheikhs of the Imams, they applied Nakarah to what he was alone in, like Uthman bin Abi Shaybah and Abu Salama Al-Tabudhaki, and they said: This is Munkar. He also said in "Al-Mizan" (3) in the biography of Ali bin Al-Madini: The singularity of the Saduq (truthful) and those below him is considered Munkar. In "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (4) to Imam Ahmad: It was said to him: These benefits (Fawa'id) which contain Munkar [narrations], do you see that the Munkar Hadith should be written? He said: Munkar is always Munkar. It was said to him: Then the weak ones? He said: They might be needed at any time. As if he did not see any harm in writing from them.

text: Ibn Rajab said in "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" (1) about Imam Ahmad that he said: Do not write these strange Hadiths (Ghara'ib); for they are Manakir (pl. Munkar) and most of them are from the weak. Ibn Rajab said in "Sharh al-Tirmidhi" (2): I have not found for anyone of the early scholars a limit for the Munkar of Hadith and its definition except what Abu Bakr Al-Bardiji the Hafiz - and he was among the notable prominent Hafizs - mentioned in Al-Ilal: That Munkar is what a man narrates from the Companions, or from the Tabi'in from the Companions, and that Hadith and the text of the Hadith is not known except from the path of the one who narrated it, so it is Munkar. He mentioned this speech in the context of if Shu'bah, or Sa'id bin Abi Aruba, or Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i were alone in a Hadith from Qatada from Anas from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. This is like explicitly stating that whatever a trustworthy person narrates alone from a trustworthy person, and the text is not known from other than that path, is Munkar. Just as Imam Ahmad said regarding the Hadith of Abdullah bin Dinar from Ibn Omar from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding the prohibition of selling Wala' (clientage) and gifting it; where he said: Abdullah bin Dinar was not corroborated in it, and the correct is what Nafi' narrated from Ibn Omar (3) that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Wala' belongs to the one who manumitted." Similarly, Ahmad said regarding the Hadith of Malik, from Al-Zuhri, from Urwah, from Aisha: That those who combined Hajj and Umrah performed Tawaf when they arrived for their Umrah and performed Tawaf for their Hajj when they returned from Mina. He said: No one said this except Malik. And he said: I do not think but that Malik erred in it; no one else brought it. And he said once: Only Malik narrated it, and Malik is trustworthy.

text: Ibn Rajab said: Perhaps Ahmad only denounced it for its contradiction to the Hadiths stating that the Qarin (one combining Hajj and Umrah) performs one Tawaf. Then Ibn Rajab said: Al-Bardiji said after that: As for the Hadiths of Qatada which the Sheikhs narrate, like Hammad bin Salama, Hammam, Aban, and Al-Awza'i, one looks into the Hadith. If the Hadith is preserved from other than their path from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, or from Anas bin Malik from another aspect, it is not rejected. But if it is not known from anyone from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, except from a path from Anas, except from the narration of this one I mentioned to you, it is Munkar. And he said: If a trustworthy person narrates via a Sahih path from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, a Hadith that is not found except with that single man, it does not harm him that no one else narrates it if the text of the Hadith is known, and it is neither Munkar nor defective (Ma'lul). And he said regarding a Hadith narrated by Amr bin Asim from Hammam from Ishaq bin Talha from Anas that a man said to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: I have committed a Hadd (punishable offense), so execute it upon me, may Allah be pleased with him... the Hadith. This, in my view, is a Munkar Hadith, and it is, in my view, a delusion from Amr bin Asim. Ibn Rajab said in "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" (1): As for most of the early Hafizs, they say regarding a Hadith if one person is alone in it, even if the trustworthy narrators did not narrate differently, that he is not corroborated in it, and they make that a defect in it. Unless he is one whose memorization was abundant and whose integrity and Hadith were famous, like Al-Zuhri and his likes. And perhaps they denounce some singularities of the senior trustworthy narrators as well. They have a specific criticism for every Hadith, and they do not have a rule that governs it. Al-Mu'allimi said in "Al-Anwar Al-Kashifah" (2): The Imams often classify the narrator as weak due to a single Munkar report he brought, let alone two or more reports, and they call the report

Meaning: It is a delusion from Ismail bin Ayyash (1). - And in "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli (2): Al-Athram said: I said to Ahmad: Do you preserve from Abdullah bin Raja, from Ubaidullah, from Nafi', from Ibn Omar "The Halal is clear"? He said: This is Munkar, I do not regard this as anything. Abu Ubaidullah said to me: This Ibn Raja claimed that his books had gone, so he started writing what he memorized, and perhaps he imagined this. Then Ahmad spoke well of the status of Abdullah. - And in the book "Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal" (3) narration of Al-Marudhi: I said to Ahmad: Do you know from Al-Walid, from Al-Awza'i, from Yahya, from Abu Salama, from Abu Huraira,

He said: "Yes, if you do not increase him in good, you will not increase him in evil." Abu Omar said: As for this Hadith, they blamed Abdul-Razzaq for it; because he was alone in it from Al-Thawri among all his companions. They said: This is a Hadith not found in the world with anyone with this Isnad except in the book of Abdul-Razzaq or in the book of one who extracted it from the book of Abdul-Razzaq, and no one narrated it from Al-Thawri other than him. They considered it a mistake and to them it is an error. They said: This is a Munkar wording; the words of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, do not resemble ordering something about which he does not know whether it benefits or does not benefit. She said: Four Rak'ahs and he would increase whatever Allah willed. Imam Ahmad said: Munkar. And he said that the correct [narration] from Aisha is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, never prayed the Duha prayer. - And in "Jami' al-Ulum wa al-Hikam" (1): He said regarding the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: "There is no Prophet whom Allah sent in a nation before except that he had from his nation disciples (Hawariyun)" and in it: "And whoever fights them with his tongue is a believer, and whoever fights them with his heart is a believer, and beyond that there is not a mustard seed of faith." Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith, and it is contrary to the Hadiths in which the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded patience over the injustice of the leaders. Nakarah is also applied to what has no basis (Asl), and to the Batil (false), and to the negation of authenticity, and to the non-existence of the Hadith in the books of the Sheikh. Examples: - In "Ilal Al-Marudhi", and "Al-Muntakhab" by Ibn Qudamah (2): The Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas: "I did not bring you in and drive you out, rather Allah brought him in and drove you out." Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith, it has no basis. - In "Masa'il Ibn Hani", and "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab (3): He said regarding the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in the story of menstruation: "Undo your hair and bathe." Ahmad said: This is Batil. And he said once: Munkar.

text: My father said: This is a denounced Hadith that has no basis. And in it also (1) he said: I heard my father say: The nephew of Abd al-Razzaq narrated, from Abd al-Razzaq, from Yahya bin al-Ala, from al-A'mash, from Khaythamah, from Abdullah who said: Hearts are naturally disposed to love those who do good to them, and hate those who do evil to them. My father said: This is a denounced Hadith, and the nephew of Abd al-Razzaq used to lie. And in it (2) he said: And I asked my father about a Hadith narrated by Burd bin Sinan, from Al-Zuhri, from Urwah, from Aisha, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he was praying and she asked for the door to be opened, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, came and opened the door and continued in his prayer. I said to my father: What is the status of this Hadith? My father said: No one narrated this Hadith from the Prophet, peace be upon him, other than Burd, and it is a denounced Hadith; Al-Zuhri does not bear such a Hadith. A group of Imams also went on to apply error and illusion to 'Nakarah' (denouncement), among them Ibn Ma'in, Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Abd al-Barr, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Daraqutni. Ibn Ma'in said in his "Tarikh" (3): Al-Duri said: I heard Yahya and asked him about the Hadith of Hakim bin Jubair, the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud: "Charity is not permissible for one who has fifty Dirhams." Does anyone narrate it other than Hakim? Yahya bin Ma'in said: Yes, Yahya bin Adam narrates it, from Sufyan, from Zubaid, and we do not know anyone who narrates it except Yahya bin Adam, and this is an illusion. If this were so, all people would have narrated it from Sufyan, but it is a denounced Hadith.

text: Al-Tirmidhi said in "Al-'Ilal Al-Kabir" (1): Al-Hasan bin Al-Sabah narrated to us, Muhammad bin Kathir narrated to us, from Al-Awza'i, from Qatadah, from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "A group of my nation will continue fighting upon the truth, victorious until the Day of Resurrection" and he gestured with his hand towards the Levant (Sham). I asked Muhammad about this Hadith and he said: This is a denounced Hadith, an error. He also said in "Al-'Ilal Al-Kabir" (2): Yahya bin Musa narrated to us, Ya'qub bin Muhammad Al-Zuhri narrated to us, Muhammad bin Fulayh narrated to us, from Abdullah bin Al-Husayn bin Ata', from Sharik bin Abi Namir, from Anas bin Malik that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said Takbir once in the prayer for rain (Istisqa). So I asked Muhammad about this Hadith and he said: This is an error, and Abdullah bin Husayn Ibn Ata' is denounced in Hadith (Munkar al-Hadith). Malik bin Anas narrated that the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed for rain in his story, and this is not in it. Al-Nasa'i narrated in his "Sunan" (3) via Al-Ahwas, from Simak, from Al-Qasim bin Abd al-Rahman, from his father, from Abu Burdah bin Niyar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Drink from vessels but do not become intoxicated." Al-Nasa'i said: This is a denounced Hadith, Abu Al-Ahwas Salam bin Sulaym erred in it. Also, Al-Nasa'i narrated in "Al-Kubra" (4) via Isa bin Muhammad Abu Umair Al-Ramli, and Isa bin Yunus attributed it, Huri narrated to us, from Murrah, from Sufyan, from Abdullah bin Dinar, from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever owns a Mahram relative, [the relative] becomes free."

text: Al-Nasa'i said: We do not know anyone who narrated this Hadith from Sufyan. Al-Tirmidhi said: Damrah was not followed in this Hadith, and it is an error according to the people of Hadith. Al-Bayhaqi said: It is a gross illusion, and what is preserved with this chain is the prohibition of selling loyalty (Wala') and gifting it. Al-Tirmidhi mentioned in "Al-'Ilal Al-Kabir" (1) a Hadith via Muhammad bin Fudayl, from Al-A'mash, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, prayer has a beginning and an end." Al-Tirmidhi said: I asked Muhammad about this Hadith and he said: Ibn Fudayl had an illusion in his Hadith, and the correct one: is the Hadith of Al-A'mash from Mujahid. Ibn Abi Hatim said in "Al-'Ilal" (2): I asked my father about a Hadith narrated by Muhammad bin Fudayl... and he mentioned it. My father said: This is an error, Ibn Fudayl had an illusion in it, the companions of Al-A'mash narrate it from Al-A'mash from Mujahid as his saying. Al-Daraqutni said: This is not authentic as Musnad (connected back to Prophet), Ibn Fudayl had an illusion in its chain, and others narrate it from Al-A'mash from Mujahid as Mursal (disconnected). Ibn Abd al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" (3): This Hadith is denounced according to all the people of Hadith, and it is an error that no one narrated from Al-A'mash with this chain except Muhammad bin Fudayl, and they denounced it from him. text: This Hadith, the Hadith of Muhammad bin Fudayl from Al-A'mash, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah regarding prayer times is an error that has no basis. Ibn Ma'in said: Muhammad bin Fudayl narrated it from Al-A'mash and erred in it. 'Munkar' may be applied to the unpreserved (Ghayr Mahfuz), the anomalous (Shadh), the strange (Gharib), and uniqueness from the companions of the Sheikh. There is no precise definition for these terms in the speech of the early Imams as the later scholars defined denouncement (Nakarah). Denouncement is lifted according to Imam Ahmad and other critics by indicators such as corroboration (Mutaba'ah), as previously mentioned in the Hadith of Malik regarding the addition "from the Muslims", so when it was corroborated it was accepted. And as in the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah regarding prayer times which Al-Tirmidhi narrated (1), and in it: "Gabriel led me at the House twice, so he prayed Dhuhr in the first..." the Hadith. Imam Ahmad said about it: This Hadith is not denounced; because Al-Husayn bin Ali who narrated it was agreed with by others on some of its descriptions (2). And as he said regarding the Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding reciting aloud in the prayer for rain, which Al-Bukhari narrated (3), he said: I used to denounce it until I saw the narration of Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri as Ibn Abi Dhi'b said. Meaning: that he recited aloud (4). And also he said regarding the Hadith of Ammar bin Yasir, which Al-Bukhari narrated (5) regarding Tayammum being one strike for the face and hands: It is authentic. And he said once: There is nothing in my heart...

text:
Book of Faith
1 - What has been narrated regarding the branches of faith
The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Faith has sixty-odd branches, the best of which is the testimony that there is no god but Allah, and the least of which is removing harm from the road" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It is only from Suhayl, from Abdullah bin Dinar, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah (2).
He was asked: From whom is the error, from Ma'mar or from Suhayl? He said: I do not know (3).
I say: Meaning: Ma'mar, Wuhaib, and others narrated it without mentioning Abdullah bin Dinar.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tayalisi in his "Musnad" (2402) who said: Wuhaib narrated to us, Suhayl bin Abi Salih narrated to us, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah as Marfu'. 
2. Narrated by Muslim (50) who said: Zuhair bin Harb narrated to us, Jarir narrated to us, from Suhayl, from Abdullah bin Dinar, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah as Marfu'. I say: Al-Bukhari (9) and Muslim (35) narrated this Hadith via Sulayman bin Bilal from Abdullah bin Dinar, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah as Marfu' without the wording "the best of which is saying: there is no god but Allah, and the least of which is removing harm from the road". However, the Hadiths of Al-Bukhari and Muslim were not free from criticism, for Al-Uqayli said in "Al-Du'afa" 2/249: And Suhayl bin Abi Salih, Muhammad bin Ajlan, and Yazid bin Al-Had narrated from Abdullah bin Dinar, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Faith has seventy-odd branches" and none of the established narrators we named followed them on it, meaning: Shu'bah, Sufyan, Malik, and Ibn Uyaynah, nor did anyone follow Abdullah bin Dinar from Abu Salih on it. This view is close to the method of Yahya Al-Qattan and Al-Bardiji.

2 - What has been narrated regarding the taste of faith
The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever loves to find the taste of faith, let him love a person, loving him only for the sake of Allah" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: I said to Yazid: What is the name of Abu Balj? He said: Yahya bin Abi Sulaym. Then Yazid said: I heard it from Shu'bah in Baghdad, and I was among the last of the people, and I have doubted it since I heard it. So Yazid retracted it and said: Write it from a man.
Imam Ahmad said: Yazid bin Harun erred in it (2).

1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 2/298 who said: Muhammad bin Ja'far and Hashim narrated to us, they said: Shu'bah narrated to us. Hashim said: Yahya bin Abi Sulaym informed me, I heard Amr bin Maymun. And Muhammad said: from Abu Balj from Amr bin Maymun, from Abu Hurayrah, from the Prophet, peace be upon him. . the Hadith. 
2. "Al-'Ilal" narration of Abdullah (1237), "Part of Masa'il Al-Baghawi" (32), "Masa'il Salih for Imam Ahmad" (797). I say: The meaning of the Hadith is authentic and established, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (16) from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him.

3 - What has been narrated regarding the comprehensive descriptions of Islam
The Hadith of Sufyan Al-Thaqafi, may Allah be pleased with him: O Messenger of Allah, command me with a command in Islam about which I will not ask anyone after you. He said: "Say I believe in Allah, then remain upright" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Hushaym did not hear it from Ya'la bin Ata' (2).
4 - What has been narrated regarding gentleness in religion
The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: "Indeed, this religion is robust, so penetrate into it with gentleness" (3).
Imam Ahmad narrated it, then abandoned it, and said: Denounced (Munkar) (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 4/384-385 who said: Hushaym narrated to us, from Ya'la bin Ata', from Abdullah bin Sufyan Al-Thaqafi, from his father as Marfu'. 
2. "Al-'Ilal" narration of Abdullah for Ahmad (2171). I say: The text of this Hadith is established and authentic, for Muslim narrated it No. (38) from the Hadith of Sufyan bin Abdullah Al-Thaqafi. 
3. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 3/199 who said: Zaid bin Al-Hubbab narrated to us, he said: Amr bin Hamzah informed me, Khalaf Abu Al-Rabi', the Imam of the mosque of Sa'id bin Abi Arubah, narrated to us, Anas narrated to us as Marfu'. 
4. "Al-Muntakhab by Ibn Qudamah from Al-'Ilal for Al-Khallal" (35). I say: The meaning of this Hadith is supported by what Al-Bukhari narrated (39) from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "Indeed, religion is ease, and no one will make religion difficult except that it will overcome him. So be steadfast, and do your best, and rejoice, and seek help in the morning and evening and something of the night."

5 - What has been reported regarding Modesty being part of Faith
The Hadith of Abu Bakra, may Allah be pleased with him: "Modesty is from Faith, and Faith is in Paradise. And obscenity is from coarseness, and coarseness is in the Fire" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This came from Hushaym—meaning he was inconsistent in it—so he narrated it once from Al-Hasan, from Abu Bakra, and once from Al-Hasan, from Imran. Ahmad said: And I heard it from Hushaym, from Auf, from Al-Hasan, as Mursal (hurried/disconnected). He said once: As for the people of Wasit, they say: From Imran bin Husain, and as for others, they say: From Abu Bakra. It was said to him: Which one is correct? He said: I do not know (2).

1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (4184), he said: Ismail bin Musa told us, Hushaym told us, from Mansur, from Al-Hasan, from Abu Bakra in a Marfu' form.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawood li-Ahmad" (2008), "Al-Muntakhab by Ibn Qudamah" (159). I say: The text is established and authentic, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (24) from the Hadith of Ibn Omar without the phrase: "And Faith is in Paradise, and obscenity is from coarseness."

6 - What has been reported regarding one who clears himself for his religion
It contains two Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Ammar bin Yasir, may Allah be pleased with them both: "The Halal is clear and the Haram is clear, and between them are doubtful matters. Whoever avoids them has cleared himself for his religion and his honor, and whoever falls into them is on the verge of falling into major sins, like the shepherd grazing around a sanctuary, on the verge of falling into it. Verily, every king has a sanctuary, and the sanctuary of Allah is His limits" (1).
Imam Ahmad said (when asked about this Hadith): I do not know it from Ammar. And he said: Who narrated it? It was said to him: Musa bin Ubayda. So he clenched his hand, then said: It is possible, and he attributed it to him [implied weakness]. And he said: His Hadith is nothing to me, his Hadith from Abdullah bin Dinar—it is as if it is not that Abdullah bin Dinar—and from Abu Hazim (2).
The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both, similar to it (3).
Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith; I do not see this as anything. He said: This Ibn Raja claimed that his books had gone, so he started writing from his memory, and perhaps he imagined this (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 2/204 (1735), he said: Ahmad bin Abdul-Rahman Ibn Bashar Al-Nasa'i told us, he said: Ishaq bin Rahwayh told us, he said: Abu Thumayla Yahya bin Wadih informed us, he said: Musa bin Ubayda told us, from his brother Abdullah, from Ammar Yasir in a Marfu' form.
2. "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 4/161, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 29/108.
3. Narrated by Al-Uqayli in "Al-Du'afa" 2/252-253, he said: Muhammad bin Musa told us, he said: Ibrahim bin Muhammad Al-Shafi'i told us, he said: Abdullah bin Raja told us, from Ubaydullah bin Omar, from Nafi', from Ibn Omar in a Marfu' form.
4. "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 2/252, "Mizan Al-I'tidal" 3/135. And the text of the Hadith is authentic, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (52) from the Hadith of Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with him. It is also in Muslim, number (1599), but I will suffice with what is in Al-Bukhari even if the Hadith is in both Sahihs, because this is not the place for extensive citation.

7 - What has been reported regarding Divine Decree (Al-Qadar)
The Hadith of Iyad bin Himar, may Allah be pleased with him: "Verily my Lord commanded me to teach you what you were ignorant of, from what He taught me this day of mine."
Imam Ahmad said: Yahya narrated to us the Hadith of Iyad bin Himar from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding Qadar, from Hisham (1). He said: And Yahya narrated to us, he said: Shu'ba narrated to us, from Qatada, he said: I heard Mutarrif (2) regarding this Hadith. Meaning the Hadith of Qadar.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (2865), he said: Abu Ghassan Al-Masma'i, Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna, and Muhammad Ibn Bashar bin Uthman told me—and the wording belongs to Abu Ghassan and Ibn Al-Muthanna—they said: Mu'adh bin Hisham told us, my father told me, from Qatada, from Mutarrif bin Abdullah bin Al-Shikhir, from Iyad bin Himar Al-Mujashi'i that the Messenger of Allah said one day in his sermon: "Verily my Lord commanded me to teach you what you were ignorant of, from what He taught me this day of mine: 'Everything I have bestowed upon a servant is lawful, and I created My servants as Hunafo (inclining to truth) all of them, but the devils came to them and turned them away from their religion, and forbade upon them what I had made lawful for them, and commanded them to associate with Me that for which I have sent down no authority.' And verily, Allah looked at the people of the earth and detested them, Arabs and non-Arabs alike, except for some remnants of the People of the Book. And He said: 'I have only sent you to test you and to test others by you, and I have sent down upon you a Book that water cannot wash away, which you recite while asleep and while awake.' And verily, Allah commanded me to burn Quraysh, so I said: 'My Lord, then they would smash my head and leave it like bread.' He said: 'Drive them out as they drove you out, and fight them and We will aid you, and spend and We will spend on you, and send an army and We will send five like it, and fight with those who obey you against those who disobey you.' He said: 'And the people of Paradise are three: A ruler who is just, charitable, and guided. And a man who is merciful and tender-hearted towards every relative and Muslim. And a chaste man with a family who refrains from begging.' He said: 'And the people of the Fire are five: The weak one who has no restraint, those among you who are followers, seeking neither family nor wealth. And the treacherous one whose greed is not hidden, even if it is small, except that he betrays it. And a man who does not wake up morning or evening except that he is deceiving you regarding your family and your wealth.' And he mentioned miserliness or lying 'and the foul-mouthed person.'"

The Hadith of 'Aidh bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with him: "Islam prevails and is not prevailed over" (1).
Imam Ahmad did not consider it to be anything [authentic] (2).

11 - What has been reported regarding Seeing the Lord, Mighty and Majestic
It contains three Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Umm Al-Tufayl, may Allah be pleased with her: That she heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, mention that he saw his Lord, Exalted is He, in a dream in the best form, a dignified young man, his feet in greenery, wearing gold sandals, and on his face a golden moth [mask/covering] (1).
Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith. And he said: Marwan bin Uthman is an unknown man, and Umarah bin Amir, from whom Marwan narrated, is not known. It was said to him: Has it reached you that Umm Al-Tufayl heard from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace? He said: I do not know. And he said: Sa'id bin Abi Hilal is Madani (from Medina), there is no harm in him (2).
The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "I saw my Lord in the form of a beardless young man, with a veil of pearls before him, his feet or legs in greenery" (3).

12 - What has been reported regarding Seeing the Lord, Mighty and Majestic, in the Hereafter
It contains two Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him: "If He settles in His place, then you will see Me, and if He does not settle, then you will not see Me in this world nor in the Hereafter" (3).
Imam Ahmad got extremely angry when he heard this Hadith, until it showed on his face, and he was sitting with people around him. So he took his sandal and put it on and said: May Allah disgrace this [narrator], this should not be written. And he denied that Yazid bin Harun narrated it or spoke of it. And he said: This is a Jahmi, this is a Kafir (disbeliever). May Allah disgrace this wicked person. Whoever says that Allah is not seen in the Hereafter, he is a Kafir.

Also, Yazid bin Ibrahim is criticized in his narration from Qatada, but Hisham and Hammam followed him with the wording: "I saw Light."

The Hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him: "O Muhammad, do you know what the Highest Assembly disputes about?" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The path of Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Zaid bin Salam, from Abu

He said: "Then surely you will see Him on the Day of Resurrection likewise. Allah will gather the people..." The Hadith.

Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 5/243, he said: Abu Sa'id, the Mawla of Ibn Hashim, told us, Jahdam—meaning Al-Yamani—told us, Yahya—meaning Ibn Abi Kathir—told us, Zaid—meaning Ibn Abi Salam—told us, from Abu Salam—and he is Zaid bin Salam bin Abi Salam, attributed to his grandfather—that Abdul-Rahman bin A'ish Al-Hadrami told him, from Malik bin Yakhamir that Mu'adh said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was detained from us one morning for the Fajr prayer until we could almost see the horn of the sun. Then the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came out quickly, called for the prayer (Iqamah), and prayed, and he was brief in his prayer. When he made the Taslim, he said: "Stay in your rows as you are." Then he turned to us and said: "I will tell you what detained me from you this morning. I stood up in the night and prayed what was decreed for me, then I slumbered in my prayer until I woke up, and lo, I was with my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, in the best form. He said: 'O Muhammad, do you know what the Highest Assembly disputes about?' I said: 'I do not know, O Lord.' He said: 'O Muhammad, what does the Highest Assembly dispute about?' I said: 'I do not know, Lord.' Then I saw Him place His palm between my shoulders until I felt the coolness of His fingertips between my chest, so everything became manifest to me and I knew. He said: 'O Muhammad, what does the Highest Assembly dispute about?' I said: 'About expiations.' He said: 'And what are the expiations?' I said: 'Moving footsteps to the Friday prayers, sitting in the mosques after the prayer, and perfecting ablution during hardships.' He said: 'And what are the degrees?' I said: 'Feeding food, soft speech, and prayer while people are asleep.' He said: 'Ask.' I said: 'O Allah, I ask You for the performance of good deeds, the abandonment of evil deeds, the love of the poor, and that You forgive me and have mercy on me. And if You intend a trial for a people, then cause me to die without being tested. And I ask You for Your love, the love of those who love You, and the love of a deed that brings me closer to Your love.'" And the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "It is truth, so study it and learn it."

Salam, from Abdul-Rahman bin A'ish Al-Hadrami, that he told him, from Malik bin Yakhamir Al-Saksaki, from Mu'adh bin Jabal, is the most correct of them (1).
And once it was said to Ahmad: Ibn Jabir narrates from Khalid, from Abdul-Rahman bin A'ish, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And Qatada narrates it from Abu Qilaba, from Khalid, from Abdullah bin Abbas. Which of them is more beloved to you? He said: The Hadith of Qatada is nothing, and the saying is what Ibn Jabir said (2).

However, Al-Hafiz narrated in "Al-Isabah" from Al-Bukhari that he said: This is a Mudtarib (disordered) Hadith. Ibn Khuzayma said likewise in "Kitab Al-Tawhid", and it is the opinion of Ibn Al-Jawzi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Marudhi, and others. Al-Hafiz and Ibn Taymiyyah authenticated it. I say: This Hadith revolves around Abdul-Rahman bin A'ish, and he is closer to being unknown (Jahala) than to being just ('Adala), for he has nothing in the Six Books except this Hadith. Abu Zur'ah Al-Razi said about him: Not known (Laysa bi-Ma'ruf). I say: One like this cannot support uniqueness, let alone having disagreement over him. He was inconsistent in this Hadith; narrating it once from a man from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and once from Malik bin Yakhamir from Mu'adh, and once from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So he was inconsistent in this Hadith despite the obscurity in him, so the defect is apparent, and whoever defends it has missed the truth. And Allah knows best. Benefit: Imam Ahmad's saying: (The most correct of them) does not mean the authenticity of the Hadith as Ibn Adi, may Allah have mercy on him, understood. It only means that Abdul-Rahman bin A'ish narrated it well and reported it as connected only while acknowledging the disorder. And Allah knows best. 14 - What has been reported regarding his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "Verily Allah does not sleep"
The Hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him: "Verily, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, does not sleep, and it does not befit Him to sleep. He lowers the Scale and raises it. The deeds of the night are raised to Him before the day, and the deeds of the day before the night. His veil is Light—and in the narration of Abu Bakr: Fire—if He were to uncover it, the sublimity of His Face would burn whatever His sight reaches of His creation" (1).
Imam Ahmad said, when the Hadith of Ubaydullah bin Musa, from Sufyan, from Hakim bin Al-Daylam, from Abu Burdah, from his father, was presented to him, saying: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stood among us with four [statements] and said: "Verily Allah does not sleep." Ahmad said: This is the Hadith of Al-A'mash from Amr bin Murrah, from Abu Ubaydah, from Abu Musa. This is the wording of the Hadith of Amr bin Murrah. I think Ubaydullah bin Musa entered the chain of a Hadith into the chain of [another] Hadith (2).
And he said once: It is not correct. This is a mistake from Ubaydullah bin Musa; he was not a man of Hadith. This is the Hadith of Al-Thawri, from Hakim, from Abu Burdah, from Abu

15 - What has been reported regarding the creation of Adam in His image
The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Do not make faces ugly, for the son of Adam was created in the image of the Most Merciful (Al-Rahman)" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Al-A'mash says: From Habib bin Abi Thabit, from Ata, from Ibn Omar: "Verily Allah created Adam in the image of the Most Merciful." As for Al-Thawri, he stopped it (made it Mawquf), meaning: The Hadith of Ibn Omar. And Abu Al-Zinad, from Al-A'raj, from Abu Huraira (2) from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "In His image" (3). And once: He authenticated it. Meaning: "In the image of the Most Merciful" (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Sunnah" 1/228, he said: Yusuf bin Musa told us, Jarir told us, from Al-A'mash, from Habib bin Abi Thabit, from Ata, from Ibn Omar in a Marfu' form.
2. Narrated by Ahmad 2/244, he said: Sufyan told us from Abu Al-Zinad, from Al-A'raj, from Abu Huraira, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "If one of you strikes, let him avoid the face, for Allah created Adam in His image."
3. "Al-Muntakhab by Ibn Qudamah from Ilal Al-Khallal" (168), "Tabaqat Al-Hanabila" 2/132.
4. "Masa'il Ishaq bin Mansur Al-Kawsaj" (3290). I say: As for his saying: "In His image," it is established in Al-Bukhari (6227) and Muslim (2612) from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. As for his saying: (In the image of the Most Merciful), Imam Ahmad and Ibn Khuzayma criticized it. Three defects were mentioned for this Hadith, which are: The first defect: That Al-Thawri contradicted Al-A'mash in its chain, so Al-Thawri sent it (Mursal) and did not say: From Ibn Omar. The second defect: That Al-A'mash is a Mudallis and did not mention that he heard it from Habib bin Abi Thabit.

Then he said: So the meaning of the report—if it is authentic via the path of transmission as Musnad (connected)—is that the son of Adam was created in the image in which the Most Merciful created Adam, then He breathed the soul into him. I say: The narration of Jarir from Al-A'mash is spoken against, and he was alone in narrating it from the companions of Al-A'mash. Benefit: Abu Ya'la reported in 'Tabaqat al-Hanabilah' 1/93, in the biography of Ibrahim bin Aban al-Mawsili: He has issues from our Imam, among them: He said: I heard Abu Abdullah, and a man came to him and said: 'I heard Abu Thawr say: Allah created Adam in the image of Himself.' He [Ahmad] lowered his head for a long time, then struck his face with his hand and said: 'This is evil speech! This is the speech of Jahm! This is a Jahmi! Do not go near him.' It was also reported from Ahmad 1/309 that he said: 'The matter is confirmed against Abu Thawr; whoever says that Allah created Adam in the image of Adam is a Jahmi. And what image did Adam have before He created him?!' I say: We take from this the weakness of the interpretation adopted by Ibn Khuzaymah regarding the Hadith 'in His image', where he said: 'The son of Adam was created in the image in which the Most Merciful created Adam, then He breathed the soul into him.' Al-Dhahabi reported in 'Al-Siyar' 20/88 from Isma'il who said: 'Ibn Khuzaymah erred in the Hadith of the Image, but he is not to be defamed for that; rather, this specific point is not accepted from him.' I say: As for what was reported regarding Imam Ahmad authentication of the Hadith 'in the image of the Most Merciful', Ibn Abd al-Barr reported in 'Al-Tamhid' 7/147-148 that Ahmad's statement regarding the Hadith 'in His image' does not mean he authenticated the Hadith 'in the image of the Most Merciful'. Issue: Al-Hafiz said in 'Al-Fath' 5/217 (abridged): 'Allah created Adam in His image'; there is a difference of opinion regarding whom the pronoun refers to. The majority hold that it refers to the one being struck [in the context of 'do not strike the face'], due to the command to honor the face. Were it not that the intention was the reason for that, this sentence would have no connection to what preceded it. Al-Qurtubi said: Some returned the pronoun to Allah, holding on to what was reported in some chains: 'Allah created Adam in the image of the Most Merciful.' It is as if the one who narrated it reported it by meaning, holding on to what he imagined, and thus erred in that. 4. 'Al-Muntakhab' by Ibn Qudamah (164), 'Al-Sunnah' by Al-Khallal 1/118, 'Al-Fatawa' 28/512.
5. Narrated by Ahmad 2/367, he said: Surayj told us, he said: Abdullah bin Nafi' told us, he said: Ibn Abi Dhi'b told me, from Salih, the client of Al-Taw'amah, from Abu Hurayrah who said: A man sat with the Prophet (peace be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to him: 'Where are you from?' He said: 'A Berber.' So the Messenger of Allah said to him: 'Stand up and leave me.' He gestured with his elbow like this. When he stood up and left him, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) turned to us and said... the Hadith.
6. 'Al-Muntakhab' by Ibn Qudamah from 'Ilal Al-Khallal' (16).

text: 25 - What has been narrated regarding the Qadariyyah. There are two paths from Ibn Umar: The First: Via Nafi' from him: 'The Qadariyyah are the Magians of this Ummah. If they fall ill, do not visit them, and if they die, do not witness [their funerals].' Imam Ahmad said: It is Munkar from the narration of Abu Hazim from Nafi' (1); because he narrates from Abu Hazim from Ibn Umar (2), and it is narrated from Nafi' from other than the Hadith of Abu Hazim (3). The Second: The path of Umar bin Abdullah from him: 'Every nation has Magians, and the Magians of my Ummah are those who say: There is no destiny (Qadar). If they fall ill, do not visit them, and if they die, do not witness [their funerals]' (4). Imam Ahmad said: I do not think Umar bin Abdullah met Abdullah bin Umar (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim in 'Al-Sunnah' (338), he said: Ibrahim bin Abdullah Al-Harawi told us, he said: Zakariya bin Manzur told us, from Abu Hazim, from Nafi', from Ibn Umar, raised [to the Prophet].
2. Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim in 'Al-Sunnah' (338), he said: Ya'qub bin Hamid bin Kasib told us, Zakariya bin Yahya bin Manzur bin Tha'labah bin Abi Malik told us, from Abu Hazim bin Dinar, from Ibn Umar, raised [to the Prophet].
3. 'Masa'il Abi Dawud' from Ahmad (1895), 'Al-Muntakhab' by Ibn Qudamah from 'Ilal Al-Khallal' (157).
4. Narrated by Ahmad 2/86, he said: Anas bin Ayad told us, Umar bin Abdullah, client of Ghafrah, told us, from Abdullah bin Umar, raised [to the Prophet].
5. 'Al-Muntakhab' by Ibn Qudamah from 'Ilal Al-Khallal' (155).

text: 26 - What has been narrated regarding not declaring people of Tawhid (Monotheism) disbelievers due to a sin. The Hadith of Abu Al-Darda, Abu Umamah, Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', and Anas bin Malik, and in it: '...and he does not declare any of the people of Tawhid a disbeliever due to a sin' (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is fabricated and has no basis. How can it be, with the Hadith of the Prophet (peace be upon him): 'Whoever abandons the prayer has disbelieved' (2). It was said to him: 'Does he [the one who abandons prayer] inherit?' He said: 'He does not inherit nor is he inherited from' (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' 8/152, he said: Mahmud bin Muhammad Al-Wasiti told us, Muhammad bin Al-Sabah Al-Jarajara'i told us, Kathir bin Marwan Al-Filastini told us, from Abdullah bin Yazid Ibn Adam Al-Dimashqi, he said: Abu Al-Darda, Abu Umamah, Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', and Anas bin Malik told me, they said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came out to us one day while we were arguing about something regarding the religion. He became angry, an anger the likes of which he had never shown, then he rebuked us and said: 'Gently, O nation of Muhammad! Indeed, those before you were destroyed by this. They took to argumentation for its little benefit. Leave argumentation, for the believer does not argue. Leave argumentation, for the one who argues has fully realized his loss. Leave argumentation, for it is enough of a sin that you never cease to be argumentative. Leave argumentation, for I will not intercede for the argumentative one on the Day of Resurrection. Leave argumentation, for I am a guarantor of three houses in Paradise—in its gardens, its middle, and its highest part—for the one who leaves argumentation while being truthful. Leave argumentation, for the first thing my Lord forbade me from after the worship of idols was argumentation and drinking wine. Leave argumentation, for Satan has despaired of being worshipped, but he is satisfied from you with provocation—which is argumentation. Leave argumentation, for the Children of Israel split into seventy-one sects, and the Christians into seventy-two sects, all of them upon error except the Great Majority (Al-Sawad Al-A'zam).' They said: 'O Messenger of Allah, and who is the Great Majority?' He said: 'Whoever is upon what I and my companions are upon, whoever does not argue in the religion of Allah, and whoever does not declare anyone of the people of Tawhid a disbeliever due to a sin, he is forgiven.' Then he said: 'Indeed, Islam began as something strange and will return to being strange.' They said: 'O Messenger of Allah, and who are the strangers?' He said: 'Those who rectify when the people become corrupt, and do not argue in the religion of Allah, and do not declare anyone of the people of Tawhid a disbeliever due to a sin.'
2. Narrated by Muslim (82) from the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him).
3. 'Ahkam Al-Nisa' 63, 'Al-Jami' li-Ahkam Ahl Al-Dhimmah' by Al-Khallal 2/535, 'Bada'i Al-Fawa'id' 4/42.

text: 27 - What has been narrated regarding Intercession contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding intercession, until he mentioned the Dajjal (1). Imam Ahmad said: Hushaym used to say in the Hadith of Mu'aththir bin Afazah: 'He narrated to us.' And he also used to say: 'Mu'aththir bin Afazah narrated to us, Abdullah narrated to us,' and he used to raise it [to the Prophet]. Meaning the Hadith of intercession (2). The Second: The Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding intercession (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Imam Ahmad in 'Al-Musnad' 1/375, he said: Hushaym told us, Al-Awwam informed us, from Jabalah bin Suhaym, from Mu'aththir bin Afazah, from Ibn Mas'ud, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: 'I met Abraham, Moses, and Jesus on the night I was taken on the Night Journey.' He said: 'They discussed the matter of the Hour. They referred their matter to Abraham, who said: I have no knowledge of it. They referred the matter to Moses, who said: I have no knowledge of it. They referred the matter to Jesus, who said: As for its time of arrival, no one knows it except Allah. That is what my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, covenanted to me, that the Dajjal is coming out.' He said: 'And with me are two rods. When he sees me, he will melt as lead melts, and Allah will destroy him, until the stone and the tree will say: O Muslim, indeed beneath me is a disbeliever, so come and kill him. He said: So Allah will destroy them. Then the people will return to their lands, but Gog and Magog will come out from every elevation, rushing. They will trample their lands; they will not come upon anything except that they destroy it, and they will not pass by water except that they drink it. Then the people will return to me complaining about them. So I will supplicate to Allah against them, and Allah will destroy them and cause their death, until the earth reeks from the stench of their smell. He said: Then Allah, Mighty and Majestic, will send rain which will sweep away their bodies until it casts them into the sea.' Abdullah bin Ahmad said: My father said: Something escaped me here which I did not understand, 'like leather (Adim)'. And Yazid bin Harun said: 'Then the mountains will be blown away, and the earth will be stretched like leather.' Then he returned to the Hadith of Hushaym, saying: 'So regarding what my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, covenanted to me: that when that happens, the Hour will be like a pregnant woman who has completed her term, whose family does not know when she will surprise them with her birth, by night or by day.'
2. 'Masa'il Abi Dawud' from Ahmad (1991).
3. Narrated by Abu Awanah 1/158, he said: Ibn Al-Junayd told us, he said: Amr bin Asim told us, he said: Hammad bin Salamah told us, from Thabit, from Anas (H) and Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Hayyan the Muezzin told us =

text: Ahmad said: I did not hear this from him—meaning Amr bin Asim—neither in Baghdad nor in Basra, and I have never heard this at all. It was said: A man claims that you said to him, 'I only memorized it from him and did not write it down'? He said: 'I did not hear it from him, so how can I narrate it? Perhaps this man heard it from someone else. I did not hear it, so that I would memorize it and write it from him and narrate it. Perhaps this man heard it from someone else. And I myself did not hear this Hadith from anyone, nor from Amr bin Asim' (1). 28 - What has been narrated regarding the mention of the Pond (Hawd). The Hadith of Harithah bin Wahb (may Allah be pleased with him): Regarding the mention of the Pond, he said: 'Like what is between Medina and Sana'a' (2). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is Munkar. Al-Athram said to him: The Hadith of Ma'bad bin Khalid? He said: Yes, do you see this as true? And he smiled as if amazed. He denounced both of them from the narration of Shu'bah. Al-Uqayli said: And they are both known from the Hadith of the people (3).

text: 29 - What has been narrated regarding those who will enter Paradise without account. The Hadith of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him): 'Indeed, Allah the Exalted promised me that seventy thousand of my Ummah will enter Paradise without account...' (1) Abdullah said: I found this Hadith in my father's book in his handwriting, and he had crossed it out. I thought he crossed it out because it was a mistake; it is only from Zaid, from Abu Salam, from Abu Umamah (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in 'Al-Musnad' 5/250, he said: Isam bin Khalid told us, Safwan bin Amr told me, from Sulaym bin Amir Al-Khaba'iri and Abu Al-Yaman Al-Hawzani, from Abu Umamah, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said: 'Indeed, my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, promised me that seventy thousand of my Ummah will enter Paradise without account.' Yazid bin Al-Akhnas Al-Sulami said: By Allah, those are not in your Ummah except like the mottled fly among flies! So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, my Lord, Mighty and Majestic, has promised me seventy thousand, and with every thousand, seventy thousand, and He added for me three handfuls.' He said: 'So what is the width of your Pond, O Prophet of Allah?' He said: 'Like what is between Aden to Amman, and wider and wider,' gesturing with his hand. He said: 'In it are two spouts of gold and silver.' He said: 'And what is the water of your Pond?' He said: 'Water whiter than milk, sweeter in taste than honey, and more fragrant in scent than musk. Whoever drinks from it will never thirst thereafter.' Also narrated by Ahmad 5/268, Al-Tirmidhi (2437), and Ibn Majah (4286), all via Isma'il bin Ayyash, from Muhammad bin Ziyad Al-Alhani, from Abu Umamah.
2. 'Musnad Ahmad' 5/250.

text: 30 - What has been narrated regarding the children of Muslims who died before reaching the age of majority. The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): 'A sparrow from the sparrows of Paradise' (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is a Munkar Hadith (2). He said another time: He narrated the Hadith 'A sparrow from the sparrows of Paradise' (3). I say: Meaning: Talhah was alone in narrating it, and he did not tolerate his solitariness. He said another time: This is a weak Hadith, and he mentioned a man in it whom he deemed weak: meaning Talhah (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (2662), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Waki' told us, from Talhah bin Yahya, from his paternal aunt Aisha bint Talhah, from Aisha, Mother of the Believers, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was invited to the funeral of a boy from the Ansar, so I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! Glad tidings for him! A sparrow from the sparrows of Paradise! He did no evil nor did it reach him.' He said: 'Or other than that, O Aisha! Indeed, Allah created inhabitants for Paradise; He created them for it while they were in the loins of their fathers. And He created inhabitants for the Fire; He created them for it while they were in the loins of their fathers.'
2. 'Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib' 3/21.
3. 'Al-Du'afa' by Al-Uqayli 2/226, 'Al-Ilal', Abdullah's narration from Ahmad (1385).
4. 'Al-Jami' li-Ahkam Ahl Al-Milal' p. 71, 'Al-Mughni' by Ibn Qudamah 10/634, 'Ahkam Ahl Al-Dhimmah' by Ibn Al-Qayyim 2/78. 'Al-Muntakhab min Al-Ilal lil-Khallal' (10). Benefit: Al-Dhahabi said in 'Al-Mizan' 3/57: Talhah was alone with the beginning of the Hadith; as for its end, it came from more than one perspective. I say: The text has an authentic witness; Muslim narrated it (2662) via Al-Ala' bin Al-Musayyib, from Fudayl bin Amr, from Aisha bint Talhah, from Aisha, Mother of the Believers... the Hadith similarly.
