1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (197), he said: Mahmud bin Ghaylan told us, Abd Al-Razzaq told us, Sufyan informed us, from Awn bin Abi Juhayfah, from his father, who said: I saw Bilal making Adhan and turning, following his mouth here and here, with his two fingers in his ears, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was in a red leather tent of his—I think he said: made of leather. Bilal came out with the Anazah (short spear) and planted it in the stony ground, then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed towards it, with dogs and donkeys passing in front of him, and he was wearing a red garment; it is as if I am looking at the glimmer of his shins. Sufyan said: We think it was a Hibarah (Yemeni cloak).
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/560. Abridged. Issue: As for placing the finger in the ear, the majority of scholars hold it to be recommended (Mustahabb). Ishaq and Al-Awza'i said: He inserts his fingers in his ears during Iqamah as well. The view of Malik is that if he wishes he puts his fingers during his Adhan and Iqamah, and if he wishes he leaves it. Ahmad was lenient regarding leaving it and regarding putting fingers in one of the ears. The Shafi'is recommended inserting the fingers in the ears during Adhan but not Iqamah.
3. Narrated by Abu Dawud (532), he said: Musa bin Ismail and Dawud bin Shu'aib Al-Ma'ni told us, they said: Hammad told us, from Ayyub, from Nafi', from Ibn Umar that Bilal made Adhan before dawn broke, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) ordered him to return and call out: "Verily the slave has slept, verily the slave has stood up." Musa added: So he returned and called out: "Verily the slave has slept."

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Imam Ahmad denounced it against Hammad bin Salamah (1). 159 - What has been narrated regarding Adhan after Fajr. The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): When the Mu'adhdhin fell silent from the first [Adhan] of the Fajr prayer, he stood up and prayed two light Rak'ahs (2). Ahmad weakened the narration of Al-Awza'i from Al-Zuhri (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/512.
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud (1336), he said: Abd Al-Rahman bin Ibrahim and Nasr bin Asim—and this is his wording—said: Al-Walid told us, Al-Awza'i told us, and Nasr said: From Ibn Abi Dhi'b and Al-Awza'i, from Al-Zuhri, from Urwah, from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to pray eleven Rak'ahs between the time he finished 'Isha prayer until the dawn broke, saying the Taslim (salutation) after every two, and making Witr with one, and remaining in his prostration for the duration it takes one of you to read fifty verses before lifting his head. Then when the Mu'adhdhin fell silent from the first [call] of the Fajr prayer, he stood and prayed two light Rak'ahs, then lay down on his right side until the Mu'adhdhin came to him.
3. "Nasb Al-Rayah" 1/396, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/506. I say: The text is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari narrated it (618), he said: Abdullah bin Yusuf told us, Malik informed us, from Nafi', from Abdullah bin Umar, who said: Hafsah informed me that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to, when the Mu'adhdhin fell silent for the Morning prayer and the dawn appeared, pray two light Rak'ahs before the prayer was established.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 160 - What has been narrated regarding Adhan for the Imam. The Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade the Imam from being the Mu'adhdhin" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Al-Mu'alla bin Hilal is Matruk (abandoned) in Hadith, and his Hadith is fabricated (2). 161 - What has been narrated regarding 'The Imam is a guarantor and the Mu'adhdhin is entrusted'. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "The Imam is a guarantor (Dhamin) and the Mu'adhdhin is entrusted (Mu'taman)" (3). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith has no basis (4). He said once: Suhail narrated it from Al-A'mash, and Ibn Fudayl narrated it from Al-A'mash, from a man; I do not know of any basis for this Hadith (5). He said once: Hushaym did not hear the Hadith of Abu Salih from Al-A'mash (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Hibban in "Al-Majruhin" 3/17, he said: Ja'far bin Idris told us, he said: Ya'qub bin Yusuf Al-Mutawwa'i told us, he said: Khalaf bin Muhammad Kurdus told us, he said: Mu'alla bin Hilal told us, from Muhammad bin Suqah, from Muhammad bin Al-Munkadir, from Jabir, raised [to the Prophet].
2. "Nasb Al-Rayah" 1/405.
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (257), he said: Hannad told us, Abu Al-Ahwas and Abu Mu'awiyah told us, from Al-A'mash, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "The Imam is a guarantor and the Mu'adhdhin is entrusted. O Allah, guide the Imams and forgive the Mu'adhdhins."
4. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1871), "Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" 1/433, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 1/207.
5. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1871), "Al-Tamhid" 19/225.
6. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1871).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: And once: He weakened the entire Hadith (1). 162 - The time between Adhan and Iqamah. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Make between your Adhan and your Iqamah a pause the amount [of time] it takes for the eater to finish his food" (2). Imam Ahmad denied it strongly and said: Ma'arik, I do not know him. And Abdullah bin Sa'id is Abu Abbad, he is Munkar Al-Hadith (denounced in Hadith) (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Al-Tamhid" by Ibn Abd Al-Barr 19/225.
2. Narrated by Ibn Adi in "Al-Kamil" 6/452, he said: Ali bin Al-Husain bin Abd Al-Rahim told us, Al-Husain bin Isa told us, Abd Al-Samad bin Abd Al-Warith told us, Al-Ma'arik bin Abbad told us, from Abdullah bin Sa'id, from his father, from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to Bilal: "Make between your Adhan and your Iqamah a pause [so that] the one relieving himself finishes his ablution at leisure, and the one eating dinner finishes his dinner."
3. Narrated by Ibn Adi in "Al-Kamil" 6/452.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 163 - When the people should stand if they see the Imam at the Iqamah. The Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): "If the prayer is established, do not stand until you see me" (1). Imam Ahmad said: They claimed that Hammad bin Zaid said: We were with Thabit, and with him was Hajjaj bin Abi Uthman. He said: Hajjaj told us, Yahya bin Abi Kathir told us, from Ibn Abi Qatadah, from his father. So he mentioned the Hadith. Jarir thought that he narrated it from Thabit from Anas, so he narrated it [as such] (2). And once he denied it and said: I heard it from Hajjaj Al-Sawwaf from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abdullah bin Abi Qatadah, from his father in the gathering of Thabit, and he thought that he heard it from Thabit (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi (2028), he said: Jarir bin Hazim told us, from Thabit, from Anas, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said... The Hadith.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1857), "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (4555), "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 1/198.
3. "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 1/198-199. I say: The text is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari (637) and Muslim (604) narrated it from the Hadith of Hajjaj Al-Sawwaf, who said: Yahya bin Abi Kathir told us, from Abu Salamah and Abdullah bin Abi Qatadah, from Abu Qatadah, raised [to the Prophet]. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 3/587: The scholars differed regarding the time when the people should stand for prayer. A group said: They stand when the Mu'adhdhin finishes the Iqamah, whether the Imam has come out or not; some Shafi'is narrated this from Abu Hanifah and Al-Shafi'i. Ibn Al-Mundhir narrated from Abu Hanifah that if the Imam is not with them, he disliked that they stand in the row while the Imam is absent. =

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 164 - What has been narrated regarding rising when saying: 'Qad Qamat Al-Salah' (The prayer has been established). The Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Awfa (may Allah be pleased with him): When Bilal used to say 'Qad Qamat Al-Salah', the Prophet (peace be upon him) would rise (1). Ahmad denied it. He said: Al-Awwam did not meet Ibn Abi Awfa (2).
foot_note:
1. = And among those who narrated from them that they do not stand until they see the Imam: Umar bin Al-Khattab and Ali bin Abi Talib. The narration from Ahmad regarding whether they do not stand until they see him varies due to the Hadith of Abu Qatadah; and it is narrated from him that they stand before seeing him if the prayer is established, due to the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah which Muslim narrated. Imam Ahmad said in the narration of Al-Marwazi: If they wish, they stand before seeing him, and if they wish, they do not stand until they see him. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/142: If the Imam is not in the mosque, the majority went to the view that they do not stand until they see him.
1. "Musnad Al-Bazzar" 8/298 (3371), he said: Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna informed us, he said: Hajjaj bin Farruj told us, from Al-Awwam bin Hawshab, from Ibn Abi Awfa, who said: When Bilal used to say 'Qad Qamat Al-Salah', the Prophet (peace be upon him) would rise.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/590, "Jami' Al-Tahsil" 249.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 165 - If the Imam says: 'Stay in your places until I return'. Al-Hasan bin Thawab said: It was said to Abu Abdullah—meaning Ahmad bin Hanbal—while I was listening: The Prophet (peace be upon him), when he gestured to them to stay, then entered and performed ablution then came out; did he say the Takbir? He said: It is narrated that he said Takbir (1). And the Hadith of Abu Salamah (2): When the people took their places in the row, he said to them: "Stay," then he came out and said Takbir. Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath": Ahmad clarified that the Hadith of Abu Salamah from Abu Hurayrah indicates that he did not use to say Takbir [before leaving]. As for his saying: (It is narrated that he said Takbir), it indicates that this has been narrated and that it contradicts the Hadith of Abu Salamah from Abu Hurayrah, and that the Hadith of Abu Salamah is more authentic, and the practice is based upon it (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 5/41, he said: Zaid told us, Hammad bin Salamah informed us, from Ziyad Al-A'lam, from Al-Hasan, from Abu Bakrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) started the prayer and said Takbir, then gestured to them 'stay in your places', then entered and came out with his head dripping, and prayed with them. When he finished the prayer he said: "I am only a human, and I was Junub."
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (645), he said: Ishaq told us, Muhammad bin Yusuf told us, Al-Awza'i told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Abu Salamah bin Abd Al-Rahman, from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The prayer was established and the people straightened their rows. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came out and stepped forward—and he was Junub—then said: "Stay in your places." So he returned and bathed, then came out with his head dripping water and prayed with them.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" 3/598.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 166 - What has been narrated regarding Adhan and Iqamah for combining two prayers. The long Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding the description of Hajj, and in it: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed Dhuhr and 'Asr with one Adhan in 'Arafah and did not praise [Allah] (Tasbih/pray Sunnah) between them, and with two Iqamahs; and he prayed Maghrib and 'Isha at Jam' (Muzdalifah) with one Adhan and two Iqamahs and did not praise [Allah] between them (1). Imam Ahmad said: Hatim erred in this long Hadith (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (1218), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah and Ishaq bin Ibrahim told us, both from Hatim; Abu Bakr said: Hatim bin Isma'il Al-Madani told us, from Ja'far, from his father, who said: We entered upon Jabir bin Abdullah... The long Hadith regarding the description of the Prophet's Hajj (peace be upon him).
2. "Mukhtasar Khilafiyat Al-Bayhaqi" 1/488, "Sunan Al-Bayhaqi" 1/400 and he attributed it to Abu Dawud in "Al-Sunan" but I did not find it, then I found it in "Awn Al-Ma'bud". Abu Dawud narrated this Hadith as Mursal without mentioning Jabir, number (1956), he said: Abdullah bin Salamah told us, Sulayman—meaning Ibn Bilal—told us, and Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, Abd Al-Wahhab Al-Thaqafi told us—the meaning is one—from Ja'far bin Muhammad, from his father that the Prophet (peace be upon him)... And in it: He prayed Maghrib and 'Isha with one Adhan and two Iqamahs. Abu Dawud said: Hatim connected this Hadith (made it Musnad), and Muhammad bin Ali Al-Ju'fi agreed with him on its chain, from Ja'far, from his father, from Jabir. Al-Bayhaqi said 1/400: And Hafs bin Ghiyath narrated it from Ja'far, as Hatim narrated it.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Chapters on Mosques. 167 - Prayer in the graveyard and the bathhouse. The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him): "The earth is all a mosque (place of prayer) except the graveyard and the bathhouse" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Sufyan narrated it to us and practiced Tadlis (concealment) in it. And he said once: Sufyan said: I did not hear from him—meaning Yahya bin Sa'id—the Hadith of Amr bin Yahya, from his father, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) regarding the graveyard and the bathhouse (2). 168 - What has been narrated regarding establishing mosques in houses. The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) commanded that mosques be established in houses and that they be cleaned and perfumed (3). Imam Ahmad denied that it is connected (Wasl) (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Imam Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 3/83, he said: Yazid bin Harun told us, Sufyan and Hammad bin Salamah informed us, from Amr bin Yahya, from his father; Hammad said in his Hadith: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri; and Sufyan did not cross his father [in the chain].
2. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (176).
3. Narrated by Ibn Majah (759), he said: Rizq Allah bin Musa told us, Ya'qub bin Ishaq Al-Hadrami told us, Za'idah bin Qudamah told us, from Hisham bin Urwah, from his father, from Aisha, raised [to the Prophet].
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/173.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 169 - What one says when entering the mosque. The Hadith of Fatimah (may Allah be pleased with her): "My Lord, forgive me my sins and open for me the doors of Your mercy" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is not from the Hadith of Asim Al-Ahwal; this is from the Hadith of Layth bin Abi Sulaym (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (314), he said: Ali bin Hajar told us, Ismail bin Ibrahim told us, from Layth, from Abdullah bin Al-Hasan, from his mother Fatimah bint Al-Husain, from her grandmother Fatimah the Elder, who said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered the mosque, he would send blessings upon Muhammad and grant peace, and say: "My Lord, forgive me my sins and open for me the doors of Your mercy." And when he exited, he would send blessings upon Muhammad and grant peace, and say: "My Lord, forgive me my sins and open for me the doors of Your bounty."
2. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (2700), "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 1/255, "Al-Kamil fi Al-Du'afa" 2/372, "Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala" 9/41. I say: The most authentic narration in this chapter is what Muslim narrated (712) from the Hadith of Abu Humaid—or from Abu Usaid—who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If one of you enters the mosque, let him say: O Allah, open for me the doors of Your mercy. And when he exits, let him say: O Allah, I ask You of Your bounty."

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 170 - What has been narrated regarding greeting the mosque (Tahiyyat Al-Masjid). The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): That he (peace be upon him) entered the mosque and sat hugging his knees (Ihtaba) and did not pray the two Rak'ahs (1). Imam Ahmad said, when asked: Is this Mahfuz (preserved)? He said: Yes (2). 171 - What has been narrated regarding the Mihrab (prayer niche) in the mosque. Imam Ahmad said: I do not know of any Hadith that is established regarding it. Meaning: regarding the dislike of the Mihrab in the mosque (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 2/531, he said: Hammad Al-Khayyat told us, Hisham bin Sa'd told us, from Nu'aim bin Abdullah Al-Mujmir, from Abu Hurayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out to the market of Bani Qainuqa' leaning on my hand, and he walked around in it then returned and sat hugging his knees in the mosque and said: "Where is Luka' (little one)? Call Luka' for me." So Al-Hasan came... The Hadith.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/464. Ibn Rajab said: This Hadith is very Gharib (strange) and its being raised [to the Prophet] is wondrous; perhaps it is Mawquf (stopped at the Companion). Al-Marwazi said, quoting from Ibn Rajab 2/464: I saw Abu Abdullah often enter the mosque and sit without praying, then leave without praying during the times of prayer. I say: There is a narration from Ahmad that the one entering the mosque should not sit until he prays. I say: Established, authentic Hadiths have been reported commanding the greeting of the mosque before sitting, among them: What Al-Bukhari narrated (444) from the Hadith of Abu Qatadah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If one of you enters the mosque, let him pray two Rak'ahs before he sits." Issue: The command for the one who enters the mosque to pray two Rak'ahs is by way of recommendation, not obligation, according to all scholars of consideration; the view of its obligation is only narrated from some of the Zahiris (Literalists).
3. "Masa'il Ishaq bin Mansur Al-Kawsaj" (248).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Chapters on facing the Qiblah. 172 - What has been narrated that between the East and the West is a Qiblah. It contains two Hadiths: First: The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah: "What is between the East and the West is a Qiblah" (1). Imam Ahmad said: It has no Isnad (chain) (2). And once Al-Zayla'i said: Ahmad spoke regarding it (3). Second: The Hadith of Ibn Umar (4) (may Allah be pleased with them both), similar to it.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi number (344), he said: Al-Hasan bin Abi Bakr Al-Marwazi told us, Al-Mu'alla bin Mansur told us, Abdullah bin Ja'far Al-Makhrami told us, from Uthman bin Muhammad Al-Akhnasi, from Sa'id Al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "What is between the East and the West is a Qiblah."
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1904), "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/289. Abu Dawud said in his "Masa'il": It has no Isnad. Meaning: The Hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far Al-Makhrami, from the son of Miswar bin Makhramah, from Uthman Al-Akhnasi, from Al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurayrah, raised [to the Prophet]. By saying "It has no Isnad," he intends the condition of Uthman Al-Akhnasi, because there is Nakarah (denouncement) in his Hadith. Ibn Rajab said in "Fath Al-Bari" 2/289: It has no Isnad. Meaning: There is weakness in its chains.
3. "Nasb Al-Rayah" 1/418.
4. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi in his "Sunan" 2/9, he said: Abu Abdullah Al-Hafiz informed us, Abu Al-Abbas Muhammad bin Ahmad Al-Mahbubi told us in Marw, Sa'id bin Mas'ud told us, Yazid bin Harun told us, Muhammad bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Al-Mujabbar informed us, from Nafi', from Ibn Umar, raised [to the Prophet]. And the Mawquf (stopped) Hadith was also narrated by Al-Bayhaqi 2/9, he said: The Jurist Abu Bakr Muhammad bin =

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Imam Ahmad said: The correct view regarding it is that it is Mawquf (stopped) at Umar (1).
foot_note:
1. = Bakr Al-Tusi informed us, Abu Bishr Muhammad bin Ahmad Al-Hadiri told us, Abu Al-Hasan Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Zuhair told us, Abdullah bin Hashim told us, Yahya bin Sa'id told us, Ubaidullah told us, Nafi' informed me, from Ibn Umar, from Umar as his saying.
1. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/292. I say: Several Hadiths have been reported in this chapter as raised [to the Prophet], but their chains are not free from criticism. Benefit: Imam Ahmad said: What is between the East and the West is a Qiblah for us, the people of the East; it is not for the people of Al-Sham nor the people of Yemen.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Chapters on the virtue of maintaining the prayers. 173 - What has been narrated regarding the bequest of the Prophet (peace be upon him) about prayer during his illness. The Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): "The prayer and what your right hands possess" (1). Al-Athram said: Al-Taimi erred in it; it was only narrated by Qatadah from Abu Al-Khalil, from Safinah, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) (2), and this is an outrageous mistake. Al-Athram said: I presented all this speech to Imam Ahmad, and he said: This is Idtirab (disturbance) (3). 174 - What has been narrated regarding affirming faith for the one who maintains the prayers. The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him): "If you see a man frequenting the mosque, then bear witness for him with faith" (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (2697), he said: Ahmad bin Al-Miqdam told us, Al-Mu'tamir bin Sulayman told us, I heard my father narrate from Qatadah, from Anas who said: The general bequest of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) when death attended him, and he was gargling [with the soul], was: "The prayer and what your right hands possess."
2. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1623), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Yazid bin Harun told us, Hammam told us, from Qatadah, from Salih Abu Al-Khalil, from Safinah, from Umm Salamah, raised [to the Prophet].
3. "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" (341-342).
4. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (2617), he said: Ibn Abi Umar told us, Abdullah bin Wahb told us, from Amr bin Al-Harith, from Darraj Abu Al-Samh, from Abu Al-Haytham, from Abu Sa'id, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If you see a man frequenting the mosque, then bear witness for him with faith, for Allah the Exalted says: {The mosques of Allah are only to be maintained by those who believe in Allah and the Last Day and establish prayer and give zakah and do not fear except Allah, for it is expected that those will be of the [rightly] guided} [At-Tawbah: 18]"

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Imam Ahmad said: Munkar (denounced) (1). 175 - What has been narrated regarding the first thing the slave is accounted for is the prayer. The Hadith of Tamim Al-Dari (may Allah be pleased with him): "The first thing the slave is accounted for on the Day of Resurrection is his prayer" (2). Imam Ahmad said: I do not think Zurarah met Tamim; Tamim was in Sham (Levant) and Zurarah was Basran, he was its judge (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/481.
2. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1426), he said: Ahmad bin Sa'id Al-Darimi told us, Sulayman bin Harb told us, Hammad bin Salamah told us, from Dawud bin Abi Hind, from Zurarah bin Awfa, from Tamim, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "The first thing the slave is accounted for on the Day of Resurrection is his prayer. If he completed it, it is written for him as voluntary [reward]; if he did not complete it, Allah Glory be to Him says to His angels: Look, do you find for My slave any voluntary deeds? Then complete with them what he wasted of his obligatory deeds. Then deeds are taken according to that."
3. "Jami' Al-Tahsil" 176, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/361.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 176 - What has been narrated regarding the lifting of mistake and forgetfulness from the Ummah. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, and it has two paths: The First Path: From the Hadith of Al-Awza'i from Ata with it (1). Imam Ahmad said: Very Munkar. He said: It is not narrated except from Al-Hasan from the Prophet (peace be upon him) as Mursal (2). The Second Path: From the Hadith of Muslim bin Khalid Al-Zanji from Ibn Abbas (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is not Marfu' (raised to the Prophet); it is only from Ibn Abbas as his saying. He said: Sa'id bin Abi Salih narrated it, and I do not know his condition, and I do not know of anyone who narrated from him other than Muslim bin Khalid (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (2045), he said: Muhammad bin Al-Musaffa Al-Himsi told us, Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, Al-Awza'i told us, from Ata, from Ibn Abbas, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Indeed, Allah has waived for my Ummah the mistake, forgetfulness, and what they are coerced into."
2. "Al-Du'afa lil-Uqayli" 4/145, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/76, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 1/282, "Jami' Al-Ulum wa Al-Hikam" 325, "Ilal Abdullah" (1340), "Al-Maqasid Al-Hasanah" 229, "Mizan Al-I'tidal" 5/168, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 5/294. And it is what Abd Al-Razzaq narrated 6/409-410 from Hisham bin Hassan, from Al-Hasan who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said... The Hadith.
3. Narrated by Al-Tabarani (11274), he said: Ali bin Abd Al-Aziz told us, Mu'alla bin Mahdi Al-Mawsili told us, Muslim bin Khalid Al-Zanji told us, Sa'id—he is Al-Allaf—told me, from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said... The Hadith.
4. "Jami' Al-Ulum wa Al-Hikam" 326.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
The Second Hadith: From Ibn Omar (similar to it) (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Munkar (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi in his "Sunan" 6/84, he said: Abu Abdullah Al-Hafiz informed us, Abu Sa'id Muhammad bin Ya'qub informed me, Abu Al-Abbas Al-Saqr Al-Sukkari told us, Muhammad bin Al-Musaffa told us, Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, Malik told us, from Nafi', from Ibn Omar that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said... The Hadith.
2. "Jami' al-Ulum wa al-Hikam" 326. I say: And Imam Ahmad's statement 'It is only narrated from Al-Hasan', this is an indication of the weakening of all paths of this Hadith, such as the path of Abu Dharr, Abu Al-Darda, Ibn Omar, Uqbah bin Amir, Thawban, and others. Abu Hatim Al-Razi, may Allah have mercy on him, also went in "Al-Ilal" to weakening all the paths as well. Issue: Al-Hafiz quoted in "Al-Talkhis" 2/282 from Al-Khallal from Ahmad, he said: Whoever claims that mistake and forgetfulness are lifted has contradicted the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for Allah has obligated expiation for killing a soul by mistake. Meaning whoever claims their lifting in general in the address of situation (Wad') and obligation (Taklif). I say: What suffices instead of this Hadith is what Muslim narrated (126) via the path of Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, he said: When this verse was revealed {Whether you disclose what is in yourselves or conceal it, Allah will call you to account for it} [Al-Baqarah: 284], he said: Something entered their hearts from it which bad not entered their hearts from anything else. So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Say: We hear and we obey and we submit." He said: So Allah cast faith into their hearts, and He revealed {Allah does not burden a soul beyond its capacity. It will have [the consequence of] what [good] it has gained, and it will bear [the consequence of] what [evil] it has earned. Our Lord, do not impose blame upon us if we have forgotten or erred} [Al-Baqarah: 286]. He said: I have done so. {Our Lord, and lay not upon us a burden like that which You laid upon those before us. Our Lord} [Al-Baqarah: 286]. He said: I have done so. {And forgive us; and have mercy upon us. You are our protector} [Al-Baqarah: 286]. He said: I have done so.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
177 - What has been reported regarding teaching children prayer
The Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Command the boy to pray when he reaches seven years" (1).
Imam Ahmad was asked about Sawwar who narrates this Hadith, so he said: A Basran Sheikh, there is no harm in him. Waki' narrated from him and flipped his name. He is a Sheikh whom they trust in Basra; nothing other than this Hadith was narrated from him (2).
And he said once: They contradicted Waki' regarding the name of this Sheikh - meaning: Dawood bin Sawwar. Ahmad said: Al-Tufawi Muhammad bin Abdul-Rahman and Al-Bursani said: Sawwar Abu Hamza (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (495), he said: Mu'ammal bin Hisham - meaning Al-Yashkuri - told us, Ismail told us, from Sawwar Abu Hamza - Abu Dawood said: And he is Sawwar bin Dawood Abu Hamza Al-Muzani Al-Sayrafi - from Amr bin Shu'ayb, from his father, from his grandfather in a Marfu' form.
2. "Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil" 4/272, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 12/237, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 2/453.
3. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (47).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
178 - What has been reported regarding getting close to the Qiblah
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "Get close (Arhiqu) to the Qiblah" (1).
Ibn Hani said: I asked Abu Abdullah: What is the meaning of a Hadith that came: "Get close to the Qiblah"? He said: I do not know what it is, but it is something narrated by Ibn Al-Mubarak from Ma'mar from Al-Hasan, and I do not know what this is (2).

179 - The reason for which getting close to the Sutrah was commanded
The Hadith of Sahl bin Abi Hathma, may Allah be pleased with him: "If one of you prays towards a Sutrah, let him get close to it so that Satan does not cut off his prayer upon him" (3).
Imam Ahmad said: Good (Salih), there is no harm in its chain (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Musnad Abu Ya'la" 8/253, he said: Harun bin Ma'ruf told us, Bishr bin Al-Sari told us, he said: Mus'ab bin Thabit told me, from Hisham bin Urwa, from his father, from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Get close to the Qiblah."
2. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2012), Arhiqu: meaning get close to the Sutrah towards which you pray. I say: And the text regarding getting close to the Sutrah is established, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (496) from the path of Abdul-Aziz bin Abi Hazim, from his father, from Sahl, he said: Between the place of prayer of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the wall was the passage of a sheep.
3. Narrated by Ahmad 4/2, he said: Sufyan bin Uyaynah told us, from Safwan bin Sulaym, from Nafi' bin Jubayr, from Sahl bin Abi Hathma, attributing it to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And Sufyan said once: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If one of you prays..." The Hadith.
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/624. Benefit: Al-Baghawi said: The people of knowledge recommended getting close to the Sutrah, such that between him and it is the amount of possible prostration, and likewise between the rows. Quoted from Al-Hafiz in "Al-Fath" 1/685.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
180 - What has been reported regarding the line if one does not find a stick for Sutrah
The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: "If one of you prays, let him place something in front of his face. If he does not find something, let him set up a stick. If he does not have a stick, let him draw a line" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Authentic (Sahih) (2). And he said once: Weak (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 2/249, he said: Sufyan told us, from Ismail bin Umayyah, from Abu Muhammad bin Amr bin Hurayth Al-Adhri, he said once: from Abu Amr bin Muhammad bin Hurayth, from his grandfather, I heard Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, saying: Abu Al-Qasim said: "If one of you prays..." The Hadith.
2. "Al-Tamhid" 4/199, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 1/286.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/637, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 6/418. Ibn Rajab said in "Fath Al-Bari": Imam Ahmad was not known to explicitly declare it authentic; rather, his method is to act upon the line, and he may have relied on the Mawquf traditions, not the Marfu' Hadith. Issue: As for the line on the ground if one does not find something to screen himself with, there are two opinions. One: That screening is achieved by it as well, which is the saying of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, Ata, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Al-Awza'i, and Al-Shafi'i in one of his two sayings and favored by many of his companions, and Ahmad, Ishaq, and Abu Thawr. The second: That it is not a Sutrah, which is the saying of Malik, Al-Nakha'i, Al-Layth, Abu Hanifa, and Al-Shafi'i in the New [School]. Malik said: The line is invalid.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
181 - The Sutrah of the Imam is a Sutrah for those behind him
The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: I came, myself and a boy, and we left the donkey in front of the row (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It is not quite right (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (716), he said: Musaddad told us, Abu Awana told us, from Mansur, from Al-Hakam, from Yahya bin Al-Jazzar, from Abu Al-Sahba', he said: We discussed what cuts off the prayer at Ibn Abbas's, so he said: I came, myself and a boy from Bani Abdul-Muttalib on a donkey while the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was praying. So he dismounted and I dismounted, and we left the donkey in front of the row, and he did not mind it. And two girls from Bani Abdul-Muttalib came and entered between the row, and he did not mind that.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" commentary of Ibn Rajab 2/611. I say: This Hadith has been narrated dropping Abu Al-Sahba' by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 1/224. Ibn Rajab said: And Ahmad's words indicate that the correct version includes him in the chain. Ibn Rajab said: Perhaps Imam Ahmad saw that this Suhayb is not known, and he is not Abu Al-Sahba' Al-Bakri the Mawla of Ibn Abbas; for that one is Madani. I say: And the text is established in Al-Bukhari similarly (493) with a change in some words from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: I came riding on a female donkey, and I had at that time neared puberty, while the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was praying with the people at Mina towards no wall. So I passed in front of part of the row, then dismounted and sent the female donkey to graze, and I entered the row, and no one denied that against me.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
182 - What has been reported regarding what cuts off the prayer
It contains three Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "The prayer is cut off by a menstruating woman and a dog" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Yahya told us it, he said: Shu'ba elevated it, and Hisham did not elevate it. Imam Ahmad said: Hisham was a Hafiz. Ibn Rajab said: This is a preference by Ahmad for its being Mawquf (stopped) (2).
The Second: The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "The prayer is cut off by a woman, a donkey, and a black dog" (3).
Imam Ahmad said: The Sheikh erred; this is from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, while she says: 'You have equated us with dogs and donkeys.' Meaning: If they had it from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, she would not have said that (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (703), he said: Musaddad told us, Yahya told us, from Shu'ba, Qatada told us, he said: I heard Jabir bin Zaid narrating from Ibn Abbas - Shu'ba elevated it - he said: "The prayer is cut off by a menstruating woman and a dog."
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/703.
3. Mentioned by Ibn Rajab in "Al-Fath" 2/705 via the path of Al-Hawdhi, from Al-Aswad, from Aisha in a Marfu' form with it.
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/705. As for the Hadith of Aisha, Al-Bukhari narrated it (514) via the path of Al-Aswad from Aisha: 'What cuts off the prayer - the dog, the donkey, and the woman - was mentioned in her presence, so she said: You have likened us to donkeys and dogs. By Allah, I saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, praying while I was on the bed between him and the Qiblah, lying down.'

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
The Third: The Hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him: "The prayer is cut off by a donkey, a woman, and a black dog" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It is authentic in chain, and I adhere to it. And he said once: It is an established Hadith narrated by Shu'ba and Sulayman bin Al-Mughira: meaning from Humayd bin Hilal. Then he said: There is nothing in my soul [doubt] regarding this Hadith. And he said once: Bring other than the Hadith of Abu Dharr, its chain is not authentic. Then he mentioned the Hadith of Al-Fadl bin Abbas that he passed some of the row while on a donkey. It was said to him: There was a short spear (Anazah) in front of him? He said: This Hadith was in an open space (2).
And he said once: Nothing cuts off the prayer except the black dog, and in my soul there is something regarding the woman and the donkey (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (510), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Ismail bin Ulayyah told us. He said: And Zuhair bin Harb told me, Ismail bin Ibrahim told us, from Yunus, from Humayd Ibn Hilal, from Abdullah bin Al-Samit, from Abu Dharr, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said... and he mentioned it.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/700-701, "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (330) on the wording: There is nothing of it in my heart.
3. "Sunan Al-Tirmidhi" 2/163, "Al-Tamhid" 21/167, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/88, "Tabaqat Al-Hanabila" 1/215, "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (330) on the wording: Nothing cuts it off except the black dog, "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Al-Jawzi 3/208-209, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 1/442. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 2/715: As for the majority of the people of knowledge who did not see the cutting off of prayer and its invalidation by the passing of something in front of the praying person, their approaches differed regarding the Hadiths

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
183 - What has been reported regarding the sin of the one passing in front of the praying person
The Hadith of Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani, may Allah be pleased with him: "For one of you to stay for forty is better for him than to pass in front of the praying person" - he does not know if forty years or forty months (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Uyaynah was deluded and erred in making the Hadith from the Musnad of Zaid bin Khalid (2).
foot_note:
1. = narrated about it. Some of them spoke regarding their chains, and this is the method of Al-Bukhari; for he did not extract any of them. And some of them claimed abrogation. Al-Shafi'i and Ahmad weakened the claim of abrogation. I say: The Hanbalis limited the invalidation of prayer to the passing of a black dog; due to opposing these Hadiths with the agreed-upon Hadith of Ibn Abbas who passed riding on a donkey then dismounted and left the female donkey grazing between the rows, and the Hadith of Aisha implying the Prophet's prayer while she was lying across between him and the Qiblah. So the black dog remained without an opponent, so it must be upheld due to its establishment and lack of opponent. Al-Nawawi refuted these Hadiths which are authentic to the Hanbalis with what Al-Shafi'i, Al-Khattabi, Al-Bayhaqi, and the verifiers among the jurists answered, that the intended meaning of cutting off is: Cutting off from humility (Khushu') and remembrance due to being occupied by it and turning towards it, not that it invalidates the prayer. See "Al-Majmu'" 3/232.
1. Narrated by Al-Humaidi (817), he said: Al-Humaidi told us, he said: Sufyan told us, he said: Salim Abu Al-Nadr told us, from Busr bin Sa'id, he said: Abu Al-Juhaym sent me to ask Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani: What did you hear regarding the one who passes in front of the praying person?... The Hadith.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/95. I say: And the Hadith is established from the Musnad of Abu Al-Juhaym in the two Sahihs.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
184 - What has been reported regarding straightening the row
The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: "Straighten your rows; for indeed, straightening the row is part of the excellence of prayer" (1).
Ahmad was asked: Who is the one who said: I overlooked four Hadiths of Qatada? He said: Shu'ba, one of them is: "Straighten your rows" (2).

185 - What has been reported regarding who should be behind the Imam in the row
The Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: "Let those of you who possess intellect and understanding stand directly behind me" (3).
Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 3/179, he said: Waki' told us, Shu'ba told us, from Qatada, from Anas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Straighten your rows..." The Hadith.
2. "Su'alat Abi Dawood" (538). I say: And the text of the Hadith is established and authentic in "Sahih Muslim" (435) via the path of Ma'mar, from Hammam bin Munabbih, he said: This is what Abu Huraira told us from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he mentioned Hadiths, among them: And he said: "Straighten the row in prayer; for the row is part of the excellence of prayer."
3. Narrated by Muslim (432), he said: Yahya bin Habib Al-Harithi and Salih bin Hatim bin Wardan told us, they said: Yazid bin Zuray' told us, Khalid Al-Hadhdha told me, from Abu Ma'shar, from Ibrahim, from Alqama, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Let those of you who possess intellect and understanding stand directly behind me, then those who follow them - three times - and beware of the tumult of the markets."
4. "Ilal Muslim" by Abu Al-Fadl bin Ammar Al-Shahid p. 81 number (12). I say: And the text is established in Muslim (432) from the Hadith of Abu Mas'ud without the phrase: "And beware of the tumult of the markets."

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
186 - What has been reported regarding the Imam being appointed only to be followed
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, became heavy [ill], so he said: "Have the people prayed?" We said: No, they are waiting for you... And in it: Abu Bakr began praying, following the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the people following the prayer of Abu Bakr, while the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sitting (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Za'idah narrated it, and there was disagreement regarding him. The majority said from him: That Abu Bakr was praying while standing following the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the people following the prayer of Abu Bakr.
And Abdul-Rahman bin Mahdi (2) narrated it from Za'idah and said in his Hadith: So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed sitting, and Abu Bakr was praying with the people while standing.
And he said once: Abdul-Rahman erred in this place, or Za'idah erred for Abdul-Rahman. Abdul-Samad (3) and Mu'awiyah narrated it and contradicted Abdul-Rahman, and it is...
foot_note:
1. = Benefit: The Hadith is established from other than this path, for Imam Muslim narrated it (432) via the path of Abu Mas'ud, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to touch our shoulders in prayer and say: "Straighten up and do not differ, lest your hearts differ. Let those of you who possess intellect and understanding stand directly behind me, then those who follow them, then those who follow them."
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (687), he said: Ahmad bin Yunus told us, he said: Za'idah told us, from Musa Ibn Abi Aisha, from Ubayd bin Abdullah bin Utbah, he said: I entered upon Aisha and said: Will you not tell me about the illness of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. She said: Yes... The Hadith.
2. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 6/251, he said: Abdul-Rahman bin Mahdi told us, he said: Za'idah told us, from Musa bin Abi Aisha, from Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah, from Aisha... And in it: So Abu Bakr began praying standing, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sitting.
3. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 6/251, he said: Abdul-Samad and Mu'awiyah bin Amr told us, they said: Za'idah told us, Musa bin Abi Aisha told us, from Ubaydullah bin Abdullah, he said: I entered upon Aisha... And in it: So Abu Bakr began praying while standing following the prayer of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the people were praying following the prayer of Abu Bakr, and the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sitting.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
the correct one, what Abdul-Samad and Mu'awiyah said (1). Imam Ahmad preferred the narration of the majority from Za'idah over the narration of Ibn Mahdi (2).

187 - What has been reported regarding appointing the best looking one for leadership in prayer
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "Let the best looking among them lead the people" (3).
Imam Ahmad said: This is a bad Hadith, and it is not authentic (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Book "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (5350).
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/86.
3. Narrated by Ibn Al-Jawzi in "Al-Mawdu'at" as Mawquf and Marfu' from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her 2/99-100, he said: I was informed by Abdullah bin Abdullah Al-Sasi, Abu Al-Abbas Ahmad bin Muhammad Al-Basri the Judge informed us, Abu Ali Al-Zajjaji the Judge told us, Ali bin Al-Hasan Al-Maruzi told us, Al-Hadrami told us, Hassan bin Yusuf told us, Muhammad bin Marwan told us, from Hisham bin Urwa, from his father, from Aisha in a Marfu' form with it.
4. "Al-Mawdu'at" by Ibn Al-Jawzi 2/100.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
188 - What has been reported regarding what is incumbent upon the Imam
The Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi: "The Imam is a guarantor; if he does well, it is for him and for them, and if he does badly - meaning - it is upon him and not upon them" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: I never heard of this. Ibn Rajab said: This implies his denouncement of it (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (981), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Sa'id bin Sulayman told us, Abdul-Hamid bin Sulayman the brother of Fulaih told us, Abu Hazim told us, he said: Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi used to push forward the youths of his people to lead them in prayer. It was said to him: You do this while you have such precedence? He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying... The Hadith.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/179.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
189 - The Imam praying behind a man from his flock
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, regarding the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, during his illness. Imam Ahmad preferred the narration of Bakr bin Isa (1). In it: That Abu Bakr prayed with the people while the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was in the row, according to the narration of Shababa (2). In it: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed behind Abu Bakr during his illness while sitting. And he mentioned that it contradicts it (3). And he said once: Bakr bin Isa narrated it and contradicted him in his words. It was said to him: And did he elevate it (Isnad) as well? He said: Yes, he said: From Abu Wa'il, from Masruq, from Aisha (4). I say: Ibn Rajab said: It does not contradict it; for the meaning of 'row' is the row of the followers, so they are thus the same meaning.
foot_note:

text:
190 - What has been reported regarding the one praying obligatory prayer leading behind one praying voluntary prayer
The Hadith of Mu'adh, may Allah be pleased with him: Mu'adh bin Jabal used to pray with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then return and lead his people, so he prayed Isha and recited Al-Baqarah (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It contains inconsistency (Idtirab), and if it is established, it has a precise meaning that is not permissible to do today (2). And he said once: I used to follow it - meaning the Hadith of Mu'adh - then it became weak according to me. And he said once: What strengthens the Hadith of Mu'adh: The Hadith of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he prayed the Fear Prayer with two groups, two Rak'ahs with each group, and I do not know anything that refutes this (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (751), he said: Muhammad bin Bashar told us, he said: Gundar told us, he said: Shu'ba told us, from Amr, he said: I heard Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, saying: Mu'adh bin Jabal used to pray with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then return and lead his people. So he prayed Isha and recited Al-Baqarah, so a man left. It seemed as if Mu'adh criticized him, so it reached the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he said: "Are you a trial (Fattan), are you a trial?" (three times) or he said: "Are you putting us to trial, are you putting us to trial, are you putting us to trial?" And he ordered him to recite two Surahs from the middle of the Mufassal. Amr said: I do not memorize them.
2. "Tabaqat Al-Hanabila" 1/92, "Al-Manhaj Al-Ahmad" 1/199.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/227. Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 4/227 regarding the factors Imam Ahmad relied on in weakening the Hadith. First: That the Hadith of Mu'adh was narrated by a group who did not mention in it that Mu'adh used to pray behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; rather, they mentioned that he used to lead his people and prolong it for them. Among them are Abdul-Aziz bin Suhaib from Anas, and Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir, and among them Muharib bin Dithar and Abu Salih from Jabir. Second: That those who mentioned: That he used to pray behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then return and lead his people, none of them mentioned that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, knew of that, except Ibn Uyaynah, from Amr bin Dinar, from Jabir.

publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
foot_note: 1. = Ahmad said: I do not regard that as preserved. And he said once: It is nothing to me. Mansur bin Zadhan, Shu'ba, and Ayyub narrated it from Amr bin Dinar and did not say what Ibn Uyaynah said. Thus he said. And Ibn Ajlan also narrated it from Ubaydullah bin Miqsam, from Jabir, like the narration of Ibn Uyaynah from Amr. And this is the strongest aspect, which is that those who narrated Mu'adh praying behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and returning to his people, none of them mentioned the story of prolonging and the complaint to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, except Ibn Uyaynah. And Ibn Ajlan followed him, from Ibn Miqsam, and Ibn Ajlan is not that strong. And those who mentioned Mu'adh's complaint to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, from the trustworthy Hafizs did not mention in it that Mu'adh used to pray with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then return to his people and lead them. And many of our companions did not understand this which Imam Ahmad intended correctly. Third: He said in the narration of Hanbal: This is by way of teaching from Mu'adh to his people. Meaning: He did not lead them except to teach them the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and did not intend the prayer [as an obligation for himself]. Just as Malik bin Al-Huwayrith taught his people the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and did not intend the prayer. But the difference between him and the Hadith of Mu'adh is that Malik bin Al-Huwayrith taught his people the prayer outside of prayer time, so they were all performing voluntary prayer, while Mu'adh used to pray the obligatory prayer, then return to his people who were waiting for him to lead them in it, so they were performing obligatory prayer. Fourth: He said in the narration of Ibrahim Al-Harbi: If it is authentic, it has a precise meaning; the like of it is not permissible today. And it has been said: This meaning which Imam Ahmad referred to is that it was in the beginning of Islam, and those who could recite the Quran were few, so they were granted a concession in that as an expansion for them. When the reciters became many, that [concession] ended. And Abbas Al-Duri narrated from Yahya bin Ma'in that he said regarding the Hadith of Mu'adh that he used to lead his companions, having prayed before that with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Yahya said: I do not see this [as valid]. Abbas said: The meaning of this according to us: That Yahya used to say this was in the beginning of Islam, and those who recite the Quran were few, so I do not see this [now]. This is Yahya's saying according to us. And Ibn Shahin mentioned, from Abu Bakr Al-Najjad, that he heard Ibrahim Al-Harbi being asked about one who prayed an obligatory prayer behind a volunteer. He said: It is not permissible. It was said to him: Then the Hadith of Mu'adh? He said: The Hadith of Mu'adh baffled the first generations.

text:
191 - What has been reported regarding the Imamate of a boy
The Hadith of Amr bin Salama Al-Jarmi, may Allah be pleased with him: They put me forward for Imamate in prayer while I was a boy of six or seven years (1).
Imam Ahmad said: I do not know what this is (2).
foot_note:
1. = Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 4/230: The majority of scholars on this issue are on prohibition, among them Malik, the people of Medina, Al-Thawri, the people of Iraq, Al-Layth, and the people of Egypt. It is the saying of the majority of Tabi'in from the people of Medina and Iraq. But a multitude of scholars have stated permissibility. And the Hadith of Mu'adh has been authenticated that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, knew of it and approved it. And Sufyan bin Uyaynah was corroborated on that. So the stronger view is: The permissibility of the one praying obligatory prayer following the one praying voluntary prayer.
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (4302), he said: Sulayman bin Harb told us, Hammad bin Zaid told us, from Ayyub, from Abu Qilaba, from Amr bin Salama, he said: Abu Qilaba said to me: Why don't you meet him and ask him? He said: So I met him and asked him. He said: We were at a water source where people passed. Riders would pass by us, so we would ask them: What is with the people, what is with the people? Who is this man? They would say: He claims that Allah has sent him, revealed to him, or Allah revealed such and such. I used to memorize that speech, and it was as if it was glued in my chest. The Arabs were delaying their Islam until the Conquest, saying: Leave him and his people, for if he prevails over them, then he is a truthful Prophet. When the event of the people of the Conquest occurred, every tribe hastened to embrace Islam, and my father hastened my tribe to Islam. When he returned, he said: I came to you, by Allah, from the Prophet truly. He said: "Pray such and such prayer at such and such time, and such and such prayer at such and such time. When prayer time comes, let one of you call the Adhan, and let the one who knows the most Quran among you lead you." So they looked, and there was no one who knew more Quran than me; because I used to receive from the riders. So they put me forward in front of them while I was a boy of six or seven years. I had a small cloak on me; when I prostrated, it would shrink up from me. So a woman from the tribe said: Will you not cover the buttocks of your reciter from us? So they bought [cloth] and cut a shirt for me. I never rejoiced over anything as I rejoiced over that shirt.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (294), "Al-Mughni" 2/54, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 1/23.

192 - What has been reported regarding prayer behind every righteous and wicked person
The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: "And prayer is obligatory upon you behind every Muslim, righteous or wicked" (1).
Imam Ahmad denounced it and did not consider it authentic (2). And he said once: We have not heard of this (3).
foot_note:

(1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (2533), he said: Ahmad bin Salih told us, Ibn Wahb told us, Mu'awiyah bin Salih told me, from Al-Ala bin Al-Harith, from Makhul, from Abu Huraira, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Jihad is obligatory upon you with every emir, righteous or wicked, and prayer is obligatory upon you behind every Muslim, righteous or wicked, even if he commits major sins. And prayer is obligatory over every Muslim, righteous or wicked, even if he commits major sins."
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/184.

We should not pray behind a wicked person. And he denounced this speech. As for prayer behind the Fasiq (sinners), Ahmad said regarding one who drinks alcohol: One does not pray behind him. And regarding one who abandoned any of the obligatory duties of Islam, or dealt in Riba (usury): One does not pray behind him, nor behind one whose entire sale is 'Inah - meaning credit sales [with tricks] - nor behind one who lies frequently. He was asked about prayer behind one who backbites people? He said: If everyone who disobeyed Allah could not be prayed behind, when would people ever establish this [prayer]?!

193 - What one says at the opening of prayer
The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: "Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, and blessed is Your Name" (1) The Hadith.
Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not authentic (2).
And he said once: The Hadith of Abu Al-Mutawakkil from Abu Sa'id, as if he did not praise its chain (3). And once: He weakened it (4). And once: He paid no attention to it at all (5). And he said once: We go with the Hadith of Omar (6).

text: 196 - What has been narrated regarding raising the hands at the opening, bowing, and prostration. It contains three Hadiths: First: The Hadith of Ibn Umar, and it has two paths. The First Path: That he used to raise his hands when he said Takbir (1). Imam Ahmad said: Hushaym did not hear from Al-Zuhri the Hadith of Salim, from his father, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he used to raise his hands when he said Takbir (2). The Second Path: That he raises his hands when he enters the prayer, when he wants to bow, when he raises his head from bowing, and when he stands up from the two Rak'ahs he raises his hands likewise parallel to the shoulders (3). Imam Ahmad said: How often this is narrated from Al-Zuhri, and it does not contain this,
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 1/265, he said: Hushaym told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from Ibn Umar that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to raise his hands when he opened [the prayer], when he bowed, and when he raised his head, and he did not raise them beyond his ears.
2. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah bin Ahmad (2203). I say: The text is established, for Al-Bukhari (738) and others narrated it via the path of Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from Ibn Umar who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) open the Takbir in prayer and raise his hands when saying Takbir until he brought them parallel to his shoulders, and when he said Takbir for bowing he did the like of that, and when he said: "Allah hears those who praise Him" he did the like of it.
3. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 3/3, he said: Muhammad bin Abdul-A'la Al-San'ani told us, he said: Al-Mu'tamir told us, he said: I heard Ubaydullah—and he is Ibn Umar—from Ibn Shihab, from Salim, from Ibn Umar, raised [to the Prophet].

text: and he weakened it (1). Second: The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah: He used to raise his hands parallel to his shoulders when opening the prayer, when bowing, and when prostrating (2). From where would Shu'bah get [the chain] Abu Al-Bakhtari, from Abdur-Rahman Al-Yahsubi, from Wa'il (3)?

When he wanted to bow, he took his hands out of the garment, then raised them, then said Takbir and bowed. When he said: "Allah hears those who praise Him," he raised his hands. When he prostrated, he prostrated between his palms.

text: 197 - What has been narrated regarding the positions of raising the hands. It contains four Hadiths: First: The Hadith of Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talhah, from Anas: "Perfect your prayer," and he (peace be upon him) commanded him to raise his hands (1). In a narration: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to raise, he would do that in his prayer. Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith (2). Second: The Hadith of Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): He raised his hands parallel to his shoulders at Takbir, and at his bowing, and when raising his head from bowing (3). Al-Athram said: I asked Abu Abdullah - meaning: Ahmad bin Hanbal - about the Hadith of Shu'bah, from Al-Hakam, from Tawus, who says: from Ibn Umar, from Umar, from the Prophet (peace be upon him). He said: Who says this from Shu'bah? I said: Adam bin Abi Iyas.

text: I said: And thus Yazid is weak? He said: Yes, he is weak (1). 198 - What has been narrated regarding raising the hands at every Takbir. The Hadith of Umair bin Habib (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to raise his hands with every Takbir in the prescribed prayer (2). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not authentic, and Ubayd bin Umair is not known to narrate from his father nor from his grandfather. And he said: I do not know Rifdah bin Quda'ah (3).

3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/328, "Bada'i al-Fawa'id" 3/90, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 2/168.

text: 199 - What has been narrated regarding raising the hands when rising from the first prostration. The Hadith of Malik bin Huwayrith (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) used to, when he entered the prayer, raise his hands, and when he bowed he did the like of that, and when he raised his head from bowing he did the like of that, and when he raised his head from prostration he did the like of all that. Meaning raising his hands (1). Imam Ahmad said, when asked about raising between the two prostrations. He said: No. It was said to him: Then when he wants to go down for prostration? He said: No. So it was said to him: O Abu Abdullah, is it not narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he did it? He said: These [other] Hadiths are stronger and more numerous (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 2/231, he said: Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna told us, he said: Mu'adh bin Hisham told us, he said: My father told me, from Qatadah, from Nasr bin Asim, from Malik bin Huwayrith... the Hadith.
2. "Al-Manhaj Al-Ahmad" 1/115-116, "Bada'i al-Fawa'id" by Ibn al-Qayyim 3/89, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/323, "Tabaqat al-Hanabilah" 1/235. I say: In the two Sahihs from the Hadith of Ibn Umar regarding raising the hands, it states: And he did not raise them between the two prostrations. This is a challenge to the Hadith. Benefit: The Hadith of Malik bin Huwayrith was narrated by Muslim in his "Sahih" (391) without the evidential point: "and when he raised his head from prostration." This suggests it is a Shadh (anomalous) addition. Issue: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/261 (abridged): The majority view is that raising the hands between the two prostrations is not recommended. Ibn Umar also denied it. Sheikh Abu Hamid in his "Ta'liq" stated oddly the consensus that raising is not legislated in other than the three places, and he was corrected by the authenticity of that from Ibn Umar, Ibn Abbas, Tawus, Nafi', and Ata.

text: 200 - What has been narrated regarding the description of lifting. The Hadith of Abu Humaid Al-Sa'idi (may Allah be pleased with him): When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stood for prayer, he stood straight and raised his hands until he brought them parallel to his shoulders (1). Imam Ahmad said: Authentic (2).
foot_note:
1. = It was also narrated by Abdur-Razzaq and others with strong chains. Among the Shafi'is, Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Al-Mundhir, Abu Ali Al-Tabari, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Baghawi held this view, and Ibn Khuwayz narrated it from Malik, but it is Shadh (anomalous). Note: Ibn al-Qayyim quoted in "Bada'i al-Fawa'id" 3/89-95 saying: Ahmad's statements differed regarding raising hands in other than the three places. The majority of narrations from him are that he did not see raising when going down to prostration, nor between the two prostrations, nor when rising from the two Rak'ahs, nor in other than the three places in the Hadith of Ibn Umar. Al-Athram narrated from him, when asked about raising hands, he said: In every lowering and raising. Al-Athram said: And I saw Abu Abdullah raising his hands in prayer in every lowering and raising. Ja'far bin Muhammad narrated from him, when asked about raising hands, he said: He raises his hands in every place except between the two prostrations. Al-Mawazi narrated from him: I do not like him to raise his hands between the two prostrations, but if he does so, it is permissible.
1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (304), he said: Muhammad bin Bashar and Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna told us, they said: Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan told us, Abdul-Hamid bin Ja'far told us, Muhammad bin Amr bin Ata told us, from Abu Humaid Al-Sa'idi: He said - and I heard him while he was among ten of the companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him), one of whom was Abu Qatadah bin Rib'i - he said: I am the most knowledgeable among you of the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). They said: You were not the one among us with the earliest companionship with him, nor the one who came to him most. He said: Indeed. They said: Then present it. So he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to, when he stood for prayer, stand straight and raise his hands until he brought them parallel to his shoulders, and when he wanted to bow he raised his hands until he brought them parallel to his shoulders then said: "Allahu Akbar" and bowed... And in it: Until when he stood up from the two prostrations he said Takbir and raised his hands until he brought them parallel to his shoulders.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/311.

text: 201 - What has been narrated regarding spreading the fingers at Takbir. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to spread his fingers when he said Takbir for prayer (1). Ahmad was asked about this Hadith: Is it not an error? Is not the Hadith the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah regarding raising his hands (2) outstretched? He said: I do not know, it is an error, but people narrate it like this. Meaning: raising his hands outstretched (3). And he said once: Weak, and Ibn Sam'an is nothing (4).

text: 202 - What has been narrated regarding placing the hands on the chest. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Wa'il bin Hujr (may Allah be pleased with him): I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and he placed his right hand over his left hand on his chest (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abdullah bin Al-Walid narrated this Hadith from Sufyan, and did not mention that. And Shu'bah and Abdul-Wahid narrated it, and they did not mention a contradiction to Sufyan (2). The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): Placing the right over the left in prayer is at the place of sacrifice (upper chest/neck base) (3). Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic (4), and the authentic one is the Hadith of Ali (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah 1/243, he said: Abu Musa told us, Mu'ammal told us, Sufyan told us from Asim bin Kulayb, from his father, from Wa'il... the Hadith.

And from him Abu Talib [narrated]: I asked Ahmad where he places his hand when he is praying? He said: On the navel or below, and all of that is wide [permissible] to him if he places above the navel or on it or below it. In the narration of Al-Muzani he said: A little below the navel. And he dislikes placing them on the chest, and that is due to what was narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he forbade "Al-Takfir", which is placing the hand on the chest.

5. "Bada'i al-Fawa'id" 3/91.

text: 203 - What has been narrated regarding not completing the Takbir. The Hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Abza (may Allah be pleased with him) that he prayed with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and he was not completing the Takbir (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is a Munkar Hadith; I do not consider it Mahfuz (preserved) (2).

text: 204 - What has been narrated regarding 'There is no prayer except with the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatiha)'. The Hadith of Ubadah bin Al-Samit (may Allah be pleased with him): "Do not do [so] except with the Opening of the Book; for there is no prayer for the one who did not recite with it" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Weak (2). He said once: No one narrated it except Ibn Ishaq (3). The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whichever prayer in which the Opening of the Book is not recited is deficient (khidaj)" (4). Imam Ahmad said: I hope that both Hadiths are authentic - meaning: the Hadith of Malik, from Al-Ala' bin Abdur-Rahman, from Abu Al-Sa'ib, from Abu Hurayrah, and [the one of] whoever said: from Al-Ala', from his father, from Abu Hurayrah (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawud (823), he said: Abdullah bin Muhammad Al-Nufayli told us, Muhammad bin Salamah told us, from Muhammad bin Ishaq, from Makhul, from Mahmoud bin Al-Rabi', from Ubadah bin Al-Samit who said: We were behind the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in the Fajr prayer, and he recited (peace be upon him) and the recitation became heavy for him. When he finished he said: "Perhaps you recite behind your Imam." We said: Yes, this [is so] O Messenger of Allah. He said: "Do not do [so] except with the Opening of the Book; for there is no prayer for the one who did not recite with it."
2. "Al-Fatawa" by Ibn Taymiyyah 23/286, 313.
3. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/602, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 1/379, with the wording: No one raised it [to the Prophet] except Ibn Ishaq. I say: The second part has an authentic witness, for Al-Bukhari (756) and Muslim (394) both narrated it from the path of Al-Zuhri, from Mahmoud bin Al-Rabi', from Ubadah bin Al-Samit that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "There is no prayer for the one who did not recite with the Opening of the Book."
4. Narrated by Ahmad 2/241, he said: Sufyan told us, Al-Ala' bin Abdur-Rahman informed me, from his father from Abu Hurayrah with it. And he also narrated it 2/478 via Shu'bah, from Al-Ala' with it. And Muslim narrated it (395/38) via Sufyan bin Uyainah, from Al-Ala', with it, and (395/41) via Abu Uwais who said: Al-Ala' informed me, saying: I heard from my father and from Abu Al-Sa'ib, both saying: Abu Hurayrah said, and he mentioned it.
5. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1986).

text: 205 - What has been narrated regarding omitting the recitation of the Basmalah aloud. There are three paths from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): First: From Qatadah from him: The Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman used to open the recitation with {Al-Hamdu lillahi Rabbi al-Alamin} (1). Abdullah bin Ahmad said: I narrated this Hadith to my father. So he said: Ismail bin Ulayyah informed us, from Sa'id (2) and it is not from Ayyub, and he denied it (3). Second: From Qatadah, Thabit, and Humaid from him that the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar used to open the recitation with {Al-Hamdu lillahi Rabbi al-Alamin} (4). Imam Ahmad said: Humaid (5) did not raise it [to the Prophet] (6). Third: From Abu Qilabah from him, similar to it (7).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 2/133, he said: Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Zuhri informed us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Ayyub, from Qatadah, from Anas, raised [to the Prophet].
2. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 3/190, he said: Ismail told us, Sa'id bin Yazid said: Qatadah informed us, from Anas, raised [to the Prophet].
3. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (5740), "Tarikh Baghdad" 13/81, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 28/544, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 5/543.
4. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 3/168, he said: Abu Kamil told us, Hammad informed us, he said: Qatadah, Thabit, and Humaid informed us, from Anas bin Malik, raised [to the Prophet].
5. Narrated by Malik in "Al-Muwatta" 1/90 from Humaid, from Anas that he said: I stood behind Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman, and all of them would not recite: Bismillah Al-Rahman Al-Rahim when they opened the prayer.
6. "Fath Al-Bari" 4/353.
7. Narrated by Ibn Hibban 5/105, he said: Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Abi Awn informed us, he said: Harun bin Abdullah Al-Hammal told us, Yahya bin Adam told us, from Sufyan, from Khalid, from Abu Qilabah, from Anas... the Hadith.
