text: Imam Ahmad said: There is a Wahm (error) in it; it is only Abu Na'amah (1). Meaning: from Anas. 206 - What has been narrated regarding the one who saw reciting Basmalah aloud. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to open his prayer with {Al-Hamdu lillahi Rabbi al-Alamin} (2). Imam Ahmad said: Ismail bin Hammad is okay [has no harm in him], and I do not know Abu Khalid. Meaning: that he is not Al-Walibi (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/373. I say: The text is established, for Al-Bukhari (743) narrated it from the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him), and in it is that the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) used to open the prayer with {Al-Hamdu lillahi Rabbi al-Alamin}.
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (245), he said: Ahmad bin Abdah Al-Dabbi told us, Al-Mu'tamir bin Sulayman told us, he said: Ismail bin Hammad told me, from Abu Khalid, from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to... the Hadith.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/364. Benefit: Ibn Rajab, may Allah have mercy on him, weakened in "Al-Fath" all the Hadiths reported regarding reciting the Basmalah aloud, and that is the truth, and Allah knows best. Issue: Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab said in 4/367: The majority of scholars hold the view of not reciting the Basmalah aloud. Among the companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) are Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, Ali, and others, and those after them from the Tabi'in. And Sufyan, Ibn Al-Mubarak, Ahmad, and Ishaq hold this view; they said: He says it in himself [silently]. Al-Awza'i said: The Imam conceals it. Ibn Shahin narrated it from the generality of the People of the Sunnah and said: And they are the vast majority. Al-Nakha'i said: It is an innovation.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 207 - What has been narrated regarding omitting recitation behind the Imam in what he recites aloud. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "I say, 'Why am I being disputed with the Quran?'" He said: So the people stopped reciting in what the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) recited aloud (1). Imam Ahmad said: What we see is that his saying: 'So the people stopped reciting...' is from the speech of Al-Zuhri (2). And he said once when asked: Did Ibn Akimah narrate other than this Hadith? He said: He narrates from a son of his. (3) The Second: The Hadith of Ubadah bin Al-Samit (may Allah be pleased with him): "When you are behind me do not recite except with the Opening of the Book, for there is no prayer for the one who did not recite with it" (4). Imam Ahmad said: Weak (5).
foot_note:
1. = And it was narrated from a group that he has the choice between reciting aloud and silently, and reciting aloud is not disliked even if reciting silently is better; this was narrated from Ibn Abi Layla and Ishaq, and a group of the Hadith scholars preferred it. And a group said: He recites it aloud, and it is the Sunnah, and it is the view of Al-Shafi'i and his companions.
1. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 2/140, he said: Qutaibah informed us from Malik, from Ibn Shihab, from Ibn Akimah Al-Laythi, from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) finished a prayer in which he recited aloud, so he said: "Did any of you recite with me just now?" A man said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: "I say, 'Why am I being disputed with the Quran?'" He said: So the people stopped reciting in what the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) recited aloud.
2. "Masa'il Salih" (687).
3. "Su'alat Abi Dawud" (201).
4. Narrated by Ahmad 5/326, he said: Yazid told us, he said: Muhammad bin Ishaq informed us, from Makhul, from Mahmoud bin Al-Rabi', from Ubadah bin Al-Samit... the Hadith.
5. "Al-Fatawa" by Ibn Taymiyyah 23/286.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of the Sciences of Imam Ahmad - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 208 - What has been narrated regarding the Imam's recitation [sufficing] for the followers. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): "The recitation of the Imam is sufficient for you, whether he recited silently or aloud" (1). Imam Ahmad said: A Munkar Hadith (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Daraqutni in his "Sunan" 1/331, he said: Muhammad bin Makhlad told us, Ali bin Zakariya Al-Tammar told us, Abu Musa Al-Ansari told us, Asim bin Abdul-Aziz told us, from Abu Suhail, from Awn, from Ibn Abbas, from the Prophet (peace be upon him)... the Hadith.
2. "Sunan Al-Daraqutni" 1/333, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 8/12, "Mukhtasar Khilafiyat Al-Bayhaqi" 1/131, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 1/377. Issue: The scholars differed regarding recitation behind the Imam. The Hanafis went to the view of no recitation in silent or loud prayers. The Hanbalis and Malikis went to the view that the follower recites the Fatiha and a Surah in the silent prayer, and does not recite in the loud prayer. And he recites the Fatiha only in the loud prayer according to the Shafi'is. The issue contains many details; specific works have been dedicated to it, and it should be looked for in the relevant sections of Fiqh books.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
209 - What has been reported regarding 'If he recites, then listen attentively'
The Hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him: "The Imam is only appointed to be followed." And in it: "If he recites, then listen attentively" (1).
Al-Athram said: I said to Ahmad bin Hanbal: Who says from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, via a Sahih path: "If he recites, then listen attentively"? He said: The Hadith of Ibn Ajlan which Abu Khalid (2) narrates. And the Hadith which Jarir narrated from Al-Taimi, and they claimed that Al-Mu'tamir narrated it. I said: Yes, Al-Mu'tamir narrated it. He said: So what do you want?
Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: Ahmad has authenticated both Hadiths (3).
Al-Athram said: None of the Hafiz companions of Qatada mentioned this phrase. Then Al-Athram said: I mentioned that to Imam Ahmad, so he said: This is Idtirab (inconsistency) (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (404), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Abu Usamah told us, Sa'id bin Abi Aruba told us, (H). And Abu Ghassan Al-Masma'i told us, Mu'adh bin Hisham told us, my father told us. And Ishaq bin Ibrahim told us, Jarir informed us, from Sulayman Al-Taimi. All of these, from Qatada, from Yunus bin Jubayr, from Hattan bin Abdullah Al-Raqashi, he said: I prayed with Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari a prayer... And in it: "When you pray, straighten your rows, then let one of you lead you"... And in it: "If he recites, then listen attentively."
2. Narrated by Abu Dawood (604), he said: Muhammad bin Adam Al-Massisi told us, Abu Khalid told us, from Ibn Ajlan, from Zaid bin Aslam, from Abu Salih, from Abu Huraira, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, he said: "The Imam is only appointed to be followed," and he added: "And if he recites, then listen attentively."
3. "Al-Tamhid" by Ibn Abd Al-Barr 11/34 "Fatawa Ibn Taymiyyah" 22/340.
4. "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab 341. I say: But most Imams consider this addition defected =

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
210 - What has been reported regarding the description of the recitation of the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatihah)
The Hadith of Umm Salama, may Allah be pleased with her: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to cut his recitation [into verses], saying {Al-hamdu lillahi rabbil-alamin}, then he would stop, {Ar-rahmanir-rahim}, then he would stop. And he used to recite it {Maliki yawmid-din} (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The recitation of these verses in this manner is only Ibn Jurayj's recounting of the Hadith of Umm Salama. And Ibn Jurayj is the one who recited (Malik) [King], and that is not in the Hadith of Umm Salama (2).
Imam Ahmad said: The old recitation is {Maliki yawmid-din} [Owner of the Day of Judgment] (3).
foot_note:
1. = "If he recites, then listen attentively," among them Abu Dawood, may Allah have mercy on him, who said regarding the Hadith of Abu Musa: It is not preserved (Mahfuz). Al-Daraqutni also found it defective in "Al-Ilzamat wa Al-Tatabbu'", as well as Abu Al-Fadl bin Umar Al-Shahid, Abu Ali Al-Naysaburi, Al-Bukhari, and Ibn Khuzayma. Al-Bayhaqi said: The consensus of these Hafizs on weakening it takes precedence over Muslim's authentication and also over the Hadith of Abu Huraira. Abu Dawood said: It is not preserved; the delusion is from Abu Khalid according to us. Al-Bukhari said in "Al-Qira'ah Khalfa Al-Imam": This is not known from the authentic Hadith of Abu Khalid. Ibn Khuzayma found it defective, and Abu Hatim said in "Al-Ilal": This addition is from the confusions of Ibn Ajlan. Al-Hafiz authenticated this addition in "Al-Nukat Al-Ziraf", and Ibn Hazm in "Al-Muhalla".
1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (2927), he said: Ali bin Hajar told us, Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Umawi informed us, from Ibn Jurayj, from Ibn Abi Mulaykah, from Umm Salama, she said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to cut his recitation, saying... The Hadith.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/359.
3. Abu Dawood (4001), "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1840).

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
211 - What has been reported regarding recitation with Madd (elongation)
The Hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him: He used to elongate it greatly (1).
Imam Ahmad denounced it from Jarir bin Hazim (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (5045), he said: Muslim bin Ibrahim told us, Jarir bin Hazim Al-Azdi told us, Qatada told us, he said: I asked Anas bin Malik about the recitation of the Prophet, so he said: He used to elongate it greatly.
2. "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab p. 339. I say: Ibn Rajab said in "Fath Al-Bari" 4/358: Ibn Ma'in was asked about the Hadith of Jarir Ibn Hazim, so he said: It is nothing. I say: Hammam followed Jarir bin Hazim in Al-Bukhari number (5046), he said: Amr bin Asim told us, Hammam told us, from Qatada, he said: Anas was asked how the recitation of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was? He said: It was with elongation, then he recited {Bismillahir-Rahmanir-Rahim} elongating {Bismillah}, elongating {Ar-Rahman}, and elongating {Ar-Rahim}. Ibn Abi Khaythama also found a defect in this Hadith in his "Ilal" and said: It is from Qatada as Mursal. Ibn Rajab affirmed its mention in "Fath Al-Bari" 4/358. Benefit: Regarding the singularity of Amr Ibn Asim from Hammam mentioned by him, there is criticism about it, see "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab 253.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
212 - What one says when raising his head from bowing (Ruku')
The Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding the supplication when raising his head from bowing. Imam Ahmad preferred the narration of Shu'ba (1). And he said: I think Al-A'mash (2) erred in it. Ibn Rajab said (3): Meaning: in mentioning that he used to say it after raising his head from bowing.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (476), he said: Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna and Ibn Bashar told us, they said: Muhammad bin Ja'far told us, Shu'ba told us, from Ubayd bin Al-Hasan, he said: I heard Abdullah bin Abi Awfa say: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to supplicate with this supplication: "O Allah, out Lord, to You is praise, filling the heavens, filling the earth, and filling whatever else You will after that."
2. Narrated by Muslim (476), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Abu Mu'awiyah and Waki' told us, from Al-A'mash, from Ubayd bin Al-Hasan, from Ibn Abi Awfa, he said: When he, peace and blessings be upon him, raised his back from bowing, he would say: "Allah listens to those who praise Him. O Allah, our Lord, to You is praise, filling the heavens, filling the earth, and filling whatever else You will after that."
3. Ibn Rajab in "Fath Al-Bari" 5/78. I say: The text of this Hadith is established in Al-Bukhari in summarized form (795) from the path of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah listens to those who praise Him," he would say: "O Allah, our Lord, and to You is praise."

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
213 - What has been reported regarding Tasbih in bowing and prostration
The Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: "If one of you bows and says in his bowing: 'Glory be to my Lord the Great' three times, his bowing is complete" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Abu Al-Hasan who narrated it from Abdullah bin Mas'ud did not meet Abdullah (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (261), he said: Ali bin Hajar told us, Isa bin Yunus informed us, from Ibn Abi Dhi'b, from Ishaq bin Yazid Al-Hudhali, from Awn bin Abdullah bin Utbah, from Ibn Mas'ud, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If one of you bows and says in his bowing: 'Glory be to my Lord the Great' three times, his bowing is complete, and that is the minimum. And if he prostrates and says in his prostration: 'Glory be to my Lord the Most High' three times, his prostration is complete, and that is the minimum." Al-Tirmidhi said: The practice is according to this among the people of knowledge; they recommend that a man does not decrease the bowing and prostration from three Tasbihs.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/60 "Jami' Al-Tahsil" 308.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
214 - What has been reported regarding reciting the Quran in bowing and prostration
The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Behold, I have been forbidden from reciting the Quran while bowing or prostrating" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Its chain is not that [strong] (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (479), he said: Sa'id bin Mansur, Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah, and Zuhair Ibn Harb told us, they said: Sufyan bin Uyaynah told us, Sulayman bin Suhaym informed me, from Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Ma'bad, from his father, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, uncovered the curtain while the people were in rows behind Abu Bakr, so he said: "O people, nothing remains of the glad tidings of prophethood except a good dream that a Muslim sees, or is seen for him. Behold, I have been forbidden from reciting the Quran while bowing or prostrating. So as for the bowing, glorify the Lord, Mighty and Majestic, in it. And as for the prostration, strive in supplication, for it is deserving that you be answered."
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/69. I say: It has a corroboration in "Sahih Muslim" from the Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib regarding the prohibition of reciting in bowing and prostration. This Hadith has great disagreement, and Al-Daraqutni quoted the disagreement in "Al-Ilal" 3/105, and did not prefer anything from it. Ibn Rajab said in "Fath Al-Bari" 5/69: Al-Bukhari wrote a chapter on this but did not extract anything in it, and it contains Hadiths that are not according to his condition. It appears that Al-Bukhari left the Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib because he saw the disagreement in it as impactful. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 5/69: Most scholars hold the dislike of reciting in bowing and prostration, and some of them narrated it as a consensus. Is the dislike for prohibition or discouragement? There is disagreement. Ibn Abd Al-Barr narrated a consensus on impermissibility. The school of Al-Shafi'i and most of our companions is: It is disliked. A group permitted reciting in bowing and prostration, among them Abu Al-Darda, Sulayman bin Rabi'ah, and Al-Mughira.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
215 - What has been reported regarding the virtue of prostration and encouragement for it
The Hadith of Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him: "There is no servant who prostrates a prostration to Allah except that Allah raises him by it a degree and removes from him by it a sin" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Two Hadiths have been narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding this, and he did not judge anything regarding it (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (488), he said: Zuhair bin Harb told me, Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, he said: I heard Al-Awza'i say: Al-Walid bin Hisham Al-Mu'ayti told me: Ma'dan bin Abi Talha Al-Ya'mari told me, he said: I met Thawban, the Mawla of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so I said: Tell me of a deed I can do by which Allah will enter me into Paradise. Or he said: I said: Of the most beloved deeds to Allah. He remained silent. Then I asked him again, and he remained silent. Then I asked him the third time, so he said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about that, and he said: "You must perform prostration to Allah frequently, for you do not prostrate a prostration to Allah except that Allah raises you by it a degree and removes from you by it a sin." Ma'dan said: Then I met Abu Al-Darda and asked him, and he told me the like of what Thawban told me.
2. "Sunan Al-Tirmidhi" 2/233.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
216 - What has been reported regarding keeping limbs apart in prostration
The Hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him: When he prostrated, he kept [his arms] apart; until the whiteness of his armpits could be seen (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Ma'mar, from Mansur, from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd, from Jabir, in a Marfu' form is a mistake. The correct one is: Sufyan, from Mansur, from Ibrahim as Mursal (2).
Abu Zur'ah said to him: O Abu Abdullah, the Hadith is authentic. So he looked at him. Abu Zur'ah said: Abu Abdullah Al-Bukhari Muhammad bin Ismail told us, Radwan Al-Bukhari told us, he said: Fudayl bin Iyad told us, from Mansur, from Salim, from Jabir that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to keep his sides apart when he prostrated. And Ibrahim bin Musa told us, Hisham bin Yusuf Al-San'ani told us, Ma'mar informed us, from Mansur, from Salim, from Jabir that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to keep his sides apart when he prostrated. Ahmad said: Give me the pen. So he wrote 'Sahh, Sahh, Sahh' (Correct, Correct, Correct) three times (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Imam Ahmad 3/294-295, he said: Abdul-Razzaq told us, Ma'mar informed us, from Mansur, from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd, from Jabir bin Abdullah, in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab 299. I say: And the text is established and authentic in the two Sahihs, for Al-Bukhari (807) and Muslim (495) narrated it via the path of Yahya bin Bukayr, he said: Bakr bin Mudar told me, from Ja'far, from Ibn Hurmuz, from Abdullah bin Malik bin Buhayna that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to open his arms when he prayed until the whiteness of his armpits appeared.
3. "Tarikh Baghdad" 10/326. Benefit: Ibn Ma'in also found a defect in this Hadith due to Irsaal (disconnection), and Ma'mar is not strong regarding Mansur.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
217 - What has been reported regarding the obligation of prostrating on the nose and forehead
The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "There is no prayer for the one whose nose does not touch the ground as the forehead touches" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It is Mursal, I fear it is not established (2). And he said once: I do not dare to judge by it. Ishaq said: As he said; due to its being Mursal (3). And once: Ahmad leaned towards it being Mursal (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Daraqutni 1/348, he said: Abdullah bin Sulayman told us, Al-Jarrah bin Makhlad told us, Abu Qutaybah told us, Sufyan Al-Thawri told us, Asim Al-Ahwal told us, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said while he saw a man praying whose nose did not touch the ground... The Hadith.
2. "Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi" 188.
3. "Masa'il Al-Kawsaj" (218).
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 15/118. I say: What suffices instead of this Hadith is what is in the two Sahihs and others; in Al-Bukhari (812) he said: Hadith of Mu'alla bin Asad, he said: Wuhayb told us, from Abdullah bin Tawus, from his father, from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I have been ordered to prostrate on seven bones: on the forehead - and he pointed with his hand to his nose - and the hands, and the knees, and the ends of the feet, and not to tuck up the clothes and hair." I say: And in "Sunan Al-Darimi" (1319): 'And he pointed with his hand to his nose' is from the action of Ibn Tawus. Issue: Al-Hafiz said in Al-Fath 2/346: Ibn Al-Mundhir quoted the consensus of the Companions that prostrating on the nose alone does not suffice. The majority held that it suffices on the forehead alone. From Al-Awza'i, Ahmad, Ishaq, Ibn Habib from the Malikis, and others: It is obligatory to combine them. It is also the saying of Al-Shafi'i.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
218 - What has been reported regarding praying in water and mud
The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed in water and mud, and I saw the trace of mud on his forehead and nose in the water and mud (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Isa erred in it. Ma'mar only narrated it from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abu Salama, from Abu Sa'id - a long story - and it is not from Al-Zuhri, it is only from Yahya bin Abi Kathir (2).

219 - What has been reported regarding supplication between the two prostrations
Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Hudhayfah (3) is more authentic (4) than the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (1167), he said: Abd bin Humayd told us, Abdul-Razzaq informed us, Ma'mar informed us. And Abdullah bin Abdul-Rahman Al-Darimi told us, Abu Al-Mughira informed us, Al-Awza'i told us, both of them from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abu Salama, from Abu Sa'id, in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (5532).
3. Narrated by Ibn Majah (897), he said: Ali bin Muhammad told us, Hafs bin Ghiyath told us, Al-Ala bin Al-Musayyib told us, from Amr bin Murrah, from Talha bin Yazid, from Hudhayfah. And Ali Ibn Muhammad told us, Hafs bin Ghiyath told us, from Al-A'mash, from Sa'd bin Ubaydah, from Al-Mustawrid Ibn Al-Ahnaf, from Silah bin Zufar, from Hudhayfah that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say between the two prostrations: "My Lord forgive me, my Lord forgive me."
4. Ibn Rajab in "Fath Al-Bari" 5/133.
5. Narrated by Ibn Majah (898), he said: Abu Kurayb Muhammad bin Al-Ala told us, Ismail bin Subaih told us, from Kamil Abu Al-Ala, he said: I heard Habib bin Abi Thabit narrating from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say between the two prostrations in the night prayer: "My Lord forgive me, have mercy on me, restore me, provide for me, and raise me." I say: 'More authentic' does not mean it is authentic according to Imam Ahmad, and Allah knows best.

book_title: The Comprehensive Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Defects of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
220 - What has been reported regarding the Sitting of Rest (Jalsat al-Istirahah)
The Hadith of Malik bin Al-Huwayrith, may Allah be pleased with him: That he saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, praying, and when he was in an odd-numbered Rak'ah of his prayer, he did not rise until he sat up straight (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Authentic (Sahih), its chain is authentic. And he said: This Hadith has no second (2). Meaning: This sitting was not narrated in other than this (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (823), he said: Muhammad bin Al-Sabah told us, Hushaym told us, Khalid informed us, from Abu Qilaba, Malik bin Al-Huwayrith Al-Laythi informed us that he saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... The Hadith.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/138. I say: This addition - i.e., the sitting of rest - was narrated in the Hadith of the one who prayed badly, but there was disagreement regarding it concerning Ubaydullah Al-Umari. Al-Qattan and Abu Usamah narrated it without it, and Ibn Numair narrated it from him confirming it. The most likely view - and Allah knows best - is that it is not established, for Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/326: Al-Bukhari indicated that this phrase is a delusion, for he said after the Hadith: Abu Usamah said at the end: Until you stand up straight. And it can be interpreted, if it is preserved, as sitting for Tashahhud.
3. Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 5/140-141: This phrase has been disputed in the Hadith of Abu Huraira. Some narrators mentioned that he ordered him to sit after the two prostrations, and some mentioned that he ordered him to stand after them, and this is what is more likely. For this Hadith did not mention anyone in it that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, taught him anything from the agreed-upon Sunan of prayer, so how could he have ordered him with this sitting? This is very remote indeed. He said: Then I found that Al-Bayhaqi mentioned this, and mentioned that there was disagreement regarding Abu Usamah about mentioning this second sitting after the two prostrations. He said: And the correct version from him is that he said after mentioning the two prostrations: Then rise until you stand up straight. Al-Bayhaqi said: And Al-Bukhari narrated it in his "Sahih" from Ishaq bin Mansur from Abu Usamah and mentioned the narration of Ibn Numair and did not mention Al-Bukhari's extraction of it, and Yahya bin Sa'id did not mention in his narration the second prostration nor what followed it of sitting or standing. He said: And standing is more similar to what the report was driven for, which is counting the pillars without the Sunan, and Allah knows best. Ibn Rajab said: This indicates that the mention of the second sitting is not preserved from Yahya.

text: He said once: Most Hadiths do not mention anything of that (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/142-143. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 5/143: Scholars differed regarding its desirability in prayer. A group said: It is desirable, which is the saying of Hammad bin Zaid and Al-Shafi'i in his most famous opinion, and Ahmad in a narration from him. Al-Khallal mentioned: That his opinion settled on it and Al-Khallal and his companion Abu Bakr bin Ja'far chose it. The majority said: It is not desirable; rather, what is desirable is that when he raises his head from the second prostration, he should rise standing. Ahmad attributed this to Omar, Ali, and Ibn Mas'ud, and Ibn Al-Mundhir mentioned it from Ibn Abbas. Al-Tirmidhi said: The practice is according to this among the people of knowledge. Among those who said this are: Ubadah bin Nasi, Abu Al-Zinad, Al-Nakha'i, Al-Thawri, Abu Hanifa, Al-Shafi'i in one of his two opinions, and Ahmad in the well-known view of his school among the generality of his companions. They interpreted the Hadith of Malik bin Al-Huwayrith that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to sit occasionally when he became old and his body became heavy, for the Arab delegations only came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, at the end of his life. What testifies to this is that the senior Companions who were close to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not use to do that in their prayers, which indicates that they knew that this was not from the Sunan of prayer in general.

text:
221 - What has been reported regarding raising the hands when rising from the two Rak'ahs
It contains two Hadiths:
First: The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: When he entered prayer he would say Takbir and raise his hands, and when he bowed he would raise his hands, and when he said: 'Allah hears those who praise Him' he would raise his hands, and when he rose from the two Rak'ahs he would raise his hands (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Ubaydullah narrated it from Nafi', from Ibn Omar, and it reached me that Abdul-A'la elevated it. And he said once: His elevating it is authentic (2). And he said once when asked if a man rises from the two Rak'ahs should he raise his hands? He said: If he does it, how close it is regarding it from Ibn Omar, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And Abu Humaid, and authentic Hadiths. But Al-Zuhri said (3) in his Hadith: And he did not do it in anything of his prayer, and I do not do it (4). And this wording is not known in the Hadith of Al-Zuhri.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (739), he said: Ayyash told us; Abdul-A'la told us, he said: Ubaydullah told us, from Nafi' that Ibn Omar... and in it: And Ibn Omar attributed that to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/315.
3. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (738) from the path of Al-Zuhri, from Nafi', from Ibn Omar, he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: He opened with Takbir in prayer and raised his hands when he said Takbir until he made them parallel to his shoulders, and when he said Takbir for Ruku' he did the like of that, and when he said: "Allah hears those who praise Him" he did the like of that and said: "Our Lord and to You is praise." And he does not do that when he prostrates nor when he rises from prostration. And in it: And Ibn Omar attributed that to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.
4. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (236), "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/321, "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/553.

text:
And he said once when asked about raising hands when rising from the two [Rak'ahs]. He said: An authentic, practiced Sunnah. Ali bin Abi Talib and Abu Humaid have narrated similar to it among ten of the Companions, and I practice it (1).
Second: The Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and in it: ...when he rose from the two prostrations [i.e., Rak'ahs], he raised his hands (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/322. Ibn Rajab said after mentioning this narration: This is a very strange narration from Ahmad, our companions do not know it, and the men of its chain are all famous Hafizs. I say: Abu Dawood said in "Al-Sunan" (741): The correct is the saying of Ibn Omar, and it is not Marfu'. Al-Daraqutni said, quoted from "Al-Fath" by Ibn Rajab 4/316: The most likely correct from Ubaydullah is what Abdul-A'la said. Then he said: And the Mawquf from Nafi' is more authentic. Ibn Rajab said 4/318: The narration of Nafi' from Ibn Omar. The majority hold that its being Mawquf is more authentic than its being Marfu', and all of these did not mention in their narration rising from the two Rak'ahs. Al-Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi authenticated its being Marfu'. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" 9/212: This is one of the four Hadiths in which Salim and Nafi' differed; Salim elevated it and Nafi' stopped it, and the saying is the saying of Salim, and people did not turn to Nafi'. Al-Nasa'i and Al-Daraqutni said: The three Mawquf Hadiths of Nafi' are closer to correctness. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/260: Al-Isma'ili narrated from some of his sheikhs that he indicated that Abdul-A'la erred in elevating it. Al-Isma'ili said: And Abdullah bin Idris, Abdul-Wahhab Al-Thaqafi, and Al-Mu'tamir opposed him - meaning from Ubaydullah - so they narrated it as Mawquf from Ibn Omar.
2. Narrated by Abu Dawood (744), he said: Al-Hasan bin Ali told us, Sulayman bin Dawood Al-Hashimi told us, Abdul-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad told us, from Musa bin Uqbah, from Abdullah bin Al-Fadl bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Abdul-Muttalib, from Abdul-Rahman Al-A'raj, from Ubaydullah bin Abi Rafi', =

Imam Ahmad said: Authentic (Sahih) (1).

222 - What has been reported regarding Tawarruk (sitting on left hip) in prayer
The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade Iq'a (sitting on heels) and Tawarruk in prayer (2).
Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal said: My father abandoned this Hadith (3).
foot_note:
1. = from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that when he stood for the obligatory prayer, he said Takbir and raised his hands parallel to his shoulders, and he does the like of that when he finishes his recitation and wants to bow, and he does it when he rises from bowing, and he does not raise his hand in anything of his prayer while sitting, and when he rises from the two prostrations [Rak'ahs] he raises his hands likewise and says Takbir.
1. "Fath Al-Bari" 4/320.
2. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 3/233, he said: Yahya bin Ishaq told us, he said Hammad Ibn Salama informed me, from Qatada, from Anas bin Malik in a Marfu' form with it.
3. "Musnad Ahmad" 3/233. I say: And the text has an authentic corroboration in Al-Bukhari number (828) from the path of Muhammad bin Amr Ibn Ata: that he was sitting with a group of the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so we mentioned the prayer of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Abu Humaid Al-Sa'idi said: I am the one among you who best preserves the prayer of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... And in it: And when he sat in the last Rak'ah, he put forward his left foot and set up the other and sat on his buttocks.

text:
223 - What has been reported regarding the description of Tashahhud
It contains two Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Attahiyatu lillah wa-salawatu tayyibat, As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: I do not know it, and he denounced it (2).
The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: We used to say in prayer before the Tashahhud was enjoined: Peace be upon Allah, peace be upon Gabriel and Michael (3).
Imam Ahmad said: Sufyan did not hear the Hadith of Abdullah regarding Tashahhud (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (971), he said: Nasr bin Ali told us, Abu Shu'ba told me, from Abu Bishr, I heard Mujahid narrating from Ibn Omar, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding the Tashahhud: "Attahiyatu lillah was-salawatu tayyibat As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh": Ibn Omar said: I added in it 'wa barakatuh': "As-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-salihin, ashhadu an la ilaha illallah" Ibn Omar said: I added in it 'wahdahu la sharika lah' "wa ashhadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh".
2. "Al-Kamil" by Ibn Adi 2/151, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 1/267, "Mizan Al-I'tidal" 1/402, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 5/908.
3. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 2/40, he said: Sa'id bin Abdul-Rahman Abu Ubaydullah Al-Makhzumi informed us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Al-A'mash and Mansur, from Shaqiq bin Salama, from Ibn Mas'ud, he said: We used to say in prayer before the Tashahhud was enjoined: Peace be upon Allah, peace be upon Gabriel and Michael. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Do not say thus, for Allah, Mighty and Majestic, is Peace. But say: Attahiyatu lillah was-salawatu wat-tayyibat, As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh, As-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-salihin, ashhadu an la ilaha illallah wa ashhadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh."
4. Al-Ilal narration of Abdullah (4610).

text:
224 - What has been reported regarding a man passing wind during Tashahhud
The Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both: "If a man passes wind while sitting at the end of his prayer before he says Taslim, his prayer is valid" (1).
Imam Ahmad rejected it and did not authenticate it (2). And he said once: Zuhair narrates nothing from Abdul-Rahman bin Ziyad (3).
foot_note:
1. = I say: And the text is established and authentic, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (831) from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: We used to say when we prayed behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: Peace be upon Gabriel and Michael, peace be upon so-and-so and so-and-so. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, turned to us and said: "Verily Allah is Peace. When one of you prays, let him say: Attahiyatu lillah was-salawatu wat-tayyibat, As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh, As-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-salihin, for if you say it, it reaches every righteous servant of Allah in the heavens and the earth, ashhadu an la ilaha illallah, wa ashhadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh."
1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (408), he said: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Musa nicknamed Mardawayh told us, he said: Ibn Al-Mubarak informed us, Abdul-Rahman bin Ziyad bin An'am informed us that Abdul-Rahman bin Rafi' and Bakr bin Sawada informed him, from Abdullah bin Amr, he said... in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/218, "Mukhtasar Khilafiyyat Al-Bayhaqi" 2/230, "Tabaqat Al-Hanabila" 2/181.
3. "Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" 1/439. And the Hadith of Zuhair was narrated by Abu Dawood (617), he said: Ahmad bin Yunus told us, Zuhair told us, Abdul-Rahman bin Ziyad bin An'am told us, from Abdul-Rahman bin Rafi' and Bakr bin Sawada, from Abdullah bin Amr that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... The Hadith.

text:
225 - What has been reported regarding shortening the Salutation (Hadhf al-Salam)
The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: "Shortening the Salam is Sunnah" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: This is something narrated by Qurrah, and he is weak (2). And once Imam Ahmad forbade elevating it (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (1004), he said: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal told us, Muhammad bin Yusuf Al-Firyabi told me, Al-Awza'i told us, from Qurrah bin Abdul-Rahman, from Al-Zuhri, from Abu Salama, from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Shortening the Salam is Sunnah."
2. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2033).
3. "Sunan Abu Dawood" (1004) "Al-Maqasid Al-Hasanah by Al-Sakhawi" p. 162. I say: Imam Ahmad said: Shortening the Salam is: That a man comes to a people and says: Al-Salamu 'alaykum, and Abu Abdullah extended his voice greatly, but let him say: Al-Salamu 'alaykum, and Abu Abdullah lightened his voice with it, he said: He says it like this. I say: It occurred in "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/593: Ahmad said: This is a Hasan Sahih Hadith, and this is an illusion, the correct is that it is from the statement of Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him. For Al-Tirmidhi said: This is a Hasan Sahih Hadith (297).

text:
226 - What has been reported regarding the two Salutations
The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: He used to say Taslim in prayer two salutations, to his right and to his left (1).
Imam Ahmad said when this Hadith was mentioned to him. He said: He says in it: 'Haddathana' (He told us). Meaning Baqiyyah. It was said to him: Do they not deny that he heard it? He said: This is the falsest of false (2).

227 - What has been reported regarding the single Salutation
It contains two Hadiths:
First: The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said one Taslim (3).
Imam Ahmad said: Jarir bin Hazim narrates wonders from Ayyub (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tahawi in "Sharh Ma'ani Al-Athar" 1/268, he said: Ibn Abi Dawood told us, he said Haywah bin Shuraih told us, Baqiyyah told us, from Al-Zubaidi, from Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from his father, in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (2005).
3. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 1/335, he said: Yunus bin Muhammad told us, he said: Jarir told us, from Hazim, from Ayyub, from Anas in a Marfu' form.
4. "Fath Al-Bari" 5/210. Issue: The first Salam to exit from prayer while sitting is obligatory according to the Malikis and Shafi'is, and two Salutations are obligatory according to the Hanbalis except in Funeral prayer, voluntary prayer, prostration of recitation and gratitude, so one exits from it with a single Salutation. Prayer is concluded according to the Malikis and Shafi'is by the first Salam, and according to the Hanbalis by the second Salam.

text:
Second: The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: He used to say one Taslim in front of his face, inclining slightly to the right side (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The Hadiths of Al-Tinnisi from Zuhair are false (Bawatil). Al-Athram said: I think he said: Fabricated. Al-Athram said: So I mentioned to him this Hadith regarding the single Taslim. He said something like this (2).
And he said once: We do not know from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding the single Taslim except a Mursal Hadith by Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace (3).
And he said once: Hisham used to say he would say one Taslim that he would make us hear. It was said to him: They differ concerning it from Hisham, some say: 'Tasliman' (Salutation) and some say: 'Taslimah' (One Salutation). He said: This is better (4).
foot_note:
1. = Ibn Al-Mundhir said: Everyone from whom I memorize among the people of knowledge agreed that the prayer of one who restricts himself to a single Salutation is valid.
1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (296), he said: Muhammad bin Yahya Al-Naysaburi told us, Amr bin Abi Salama Abu Hafs Al-Tinnisi told us, from Zuhair bin Muhammad, from Hisham bin Urwa, from his father, from Aisha, in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/209, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 4/344.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/208.
4. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/589, and see "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1967).

text:
228 - What has been reported regarding one who breaks his wudu in prayer before Taslim
The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: "He should not leave until he hears a sound or smells an odor" (1).
Imam Ahmad denounced it and considered it grave (in error), and said: Al-Muharibi from Ma'mar is very Munkar (denounced). And he said: We do not know that Al-Muharibi heard anything from Ma'mar, and it has reached us that Al-Muharibi used to practice Tadlis (2).

229 - What has been reported regarding responding to the Salam of the Imam
The Hadith of Samura bin Jundab, may Allah be pleased with him: "When the Imam says Salam, respond to him" (3).
Imam Ahmad said regarding responding to the Imam: I do not know a high (authentic) Hadith in it that can be relied upon (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (514), he said: Abu Kurayb told us, Al-Muharibi told us, from Ma'mar bin Rashid, from Al-Zuhri, Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib informed us, from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was asked about doubt in prayer? He said: "He should not leave until he hears a sound or smells an odor."
2. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (5597), "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 2/347-348, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 3/417, "Mizan Al-I'tidal" 3/299. I say: And the text is established and authentic in the two Sahihs, for Al-Bukhari (177) and Muslim (361) narrated it from the Hadith of Abbad bin Tamim, from his uncle, that a complaint was made to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about a man who imagines he feels something during prayer. He said: "He should not leave until he hears a sound or smells an odor."
3. Narrated by Ibn Majah (921), he said: Hisham bin Ammar told us, Ismail bin Ayyash told us, Abu Bakr Al-Hudhali told us, from Qatada, from Al-Hasan, from Samura bin Jundab in a Marfu' form with it.
4. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (506), "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/226.

text:
230 - What has been reported regarding the completion of prayer after Taslim
The Hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: "If he sits for the duration of the Tashahhud then breaks his wudu, his prayer is complete" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic (2).

231 - What has been reported regarding the Taslim of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, to his right and left
It contains two Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say Taslim to his right and to his left until the whiteness of his cheek could be seen (3).
Imam Ahmad said: Shu'ba used to denounce the Hadith of Abu Ishaq from Abu Al-Ahwas, from Abdullah, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding the two Salutations.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi 2/173, he said: Abu Nasr Omar bin Abdul-Aziz bin Omar bin Qatada informed us from the original of his book, Abu Amr bin Najid informed us, Abu Muslim informed us, Abu Asim told us, Abu Awana informed us, from Al-Hakam, from Asim bin Damrah, from Ali, his saying.
2. "Sunan Al-Bayhaqi" 2/140, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd Al-Hadi 1/410.
3. Narrated by Ahmad 1/390, 408, 444, 448, Abu Dawood (996), Al-Nasa'i 3/63, and Ibn Majah (914), all from paths from Abu Ishaq, from Abu Al-Ahwas, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud with it. And Ahmad narrated it 1/406, and Abu Dawood (996) from the path of Isra'il, from Abu Ishaq, from Abu Al-Ahwas and Al-Aswad, from Ibn Mas'ud. And Al-Nasa'i narrated it 3/63 from the path of Al-Husain bin Waqid, from Abu Ishaq, from Abu Al-Ahwas, Alqama, and Al-Aswad, from Ibn Mas'ud.

text:
And the Hadith of Hammad, from Ibrahim, from Abdullah, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. It was said to him: Did he denounce it? Ahmad said: Abdul-Rahman and Yahya said: They were like the wind to him. It was said to him: What did he denounce from it? He said: He denounced that it be elevated to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace (1).
The Second: The Hadith of Al-Bara bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say Taslim to his right and to his left (2).
Imam Ahmad said: This is Munkar (3). And he said once: It is established from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, from more than one aspect that he used to say Taslim to his right and to his left until the whiteness of his cheek could be seen (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1911).
2. Narrated by Ibn Adi in "Al-Kamil" 2/431, he said: Ishaq bin Ibrahim Al-Manjaniqi told us, Muhammad bin Bakkar told us, Hudayj told us, from Abu Ishaq, from Al-Bara that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say Taslim to his right and to his left.
3. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2292) "Ilal Al-Marudhi" number (231), "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (5251), "Bahr Al-Dam" (256), "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 1/296.
4. "Masa'il Abdullah bin Ahmad" (295), "Al-Mughni" 1/592, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/208. I say: And the Hadith was narrated by Muslim (582) via the path of Amir bin Sa'd, from his father, he said: I used to see the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say Taslim to his right and to his left until I could see the whiteness of his cheek.

text:
232 - What has been reported regarding the Imam facing the people when he says Taslim
The Hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever says after the Fajr prayer while he is still bending his legs before he speaks: There is no god but Allah alone, He has no partner..." The Hadith (1).
Ahmad did not take the Hadith of Abu Dharr, for this Hadith was mentioned to him, so he said: It is more pleasing to me that he does not sit; because the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he prayed the Morning prayer (2), would turn his face towards them (3).
Ibn Rajab said: Meaning: That this is more authentic than the Hadith of Shahr bin Hawshab.
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (3474), he said: Ishaq bin Mansur told us, Ali bin Ma'bad Al-Misri told us, Ubaydullah bin Amr Al-Raqqi told us, from Zaid bin Abi Anisa, from Shahr bin Hawshab, from Abdul-Rahman bin Ghanm, from Abu Dharr, in a Marfu' form with it.
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (845) via the path of Jarir bin Hazim, he said: Raja' told us, from Samura bin Jundab, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he prayed, would turn his face towards us.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/261.

text:
233 - What has been reported regarding recitation in Zuhr prayer
The Hadith of Abu Qatada, may Allah be pleased with him: And in it is an addition: And in the last two Rak'ahs with the Opening of the Book (Umm Al-Kitab) (1).
Imam Ahmad said when asked about this addition: Is it established? He said: Several people narrated it, and some of them narrated it from Al-Awza'i. It was said to him: Hisham does not say it (2). He said: Yes, Hisham does not say it (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (776), and Muslim (451), both from the path of Hammam - and Muslim added: Aban - from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abdullah bin Abi Qatada, from his father that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to recite in the first two Rak'ahs of Zuhr with Umm Al-Kitab and two Surahs, and in the last two Rak'ahs with Umm Al-Kitab, and he would let us hear the verse, and he would prolong the first Rak'ah more than the second, and likewise in Asr, and likewise in Subh (Fajr).
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (779), he said: Abu Nu'aym told us, Hisham told us, from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abdullah bin Abi Qatada, from his father that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to prolong the first Rak'ah of Zuhr prayer and shorten the second, and he did that in Subh prayer.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/476. I say: There was disagreement regarding it concerning Yahya bin Abi Kathir. Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i - who is the most reliable person regarding Yahya - Shayban, Hajjaj bin Al-Sawwaf, and Al-Awza'i in a narration from Yahya bin Abi Kathir narrated it without this addition. And Hammam, Aban, Al-Awza'i in a narration, and Muhammad bin Maymun narrated it mentioning it. Ibn Khuzayma said 1/254: I used to think for a time that this report mentioning the recitation of the Opening of the Book in the last two Rak'ahs of Zuhr and Asr was not narrated by anyone except Aban bin Yazid and Hammam bin Yahya, based on what I used to hear from our companions among the People of Traditions, then behold, Al-Awza'i with his eminence has mentioned this addition in a report.

text:
234 - What has been reported regarding the amount of recitation in Zuhr
The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prostrated in the first Rak'ah of Zuhr prayer, so his companions thought that he recited Tanzil Al-Sajdah (1).
Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith has no Isnad (2). And he said once: Sulayman did not hear it from Abu Mijlaz, and some of them do not say in it: From Ibn Omar. Meaning: He made it Mursal (3).
foot_note:
1. = I say: And Al-Awza'i errs in the Hadith of Yahya bin Abi Kathir. What is apparent from Imam Ahmad's words is the acceptance of this addition, and Allah knows best. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 4/476: Most scholars have adopted the view of saying this, and that he does not add to the Opening of the Book in the last two Rak'ahs and the third of Maghrib. Similar to this was narrated from Ali, Ibn Mas'ud, Aisha, Abu Huraira, Jabir, and Abu Al-Darda. And from Ibn Sirin, he said: I do not know them differing that he recites in the first two Rak'ahs with the Opening of the Book and a Surah, and in the last two with the Opening of the Book. Also indicative of this is the Hadith of Sa'd regarding shortening the last two. Malik narrated from Nafi', from Ibn Omar that when he prayed alone, he would recite in all four Rak'ahs with Umm Al-Quran and a Surah. Al-Shafi'i held - in one of his two opinions - that it is recommended to recite a Surah with the Quran [Fatihah] in all Rak'ahs. Some of our companions narrated it as a narration from Ahmad, but most of our companions said: It is not recommended, a single narration. And regarding its dislike from Imam Ahmad, there are two narrations.
1. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 2/83, he said: Yazid bin Harun told us, Sulayman Al-Taimi informed us, from Abu Mijlaz, from Ibn Omar that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prostrated in the first Rak'ah of Zuhr prayer, so his companions thought that he recited Tanzil Al-Sajdah.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/444.
3. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (2037), "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/444, "Musnad Ahmad" 2/83.

text:
235 - What has been reported regarding recitation in Fajr
The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed two Rak'ahs in which he did not add to the Opening of the Book (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Weak (2).

236 - What has been reported regarding reciting the Quran completely in the obligatory prayer
The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: The companions of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to recite the Quran from its beginning to its end in the obligatory prayers (3).
Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith (4).
foot_note:
1. = I say: And in "Sahih Muslim" (452) there is a corroboration for this Hadith with different wordings from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he said: We used to estimate the standing of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in Zuhr and Asr. So we estimated his standing in the first two Rak'ahs of Zuhr to be the amount of reciting {Alif Lam Mim (1) The revelation of} Al-Sajdah, and we estimated his standing in the last two to be half of that... The Hadith.
1. The Hadith.
2. "Al-Uqayli" 1/290, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 7/449.
3. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 8/123 number (8162), he said: Musa bin Harun told us; Abu Al-Rabi' Al-Zahrani told us, Salm bin Qutaybah Abu Qutaybah told us, Sahl bin Abi Hazim told us, from Thabit Al-Bunani, from Anas bin Malik, he said: The companions... The Hadith.
4. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2334), "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/12, "Bada'i' Al-Fawa'id" 3/95.

text:
237 - What has been reported regarding praying behind the row alone
It contains three Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Wabisah bin Ma'bad, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man prayed behind the row, so the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered him to repeat the prayer (1).
Imam Ahmad said: Hasan (Good) (2). And he said once: The Hadith of Amr bin Murrah is more established (3). And he said once: I do not know anyone opposing the Hadith of Wabisah (4). And he said once: Amr bin Murrah and Husain only differed, and he said: Amr bin Rashid is known (5). And once Ahmad established it (6).
The Second: The Hadith of Ali bin Shayban, may Allah be pleased with him: "Repeat your prayer, for there is no prayer for a man alone behind the row" (7).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (231), he said: Muhammad bin Bashar told us, Muhammad bin Ja'far told us, Shu'ba told us, from Amr bin Murrah, from Hilal bin Yasaf, from Amr bin Rashid, from Wabisah bin Ma'bad that a man prayed behind the row... The Hadith.
2. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/42, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd Al-Hadi 2/23.
3. "Sunan Al-Darimi" 1/333, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/23, "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/42.
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/25.
5. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/24.
6. "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd Al-Hadi 2/33.
7. Narrated by Ahmad 4/23, he said: Abdul-Samad and Surayj told us, they said: Mulazim bin Amr told us, Abdullah bin Badran told us, from Abdul-Rahman bin Ali, he told him that his father Ali bin Shayban told him that he =

Imam Ahmad said: It is Hasan because it contradicts the Waqf (being stopped at a Companion) (1).
The Third: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas similar to it (2).
Imam Ahmad said: This is Munkar, or he said: Batil. Then he said: Al-Nadr Abu Omar is Munkar al-Hadith (denounced in Hadith); Al-Himmani has narrated Munkar Hadiths from him other than this Hadith (3).
foot_note:
1. = went out as a delegate to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He said: So we prayed behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he glanced with the corner of his eyes at a man who was not straightening his back in bowing and prostration. When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, finished, he said: "O assembly of Muslims, indeed there is no prayer for the one who does not straighten his back in bowing and prostration." He said: And he saw a man praying behind the row, so he stopped until the man finished, then the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Repeat your prayer, for there is no prayer for a man alone behind the row."
1. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/42, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 2/37, "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/25, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 2/34.
2. Narrated by Al-Uqayli in "Al-Du'afa" 4/292, he said: Muhammad bin Ismail told us, he said: Al-Hasan bin Ali told us, he said: Abu Yahya Al-Himmani told us, he said: Al-Nadr bin Abdul-Rahman Abu Omar Al-Khazzar told us, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas that a man prayed behind the row alone, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered him to repeat.
3. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2286). Benefit: The jurists differed regarding the validity of praying behind the rows alone, with two opinions: The majority other than the Hanbalis said: If a person prays behind the row alone, his prayer suffices, except that the Shafi'is and Hanafis said: The prayer is valid with Karahah (dislike). The Hanbalis said: The prayer of the individual if he prays a complete Rak'ah behind the row alone is invalid and does not suffice, and it is obligatory to repeat it. I say: Ability is the criterion for obligation; if he does not find a place in the row and prays alone, his prayer is valid, if Allah wills.

text:
238 - What has been reported regarding bowing before reaching the row
The Hadith of Abu Bakra, may Allah be pleased with him: "May Allah increase you in eagerness, but do not return [to doing it]" (1).
Imam Ahmad said when asked about the narration of Mubarak from Al-Hasan. Meaning the Hadith "May Allah increase you in eagerness." Leave Mubarak, and he paid no attention to Mubarak (2).

239 - What has been reported regarding the bowing of the follower before joining the row
The Hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, may Allah be pleased with him: If one of you enters the mosque while the people are bowing, let him bow when he enters then walk slowly while bowing until he enters the row, for that is
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 5/37, he said: Khalaf bin Al-Walid told us, Al-Mubarak told us, from Al-Hasan, from Abu Bakra that he told him, he said: The sun eclipsed during the time of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so he stood up dragging his garment hurriedly until he came to the mosque, and the people gathered. So he prayed two Rak'ahs, and it cleared. Then he turned to us and said: "The sun and the moon are two signs..." The Hadith. I say: I did not find the Hadith of Mubarak except from this outlet, and Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab mentioned it in "Fath Al-Bari" in the explanation of this Hadith to prove Al-Hasan's hearing from Abu Bakra, and he mentioned that it is in the Eclipse Prayer 5/8.
2. "Al-Kamil fi Al-Du'afa" by Ibn Adi 6/319. I say: And the text is established in Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of Abu Bakra number (783). Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 5/908: Whoever catches the Ruku' with the Imam has caught the Rak'ah even if he missed the standing and recitation of Al-Fatihah with him. This is the saying of the majority of scholars, and Ishaq bin Rahwayh and others narrated it as a consensus among scholars. Imam Ahmad mentioned in the narration of Abu Talib that no one from the people of Islam disagreed on that. It is the saying of the general scholars of the regions. A group held that he does not catch the Rak'ah by catching the Ruku' with the Imam; because he missed the standing and recitation of Al-Fatihah with the Imam. Al-Bukhari and Ibn Khuzayma went to this school, and this is an anomaly (Shudhudh) from the people of knowledge and opposition to their group.

Imam Ahmad did not authenticate this Hadith. And he said: The correct view from Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr is the prohibition of it (2).

240 - What has been reported regarding the prayer of the sitting person
The Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "The prayer of the sitting person receives half [the reward] of the prayer of the standing person" (3).
Imam Ahmad said: Munkar (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Khuzayma in his "Sahih" 3/32 number (1571), he said: Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Sa'id bin Al-Hakam bin Abi Maryam Al-Misri told us, my grandfather told us, Abdullah bin Wahb informed me, Ibn Jurayj informed me, from Ata that he heard Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr on the pulpit saying to the people: If one of you enters the mosque while the people are bowing, let him bow when he enters, then walk slowly while bowing until he enters the row, for that is the Sunnah. Ata said: And I saw him do that.
2. Ibn Rajab in "Fath Al-Bari" 5/14. I say: The correct report in this chapter is what Al-Bukhari narrated (783) from the Hadith of Al-Hasan from Abu Bakra that he reached the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, while he was bowing, so he bowed before reaching the row. He mentioned that to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he said: "May Allah increase you in eagerness, but do not return [to doing it]."
3. Narrated by Al-Uqayli in "Al-Du'afa" 1/206-207, he said: Abdullah bin Ahmad told us, from Jabbar bin Al-Mughallis, from Hammad bin Yahya Al-Abh, from Al-Hakam, from Ibn Jarir, from Ibn Abbas... in a Marfu' form with it.
4. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (1090), Al-Uqayli in "Al-Du'afa" 1/207, "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" 4/491, "Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib" 1/359. I say: And the text is established and authentic in the two Sahihs, for Al-Bukhari narrated it (1116), he said: Abu Ma'mar told us, he said: Abdul-Warith told us, he said: Husain Al-Mu'allim told us, from Abdullah bin =

text:
241 - The position of the woman and the boy in prayer
The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: I and an orphan prayed in our house behind the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and my mother - Umm Sulaym - was behind us (1).
Imam Ahmad said: My heart does not dare [to accept] the Hadith of Ishaq from Anas; because the Hadith of Musa (2) contradicts it, it does not mention the orphan (3).
And Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal said: My father did not insist on this - the Hadith of Ishaq - because the Hadith of Shu'ba. Meaning: contradicts it (4).
foot_note:
1. = Buraydah, that Imran bin Husain was a man with hemorrhoids, and Abu Ma'mar said once: from Imran, he said: I asked the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about the prayer of a man while sitting, so he said: "Whoever prays standing, it is better. And whoever prays sitting, he has half the reward of the standing one. And whoever prays lying down (sleeping), he has half the reward of the sitting one."
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (727), and Muslim (658). Al-Bukhari said: Abdullah bin Muhammad told us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Ishaq, from Anas bin Malik, he said... So he mentioned it.
2. Narrated by Muslim (660), he said: Ubaydullah bin Mu'adh told us, my father told us, Shu'ba told us, from Abdullah bin Al-Mukhtar, he heard Musa bin Anas narrating, from Anas bin Malik that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, prayed with him and his mother or his maternal aunt. He said: So he made me stand on his right, and made the woman stand behind us.
3. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/269, "Bada'i' Al-Fawa'id" by Ibn Al-Qayyim 3/83.
4. "Masa'il Abdullah" (416). Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 4/270: In summary, scholars have two approaches regarding these Hadiths from Anas: One: Contradiction between them and preferring the narration of Musa bin Anas from him; because it agrees with the Hadith of Ibn Abbas and others. Two: That they are two different incidents, and this is the approach of Ibn Hibban and others. Issue: The majority of people of knowledge hold that the man stands on the right of the Imam and the woman behind him.

242 - What has been reported regarding daytime prayer
It contains two Hadiths:
The Hadith of Ibn Omar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "The prayer of the night and the day is two by two" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The addition of "the day" is weak (2).
And he said once: If only that Hadith were established (3).
And he said once: Shu'ba was hesitant about the Hadith of Ibn Omar due to the addition which contains: "the day"; because it is famous from Ibn Omar from several aspects: "The prayer of the night" without: "and the day" (4).
And he said: And Nafi' narrated from Ibn Omar that he saw no harm in praying four during the day, and some of them said: From Nafi' from Ibn Omar that he used to pray four during the day. If Ibn Omar had preserved from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, 'the prayer of the day is two by two', he would not have prayed four during the day. And it has been narrated from Ibn Omar his saying: 'The prayer of the night and the day is two by two', and Allah knows best (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (1295), he said: Amr bin Marzuq told us, Shu'ba informed us, from Ya'la bin Ata, from Ali bin Abdullah Al-Bariqi, from Ibn Omar, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... The Hadith.
2. "Al-Fatawa" by Ibn Taymiyyah 23/169.
3. "Al-Tamhid" by Ibn Abd Al-Barr 13/244.
4. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (990), and Muslim (749) via the path of Malik, from Nafi' and Abdullah bin Dinar, from Ibn Omar: That a man asked the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about the night prayer: So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The night prayer is two by two, so if one of you fears the morning, let him pray one Rak'ah which will make odd (Witr) for him what he has prayed."
5. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1872), (1968).

text:
243 - Starting a voluntary prayer after the Mu'adhin starts the Iqamah
The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: "When the prayer is established (Iqamah), there is no prayer except the obligatory one" (1).
Imam Ahmad leaned towards elevating it [to the Prophet] (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (710), he said: Ahmad bin Hanbal told me, Muhammad bin Ja'far told us, Shu'ba told us, from Warqa', from Amr bin Dinar, from Ata bin Yasar, from Abu Huraira... in a Marfu' form with it.
2. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/55. Ibn Rajab said: There was disagreement regarding its elevation and its stopping (Waqf). Al-Tirmidhi and Muslim preferred its elevation, Abu Zur'ah preferred its stopping, and Ibn Ma'in paused regarding it. Al-Bukhari did not extract it due to his pause or his preference for its stopping, and Allah knows best. I say: Al-Tahawi also preferred its stopping in "Sharh Ma'ani Al-Athar". Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 6/59-62, (adapted): We know of no disagreement that the establishing of prayer cuts off voluntary prayer except for the two Rak'ahs of Fajr; there is disagreement about them. Among those who disliked prayer after Iqamah: Al-Shafi'i, Ibn Al-Mubarak, Ahmad bin Hanbal, Ishaq, Abu Thawr, Abu Hanifa, and Sulayman bin Dawood. Malik permitted prayer after Iqamah outside the mosque if he did not fear missing the first Rak'ah. Ibn Mansur narrated from Ahmad and Ishaq that they permitted them in the house. It was also narrated from Ahmad and Al-Shafi'i that he does not pray them in the mosque nor in the house, and all of this is the ruling on starting voluntary prayer after the establishment of prayer.

text:
244 - What has been reported regarding the number of Rak'ahs in a day
It contains two Hadiths:
The First: The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "Whoever prays twelve Rak'ahs in a day, Allah builds for him a house in Paradise" (1).
Imam Ahmad said: The Hadiths of Mughira bin Ziyad are Manakir (denounced). Then this Hadith was mentioned to him to clarify the reason for the Nakarah. He said: They narrate it from Ata from Anbasa from Umm Habiba (2).
The Second: The Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him: Similar to it (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (414), he said: Muhammad bin Rafi' Al-Naysaburi told us, Ishaq bin Sulayman Al-Razi told us, Al-Mughira bin Ziyad told us, from Ata, from Aisha, she said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever persists in twelve Rak'ahs from the Sunnah, Allah builds for him a house in Paradise: four Rak'ahs before Zuhr, and two Rak'ahs after it, and two Rak'ahs after Maghrib, and two Rak'ahs after Isha, and two Rak'ahs before Fajr."
2. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah (835) and also (4011), (4012), (4054), (4729), "Al-Du'afa Al-Kabir" 4/176, "Al-Kamil" by Ibn Adi 8/73, Ibn Abi Hatim in "Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil" 8/222, "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 2/12 from other than the path of Ata. I say: And the Hadith of Umm Habiba was narrated by Muslim without mentioning the detail (728), he said: Muhammad Ibn Abdullah bin Numair told us, Abu Khalid told us, from Dawood bin Abi Hind, from Al-Nu'man bin Salim, from Amr bin Aws, he said: Anbasa bin Abi Sufyan told me during his illness in which he died a Hadith that was whispered to him, he said: I heard Umm Habiba saying: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "Whoever prays twelve Rak'ahs in a day and night, a house is built for him with them in Paradise."
3. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 9/166 number (9436), he said: Haitham bin Khalaf told us, Ahmad bin Ibrahim Al-Mawsili told us, Hammad bin Zaid told us, from Harun Abu Ishaq Al-Kufi, that he heard Abu Burdah narrating from his father, Abu Musa, in a Marfu' form with it.

245 - What has been reported regarding one who misses the two Rak'ahs before Fajr
The Hadith of Qais bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with him: "Wait, O Qais, two prayers together?" (2).
Imam Ahmad said: Mursal (3). And he said once: Not authentic (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Abi Dawood" for Ahmad (1886).
2. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 5/447, he said: Ibn Numair told us, Sa'd bin Sa'id told us, Muhammad bin Ibrahim Al-Taimi told me, from Qais bin Amr, he said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw a man praying two Rak'ahs after the Subh prayer, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Is the Subh prayer twice?" The man said: I had not prayed the two Rak'ahs that are before it, so I prayed them now. He said: So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, remained silent.
3. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/532, "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1881), "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 1/481.
4. "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/318. Issue: Al-Khattabi said in "Ma'alim Al-Sunan" 1/238: People differed regarding the time of making up the two Rak'ahs of Fajr. It was narrated from Ibn Omar that he said: He makes them up after the Subh prayer. Ata, Tawus, and Ibn Jurayj said the same. A group said: He makes them up when the sun rises. This is the opinion of Al-Qasim bin Muhammad, and it is the school of Al-Awza'i, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad bin Hanbal, and Ishaq bin Rahwayh. The People of Opinion (Ashab Al-Ra'y) said: If he wishes, he makes them up when the sun has risen high, and if he does not do so, there is nothing upon him; because it is voluntary. Malik said: He makes them up in the Duha time until the time of the sun's zenith, and he does not make them up after the zenith.

text:
246 - What has been reported regarding lying down after the two Rak'ahs of Fajr
The Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: And in it... then lie down on his right side until the caller comes to him for Iqamah (1).
Imam Ahmad said, when asked about lying down: Shu'ba does not elevate it. It was said to him: Is there anything against lying down? He said: No, Aisha narrates it (2), and Ibn Omar denounces it (3). Al-Khallal said: And Al-Marudhi informed us that Abu Abdullah said: The Hadith of Abu Huraira is not that [strong]. It was said to him: Al-A'mash narrates it from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira. He said: Abdul-Wahid alone narrates it (4). And he said once: There is no Hadith established regarding lying down. It was said to him: The Hadith of Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira?
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (420), he said: Bishr bin Mu'adh Al-Aqadi told us, Abdul-Wahid bin Ziyad told us, Al-A'mash told us, from Abu Salih, from Abu Huraira, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "When one of you prays the two Rak'ahs of Fajr, let him lie down on his right side."
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (626) and Muslim (736), both from the path of Ibn Shihab, from Urwa, from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when the caller fell silent from the first Adhan of the Fajr prayer, would stand and pray two light Rak'ahs before the Fajr prayer after the dawn became clear, then lie down on his right side until the caller came to him for Iqamah.
3. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/151, he said: Waki' told us, he said: Imran bin Hudayr told us, from Abu Mijlaz, he said: I asked Ibn Omar about a man lying down on his right side after the two Rak'ahs before the Fajr prayer, so he said: Satan is playing with you.
4. "Zad Al-Ma'ad" 1/321.

He said: Some of them narrated it as Mursal (1). And he said once: It is not a Sunnah; because Ibn Mas'ud (2) denounced it (3).

247 - What has been reported regarding talking after the two Rak'ahs of Fajr
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to pray two Rak'ahs, if I was awake he would talk to me, otherwise he would lie down (4).
Imam Ahmad was asked about this Hadith, so he said: That is not clear. As if silence was more pleasing to him (5).

248 - What has been reported regarding prayer before Zuhr
The Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, persisted in four Rak'ahs at the declining of the sun (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Al-Tamhid" by Ibn Abd Al-Barr 8/126, "Al-Nasikh wa Al-Mansukh" by Al-Athram (55).
2. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/151, he said: Waki' told us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Hammad, from Ibrahim, he said: Abdullah said: What is with the man, when he prays the two Rak'ahs, rolling like a beast and a donkey roll? If he says Taslim, let him sit and pray.
3. Ibn Qudamah in "Al-Mughni" 1/763.
4. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1168), and Muslim (743) from the path of Sufyan bin Uyaynah, from Abu Al-Nadr, from Abu Salama, from Aisha in a Marfu' form with it.
5. "Masa'il Al-Kawsaj" (298).
6. Narrated by Ahmad 5/416, he said: Abu Mu'awiyah told us, Ubaydah told us, from Ibrahim, from Sahm bin Minjab, from Qaza'ah, from Al-Qartha', from Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, persisted in four Rak'ahs at the declining of the sun. He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, what are these Rak'ahs which =
