Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith was narrated by Qaza'ah and Qartha', and who is Qaza'ah and who is Qartha'? (1).

249 - What has been reported regarding the one who misses the four before Zuhr
The Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, if he missed the four before Zuhr, he would pray them after the two Rak'ahs after Zuhr (2).
Imam Ahmad said: More than one narrate it without mentioning this in it. Meaning: They narrate the Hadith of Khalid from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, 'I asked Aisha about the voluntary prayer of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace' (3), meaning: This is not in it (4).
foot_note:
1. = I see you have persisted in? He said: "Verily, the gates of heaven are opened at the declining of the sun, and they are not closed until the Zuhr prayer is prayed, so I love that good ascends for me in that time." He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, do you recite in all of them? He said: "Yes." He said: I said: Is there a separating Taslim in them? He said: "No."
1. "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Al-Jawzi 3/292, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd Al-Hadi 1/499.
2. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1158), he said: Muhammad bin Yahya, Zaid bin Akhram, and Muhammad bin Ma'mar told us, they said: Musa bin Dawood Al-Kufi told us, Qais bin Al-Rabi' told us, from Shu'ba, from Khalid Al-Hadhdha, from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, from Aisha in a Marfu' form with it.
3. Narrated by Muslim (730), he said: Yahya told us, Hushaym informed us, from Khalid, from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, he said: I asked Aisha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about his voluntary prayer? She said: He used to pray four in my house before Zuhr, then go out and lead the people in prayer, then enter and pray two Rak'ahs. And he used to lead the people in Maghrib prayer, then enter and pray two Rak'ahs. And he would lead the people in Isha prayer and enter my house and pray two Rak'ahs. And he used to pray nine Rak'ahs at night, including Witr. And he used to pray for a long time at night standing and for a long time sitting. And if he recited while standing, he would bow and prostrate while standing, and if he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate while sitting. And when Fajr rose, he would pray two Rak'ahs.
4. "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (1876).

text: 250 - What has been narrated regarding the virtue of Isha and Fajr prayers in congregation contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b (may Allah be pleased with him): "These two prayers are the heaviest prayers for the hypocrites. If you knew what is in them, you would come to them even if crawling on knees." Imam Ahmad said: Sufyan (1) and Shu'bah (2) say: From Abu Ishaq, from Abdullah bin Abi Basir, they did not say from his father, so he mentioned it. Zuhair (3) and others say: From Abu Ishaq, from Abdullah bin Abi Basir, from his father, from Ubayy bin Ka'b (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq (2004), who said: Al-Thawri informed us, from Abu Ishaq, from Abdullah bin Abi al-Basir, from Ubayy bin Ka'b... elevated [to the Prophet].
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud (554), who said: Hafs bin Umar told us, Shu'bah told us, from Abu Ishaq, from Abdullah bin Abi Basir, from Ubayy bin Ka'b who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) led us in the Morning prayer one day and said: "Is so-and-so present?" They said: No. He said: "Is so-and-so present?" They said: No. He said: "Indeed, these two prayers are the heaviest prayers for the hypocrites. If you knew what is in them, you would come to them even if crawling on knees. And indeed, the first row is like the row of the angels; if you knew its virtue, you would race to it. And indeed, a man's prayer with another man is purer than his prayer alone, and his prayer with two men is purer than his prayer with one man, and what is more is more beloved to Allah the Almighty."
3. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi 3/68, who said: Abu al-Hasan bin al-Fadl al-Qattan informed us in Baghdad, Abdullah bin Ja'far informed us, Ya'qub bin Sufyan told us, Ahmad bin Yunus told us, Zuhair told us, Abu Ishaq told us, Abdullah bin Abi Basir told me, from his father who said: I came to Medina and met Ubayy bin Ka'b... elevated [to the Prophet].
4. "Ilal Abdullah bin Ahmad" (2632). Benefit: It is known that Shu'bah and Sufyan are among the trustworthy and reliable companions of Abu Ishaq. I say: The first paragraph of the Hadith has a witness in the Two Sahihs, for Al-Bukhari narrated (657) from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "No prayer is heavier for the hypocrites than Fajr and Isha, and if they knew what is in them, they would come to them even if crawling."

text: The Second: The Hadith of Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever prays Isha in congregation, it is as if he stood for half the night, and whoever prays the Morning prayer in congregation, it is as if he stood for the whole night" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi used to be hesitant to elevate this Hadith from Sufyan (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (656), who said: Ishaq bin Ibrahim told us, Al-Mughirah bin Salamah al-Makhzumi informed us, Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad told us, Uthman bin Hakim told us, Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Amrah told us, who said: Uthman bin Affan entered the mosque after Maghrib prayer and sat alone, so I sat with him. He said: O son of my brother, I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say... and he mentioned it.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1863). I say: Al-Daraqutni identified a defect in this Hadith as being Mawquf (stopped at the Companion) in "Al-Ilzamat wa al-Tatabbu'" p. 409, and in "Al-Ilal" 3/48. It should not be said: Al-Daraqutni authenticated the Hadith of Al-Thawri. End quote. As he said in "Al-Ilal": The closest to correctness is the Hadith of Al-Thawri. This applies to the last disagreement mentioned by Al-Daraqutni in "Al-Ilal" only, not to all paths of the Hadith, and Allah knows best.

text: 251 - What has been narrated regarding the virtue of going early to the Morning prayer. The Hadith of Salman al-Farsi (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever goes early to the Morning prayer is given a quarter of faith, and whoever goes early to the market is given the banner of Iblis, and he is with the first to go early and the last to return" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" 6/255 number (6146), who said: Ali bin Abd al-Aziz told us, Khalaf bin Hisham al-Bazzar told us, Isa bin Maymun told us, from Awn bin Abi Shaddad, from Abu Uthman, from Salman who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say... and he mentioned it.
2. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (5952), "Al-Du'afa" by Al-Uqayli 3/418, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 19/278, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 4/59.

text: 252 - What has been narrated regarding looking around in prayer contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Sa'id bin al-Musayyib—and some have connected it—he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to glance in prayer but not turn his head (1). Al-Khallal said: Al-Maimuni informed me that Abu Abdullah was told: Some people have attributed (Musnad) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to glance in prayer. He denied that strongly until his color changed and his body shook, and I saw him in a state I had never seen him worse than. He said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to glance in prayer?! Meaning: he denied that, and I reckon he said: It has no chain. He said: Who narrated this?! This is only from Sa'id bin al-Musayyib. Then some of our companions said to me: Abu Abdullah weakened the Hadith of Sa'id and weakened its chain, and said: It is only from a man from Sa'id (2). The Second: The Hadith of Abu Umamah and Wathilah (may Allah be pleased with them both): The Prophet (peace be upon him), when he stood in prayer, did not turn right or left and cast his gaze to the place of his prostration" (3). Imam Ahmad denied it strongly and said: Strike it out (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah in his "Musannaf" 1/493, who said: Hushaym told us, he said: Some of our companions informed me from Al-Zuhri, from Sa'id bin al-Musayyib who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to... The Hadith.
2. "Zad al-Ma'ad" 1/249-250, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/404.
3. Narrated by Al-Uqayli 1/255, who said: Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, he said: My father narrated to me the Hadith of Hassan bin Ibrahim, from Abd al-Malik al-Kufi who said: I heard Al-Ala' say: I heard Makhul narrate from Abu Umamah and Wathilah who said... The Hadith.
4. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (2701), "Al-Kamil fi al-Du'afa" 2/372, "Zad al-Ma'ad" 1/250, "Du'afa Al-Uqayli" 1/255 - Siyar A'lam al-Nubala 9/42.

publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Faiyum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 253 - What has been narrated regarding gesturing in prayer. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever gestures in his prayer a gesture that is understood from him, let him repeat the prayer" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not established; its chain is nothing (2).
foot_note:
1. = I say: Abu Ya'la said in "Tabaqat al-Hanabilah" 2/230, Al-Dhahabi in "Al-Siyar" 11/382, Al-Khatib in his "Tarikh" 6/351, and Al-Mizzi in "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 2/383: It was narrated from Ishaq bin Rahwayh that he said: Ahmad bin Hanbal asked me about the Hadith of Al-Fadl bin Musa, the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to glance in his prayer and not turn his neck behind his back. He said: So I narrated it to him. A man said: O Abu Ya'qub, Waki' narrated it differently than this. Ahmad bin Hanbal said to him: Be silent; if Abu Ya'qub, the Commander of the Faithful [in Hadith], narrates to you, then hold on to it. I say: Al-Tirmidhi narrated it (587) and described it as Gharib (strange), and the Imams identified a defect of Irsaal (disconnection) in it. Benefit: Authentic Hadiths have been narrated regarding looking around, among them in Al-Bukhari (751) from the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about looking around in prayer, so he said: "It is a snatching that Satan snatches from the servant's prayer." Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/274: Looking around is disliked (Makruh), and this is a consensus, and the majority hold that it is for tanziih (discouragement, not prohibition). End quote. Ibn Rajab said in "Fath al-Bari" 4/404: Ibn Mansur said: I said to Ahmad: If he looks around in prayer, does he repeat the prayer? He said: They have done wrong; I do not know that I have heard a Hadith regarding it that he repeats. As for looking around for the benefit of the prayer, like Abu Bakr looking around when the people clapped behind him, it does not invalidate the prayer. Our companions said: The looking around that invalidates is turning his neck, but if he turns his chest, his prayer is invalidated because he has left facing the Qiblah with most of his body, unlike if he turns with his face; for most of his body is facing the Qiblah. 
1. Narrated by Abu Dawud (944), who said: Abdullah bin Sa'id told us, Yunus bin Bukair told us, from Muhammad bin Ishaq, from Ya'qub bin Utbah bin al-Akhnas, from Abu Ghatafan, from Abu Hurayrah... elevated [to the Prophet].
2. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2038), "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/103, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/530, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 1/432.

text: 254 - What has been narrated regarding spitting in prayer. The Hadith of Tariq bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him): "If you pray, do not spit to your right nor in front of you, but spit behind you" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Neither Waki' nor Abd al-Razzaq said: "Spit behind you." Imam Ahmad denied this addition (2). 255 - What has been narrated regarding smoothing the pebbles in prayer. The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): Do not smooth the pebbles, for it is from Satan (3). Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Fudayl erred; he said: Muslim bin Abi Yasar. The correct is: Muslim bin Abi Maryam. Except that Shu'bah says: Abd al-Rahman bin Ali al-Ma'afiri, but it is: Ali bin Abd al-Rahman; Shu'bah erred (4).
foot_note:
1. = I say: Understood gesturing has been authentically reported from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in authentic Hadiths: during the illness of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and in the Hadith of Abu Bakr, Aisha, and others. And Allah knows best.
1. Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 6/396, saying: Yahya bin Sa'id told us, from Sufyan, from Mansur, from Rib'i, from Tariq bin Abdullah al-Muharibi who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If you pray, do not spit to your right nor in front of you, but spit behind you and to your left if it is empty, otherwise like this" and that is under his foot.
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 6/396, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/344.
3. Narrated by Ahmad 2/10, who said: Sufyan told us, Muslim bin Abi Maryam told me, from Ali bin Abd al-Rahman al-Ma'afiri who said: I prayed next to Ibn Umar and smoothed the pebbles, so he said: Do not smooth the pebbles, for it is from Satan, but do as you saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) doing; he used to move it like this.
4. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (210), "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 21/54. I say: Muslim narrated it (579) from the same source without this text.

text: 256 - What has been narrated regarding praying in Khuffs (leather socks) and sandals. The Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) praying in Khuffs and sandals (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abu Ishaq did not hear it from Alqamah bin Qais (2). 257 - What has been narrated regarding the dislike of praying in women's wraps (Lihaf). The Hadith of Aisha: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used not to pray in the wraps of his wives (3). Imam Ahmad denied it strongly and said: I have not heard from Ash'ath a Hadith more Munkar (denounced) than this (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Imam Ahmad in his "Musnad" 1/461, who said: Hasan bin Musa told us, Zuhair told us, from Abu Ishaq, from Alqamah bin Qais—and he did not hear it from him—and a man asked him about the Hadith of Alqamah, which is this Hadith: That Abdullah bin Mas'ud came to Abu Musa al-Ash'ari in his house, and the prayer time came, so Abu Musa said: Come forward, O Abu Abd al-Rahman; for you are older than us and more knowledgeable. He said: No, rather you come forward; for we came to you in your house and your mosque, so you are more entitled. So Abu Musa came forward and removed his sandals. When he finished the prayer, he said: Why did you remove them? Are you in the Sacred Valley?! I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) praying in Khuffs and sandals.
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 1/461.
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (600), who said: Muhammad bin Abd al-A'la told us, Khalid bin al-Harith told us, from Ash'ath bin Abd al-Malik, from Muhammad bin Sirin, from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, from Aisha elevated [to the Prophet].
4. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 1/462, "Ilal Abdullah bin Ahmad" (5982), "Al-Farusiyyah" by Ibn al-Qayyim p. 198.

text: 258 - Prayer in the garment in which one approaches his wife. The Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah (may Allah be pleased with him): I heard a man ask the Prophet (peace be upon him): Can I pray in my garment in which I approach my wife? He said: "Yes" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not elevated (Marfu') from Abd al-Malik bin Umair (2). And he said once: This Hadith is not elevated from Jabir bin Samurah, indicating that whoever elevated it was mistaken (3).
foot_note:
1. = I say: A concession regarding that has been narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him). Muslim narrated in his Sahih (514), saying: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah and Zuhair bin Harb told us, Zuhair said: Waki' told us, Talhah bin Yahya told us, from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah who said: I heard him from Aisha who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to pray at night while I was beside him, and I was menstruating and had a sheet (Mirt) on me, part of which was on his side. Al-Shawkani said: All of that indicates the non-obligation of avoiding women's clothes, and it is only recommended to do so out of precaution. Al-Athram said: The Hadiths of concession are more numerous and more famous. He said: If praying in women's hair [garments] were invalid for men, prayer in them would be invalid for women.
1. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 5/89, who said: Abdullah bin Maymun Abu Abd al-Rahman—meaning Al-Raqqi—told us, Ubaidullah—meaning Ibn Amr—told us, from Abd al-Malik bin Umair, from Jabir bin Samurah who said: I heard a man asking the Prophet (peace be upon him): Can I pray in my garment in which I approach my wife? He said: "Yes, unless you see something in it, then wash it."
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 5/89.
3. Ibn Rajab in "Fath al-Bari" 2/136.

text: 259 - Praying with unfastened buttons if one is wearing more than one garment. The Hadith of Zaid bin Aslam (may Allah be pleased with them both): I saw Ibn Umar praying with his buttons unfastened, so I asked him about that, and he said: I saw the Prophet (peace be upon him) doing it (1). Imam Ahmad said after mentioning this Hadith: It seems this Sheikh is another Sheikh; they must have flipped his name. Meaning the narration of Zuhair bin Muhammad from the Levantines (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah (799), who said: Muhammad bin Yahya informed us, Safwan bin Salih al-Thaqafi told us, Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, Zuhair bin Muhammad told us, Zaid bin Aslam told us... The Hadith.
2. "Siyar A'lam al-Nubala" 8/190.

text: 260 - What has been narrated regarding congregation in a mosque where prayer has already been held once. The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him): "Who among you will give charity to this one?" (1). Imam Ahmad strengthened it and adopted it (2). 261 - A man prays alone then catches the congregation. Contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Yazid bin al-Aswad (may Allah be pleased with him): "What prevented you two from praying with us?" They said: O Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), we had already prayed in our dwellings. He said: "Do not do that" (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (220), who said: Hannad told us, Abdah told us, from Sa'id bin Abi Arubah, from Sulayman al-Naji al-Basri, from Abu al-Mutawakkil, from Abu Sa'id who said: A man came after the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) had prayed, so he said... The Hadith.
2. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 4/26. Issue: Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 4/24: Scholars differed regarding repeating the congregation in a mosque where its regular Imam has prayed. Some of them: disliked it and said: They pray in it individually. This was narrated from Salim and Abu Qilabah, and some attributed it to scholars, from Sa'id bin al-Musayyib, Al-Hasan, Al-Nakha'i, Al-Dahhak, Al-Qasim bin Muhammad, Al-Zuhri, and others. It is the view of Al-Layth, Al-Awza'i, Al-Thawri, Abu Hanifah, and Malik. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it from Ibn al-Mubarak and Al-Shafi'i. Al-Rabi' narrated from Al-Shafi'i that the Salaf did not do it, rather some of them criticized it. Most scholars went to the permissibility of repeating the congregation in mosques in general, as Anas bin Malik did. Among them are Ata, Qatadah, and Makhul. It is the view of Ishaq, Abu Yusuf, Muhammad, and Dawud. There is a narration from Ahmad that it is not disliked at all, and another time from him that it is disliked in the two mosques of Mecca and Medina, and permissible elsewhere.
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (219), who said: Ahmad bin Mani' told us, Hushaym told us, Ya'la bin Ata informed us, Jabir bin Yazid bin al-Aswad told us, from his father who said: I witnessed with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) =

text: Imam Ahmad said: Hushaym did not hear this word from Ya'la bin Ata (1) — meaning: that the Prophet led them in the Morning prayer then turned away. And he said once: Hushaym narrated it and heard it from Ya'la, but he did not hear from him: "he turned away," so when Hushaym was asked: "he turned away?" He said: Yes, but I did not hear it (2). The Second: The Hadith of Mihjan al-Dili (may Allah be pleased with him): "If you do so, pray with them and make it voluntary" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Neither Abu Nu'aym nor Abd al-Rahman said: "and make it voluntary" (4).

He said: When he finished his prayer, he turned away and found two men at the back of the people who had not prayed with him. He said: "Bring them to me." So they were brought with their shoulders trembling. He said: "What prevented you two from praying with us?" They said: O Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), we had already prayed in our dwellings. He said: "Do not do that."

He said to me: "Did you not pray?" He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have already prayed in the dwelling then came to you. He said: "If you do so, pray with them and make it voluntary."

text: 262 - What has been narrated regarding catching the Morning prayer by catching a Rak'ah of it. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "If one of you prays a Rak'ah of the Morning prayer then the sun rises, let him pray another to it" (1). Imam Ahmad said: When asked about Azrah, he said: This is not Azrah who narrated from Al-Sha'bi and Sa'id bin Jubayr; this is Azrah bin Tamim. Meaning another man (2). And he said once: Azrah bin Tamim, Qatadah narrated from him from Abu Hurayrah; I do not know of anyone other than Qatadah who narrated from him (3). 263 - What has been narrated regarding action in prayer. The Hadith: "If your father calls you while you are in prayer, answer him" (4). Imam Ahmad said: Weak (5).

2. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (2031).
3. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (5311).

I also found it in "Ilal al-Daraqutni" in the manuscript part from the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah, and Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it in "Al-Musannaf" 2/191 from the path of Muhammad bin al-Munkadir, from the Prophet (peace be upon him).

text: Chapter of Prostration of Recitation. 264 - What has been narrated regarding prostration in Surah An-Najm. The Hadith of Abu Darda (may Allah be pleased with him): That he prostrated with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) eleven prostrations, among them An-Najm (1). Imam Ahmad said: Sa'id bin Abi Hilal, I do not know what his Hadith is; he mixes up Hadiths. Then he said: He also narrates from Abu Darda regarding prostration. It was said to him: The Hadith of An-Najm? He said: Yes (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 5/194, who said: Surayj bin al-Nu'man told us, Ibn Wahb told us, from Umar bin al-Harith, from Sa'id bin Abi Hilal, from Amr al-Dimashqi, from Umm al-Darda who said: Abu Darda told me... and he mentioned it.
2. "Min Su'alat Abi Bakr al-Athram lil-Imam Ahmad" (64). I say: As for the prostration of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in An-Najm, it is established; Al-Bukhari narrated it (4862) from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) prostrated in An-Najm, and the Muslims, the polytheists, the jinn, and mankind prostrated with him.

text: Chapters on Prostration of Forgetfulness (Sahu). 265 - What has been narrated regarding prostration of forgetfulness. The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him): "If one of you doubts in his prayer and does not know how much he has prayed, three or four, let him cast aside the doubt" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Its connection (Wasl) is authentic. And he said: I adopt it. It was said to him: They differ regarding its chain. He said: Malik fell short in it (2), and several have connected it, and he mentioned among them: Ibn Ajlan and Abd al-Aziz bin Abi Salamah (3). And he said once: Muhammad bin Ajlan, Al-Majishun, and Sulayman bin Bilal connect it. And there was something in the circle of Zaid bin Aslam, so sometimes he would connect it for them, and sometimes he would fall short (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (571), who said: Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Abi Khalaf told us, Musa bin Dawud told us, Sulayman bin Bilal told us, from Zaid bin Aslam, from Ata bin Yasar, from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If one of you doubts in his prayer and does not know how much he has prayed? Three or four? Let him cast aside the doubt and build upon what he is certain of, then prostrate two prostrations before he says Taslim. If he prayed five, his prayer will be an intercessor for him, and if he prayed completing four, they will be a humiliation for Satan."
2. Narrated by Malik in "Al-Muwatta" number (61) from Zaid bin Aslam, from Ata bin Yasar that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: ... The Hadith.
3. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/505, "Al-Tamhid" 5/25.
4. "Masa'il Salih" (989). I say: Al-Daraqutni and Ibn Abd al-Barr in "Al-Tamhid" authenticated its connection. Al-Hafiz reported the disagreement in "Al-Talkhis," and Ibn Rajab said: Perhaps Al-Bukhari left its extraction due to Malik and Al-Thawri narrating it as Mursal.

text: 266 - What has been narrated regarding seeking correctness if one doubts in prayer. The Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): "If one of you doubts in his prayer, let him seek correctness" (1). Imam Ahmad said, as Al-Athram narrated from him: The Hadith of seeking correctness is only narrated by Mansur. I said to him: Only Mansur narrates it? He said: No, all of them say: The Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed five. He said: Except that Shu'bah narrated from Al-Hakam, from Abu Wa'il, from Abdullah as Mawquf (stopped) similar to it: He said: If one of you doubts, let him seek correctness (2). And he said once: The Hadith of certainty is more authentic in narration than seeking correctness. And he said regarding the Hadith of seeking correctness: It is authentic, narrated from more than one path (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (401), Muslim (572) both via the path of Jarir, from Mansur, from Ibrahim, from Alqamah who said: Abdullah said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed—Ibrahim said: I do not know if he added or decreased—so when he said Taslim, it was said: O Messenger of Allah, has something new happened in the prayer? He said: "And what is that?" They said: You prayed such and such. So he bent his legs and faced the Qiblah and prostrated two prostrations then said Taslim. When he turned his face to us, he said: "If something new had happened in the prayer, I would have informed you, but I am only a human like you, I forget as you forget. So if I forget, remind me. And if one of you doubts in his prayer, let him seek correctness, complete upon it, then say Taslim, then prostrate two prostrations."
2. "Al-Tamhid" by Ibn Abd al-Barr 5/37, 38 - "Fath al-Bari" 6/508, 509.
3. "Fath al-Bari" 6/509. Issue: Ibn Abd al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" 5/35-36: Jurists differed regarding the one who doubts in his prayer and does not know whether he prayed one, two, three, or four. Malik and Al-Shafi'i said: He builds on certainty and seeking correctness does not suffice him. Similar was narrated from Al-Thawri, and Dawud said it

text: 267 - What has been narrated regarding if one doubts how much he prayed. Contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Mu'awiyah bin Hudayj (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed one day and said Taslim while a Rak'ah remained of the prayer. A man caught up with him and said: You forgot a Rak'ah from the prayer. So he returned and entered the mosque (1). Imam Ahmad denied that Mu'awiyah bin Hudayj had companionship (Sahbah) (2). The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): regarding the story of Dhul-Yadayn: And in it... Did you forget or was the prayer shortened? He said: "I did not forget, and the prayer was not shortened" (3).
foot_note:
1. = and Al-Tabari. Abu Hanifah said: If that is the first time he doubts, he restarts and does not seek correctness, but if he encounters that more than once, he seeks correctness. Ahmad bin Hanbal said: Doubt is of two types: Certainty, and seeking correctness. Whoever returns to certainty casts aside doubt and prostrates the two prostrations of forgetfulness before Taslim based on the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. And if he returns to seeking correctness—which is mostly delusion—he prostrates the two prostrations of forgetfulness after Taslim based on the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud which Mansur narrates. Abu Khaythamah Zuhair bin Harb said the same. He said: And the Hadith of Abd al-Rahman bin Awf only contains building on certainty, and there is a difference between building on certainty and seeking correctness; because seeking correctness is to seek the most correct of that and the most likely to him, while building on certainty cancels doubt entirely and builds on his certainty.
1. Narrated by Abu Dawud (1023), who said: Qutaibah bin Sa'id told us, Al-Layth bin Sa'id told us, from Yazid bin Abi Habib, that Suwayd bin Qais informed him, from Mu'awiyah bin Hudayj that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed one day and a Rak'ah remained of the prayer. A man caught up with him and said: You forgot a Rak'ah from the prayer. So he returned and entered the mosque and ordered Bilal so he established the prayer, and he prayed a Rak'ah for the people. I informed the people of that, so they said to me: Do you know the man? I said: No, unless I see him. So he passed by me and I said: This is him. They said: This is Talhah bin Ubaidullah.
2. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/472 - and also 3/461.
3. Narrated by Abu Dawud (1017), who said: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Thabit told us, Abu Usamah told us, =

text: Chapters on Tahajjud. 268 - What has been narrated regarding the Prophet's encouragement (peace be upon him) of night prayer. The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): Stick to night prayer; for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used not to leave it. If he was sick, he recited while sitting. And I know that one of you says: It is enough for me to establish what was prescribed for me. And how can that be for him (1). Imam Ahmad said: Yazid bin Khumayr is Salih al-Hadith (good in Hadith), and Abdullah bin Abi Musa is a mistake; Shu'bah erred in it. He is Abdullah bin Abi Qais (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Musnad Ahmad" 6/125, who said: Muhammad bin Ja'far told us, he said: Shu'bah told us, from Yazid bin Khumayr who said: I heard Abdullah bin Abi Musa say: Mudrik—or Ibn Mudrik—sent me to Aisha to ask her about things. He said: So I came to her and found her praying Duha. I said: I will sit until she finishes. They said: Far from it. So I said to her doorkeeper: How do I ask permission to enter upon her? He said say: Peace be upon you and the mercy of Allah and His blessings, peace be upon us and upon the righteous servants of Allah, peace be upon the Mothers of the Believers—or the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him)—peace be upon you. He said: So I entered upon her and asked her, and she said: Brother of Azib, yes, the people of the house. So I asked her about Wisal (fasting continuously), and she said: When it was the day of Uhud, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) continued fasting... The Hadith.
2. "Ilal Ahmad" narration of Abdullah (3659), (3660), "Musnad Ahmad" 6/125.

text: 269 - What has been narrated regarding Satan's knots if one sleeps at night. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Over the son of Adam are three knots with magic if he sleeps at night. If he wakes up at night and remembers Allah Almighty, a knot is undone. If he performs ablution, a knot is undone" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Ismail told us from Yunus and did not elevate it (2). 270 - What has been narrated regarding supplication in night prayer and standing. Contains three Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): That he slept at the Messenger of Allah's (peace be upon him) [house], so he woke up, used the Siwak, and performed ablution while saying: {Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding} [Al Imran: 190] The Hadith. Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Al-A'mash (3), from Habib, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to, when he stood at night, pray two Rak'ahs then use the Siwak, is a Wahm (error) from Al-A'mash. The Hadith is the Hadith of Husayn bin Abd
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 2/497, who said: Hashim bin al-Qasim told us, Al-Mubarak told me, from Al-Hasan, from Abu Hurayrah, elevated [to the Prophet].
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 2/497. I say: The text is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari narrated it (1142) from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) similarly.
3. Narrated by Ibn Majah (288), who said: Sufyan bin Waki' told us, Atham bin Ali told us, from Al-A'mash, from Habib bin Abi Thabit, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas elevated [to the Prophet].

Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (3423), who said: Al-Hasan bin Ali al-Khallal told us, Sulayman bin Dawud al-Hashimi told us, Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Zinad told us, from Musa bin Uqbah, from Abdullah bin al-Fadl, from Abd al-Rahman al-A'raj, from Ubaidullah bin Abi Rafi', from Ali bin Abi Talib, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): That he used to, when he stood for the prescribed prayer, raise his hands parallel to his shoulders, and do that also when he finished his recitation and wanted to bow, and do it when he raised his head from bowing, and not raise his hands in any part of his prayer while sitting, and when he rose from two prostrations he raised his hands likewise and said Takbir. And he says when he opens the prayer after Takbir: "I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of the associators. Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds. No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am of the Muslims. O Allah, You are the King, there is no god except You. Glory be to You, You are my Lord and I am Your servant. I have wronged myself and admitted my sin, so forgive me all my sins; indeed, no one forgives sins except You. And guide me to the best of morals; no one guides to the best of them except You. And turn away from me the evil of them; no one turns away from me the evil of them except You. Here I am and at Your service; I am by You and to You. There is no refuge or shelter from You except to You. I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You." Then he recites. When he bows, his speech in his bowing is to say: "O Allah, to You I have bowed, in You I have believed, and to You I have submitted. You are my Lord. My hearing, my sight, my brain, and my bones have humbled themselves to Allah, Lord of the worlds." When he raises his head from bowing he says: "Allah hears those who praise Him," then follows it with: "O Allah, our Lord, and to You is praise, filling the heavens and the earth, and filling whatever else You will." And when he prostrates he says in his prostration: "O Allah, to You I have prostrated, in You I have believed, and to You I have submitted. You are my Lord. My face has prostrated to the One who created it and opened its hearing and sight. Blessed is Allah, the Best =

text: Chapters on Witr 271 - What has been related regarding the Witr prayer before the morning (Subh). There are three paths for Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: The First Path: From Abdullah bin Shaqiq from him: "Hasten the morning by Witr" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Asim did not narrate anything from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, nor did Ibn Abi Za'idah narrate it, and I do not know (2). The Second Path: From Sulaiman bin Musa from Nafi' from him: "If dawn rises, all night prayer is gone, and the Witr; so perform Witr before the rising of dawn" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Jurayj did not hear it from Sulaiman bin Musa; he only said: Sulaiman said. It was said to him: But Abd al-Razzaq said from Ibn Jurayj: Sulaiman informed us?
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (750), he said: Narrated to us Harun bin Ma'ruf, Surayj bin Yunus, and Abu Kurayb, all of them from Ibn Abi Za'idah. Harun said: Narrated to us Ibn Abi Za'idah, informed me Asim Al-Ahwal, from Abdullah bin Shaqiq, from Ibn Umar that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... the Hadith. 
2. "Jami' al-Tahsil" p. 203, "Fath al-Bari" 6/237, "Marasil Ibn Abi Hatim" p. 153, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 3/33. I say: The text has a authentic supporting evidence; Muslim (749) narrated it via Abdullah bin Shaqiq, from Ibn Umar that a man asked the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while I was between him and the inquirer, saying: O Messenger of Allah, how is the night prayer? He said: "Two by two, then if you fear the morning, pray one Rak'ah, and make the last of your prayer Witr." 
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (469), he said: Narrated to us Mahmud bin Ghaylan, narrated to us Abd al-Razzaq, informed us Ibn Jurayj, from Sulaiman bin Musa, from Nafi', from Ibn Umar, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... the Hadith.

text: So he denied it and said: We wrote from the books of Abd al-Razzaq, and it was not in them, and these people wrote from him later on (1). The Third Path: From Ubaydullah from Nafi' from him: "Hasten the morning by Witr" (2). Imam Ahmad said: I see this as him abbreviating the Hadith: "Night prayer is two by two, so if you fear the morning, then perform Witr with one." And it has the same meaning. I said to him: Did anyone else narrate it? He said: No (3). 272 - What has been related regarding the one who does not perform Witr. Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever does not perform Witr is not one of us" (4). Imam Ahmad said: Muawiyah bin Qurrah did not hear anything from Abu Hurairah nor did he meet him (5).

I say: The text has a authentic supporting evidence in "Sahih Muslim" (754) via Abu Nadrah Al-Awqi that Abu Sa'id informed them that they asked the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, about Witr? He said: "Perform Witr before the morning."

Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: "Three are obligatory upon me and they are voluntary for you: Witr, the Sacrifice (Nahr), and the Duha prayer" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Weak (2). 274 - Witr for the one who recites the Quran. text: Chapters on Qunut 280 - What has been related regarding Qunut before bowing (Ruku'). Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: Regarding Qunut before bowing (1). Al-Athram said: I said to Abu Abdullah - meaning: Ahmad bin Hanbal -: Does anyone say regarding the Hadith of Anas: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, performed Qunut before bowing, other than Asim Al-Ahwal? He said: I do not know of anyone saying it other than him. Abu Abdullah said: Asim contradicted all of them; Hisham from Qatadah from Anas, and Al-Taimi from Abu Mijlaz from Anas from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: He performed Qunut after bowing; and Ayyub from Muhammad bin Sirin said: I asked Anas; and Hanzalah Al-Sadusi from Anas, four perspectives. As for Asim, he said: I said to him? So he said: They lied, he only performed Qunut after bowing for a month. It was said to him: Who mentioned it from Asim? He said: Abu Muawiyah and others.
foot_note:
1. = Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr, from his father, that Abdullah bin Qays bin Makhramah informed him, from Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani... the Hadith. And likewise Muslim (765) narrated it mentioning his father as well. 
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1002), and Muslim (677). Al-Bukhari said: Narrated to us Musaddad, he said: Narrated to us Abd al-Wahid, he said: Narrated to us Asim. And in Muslim he said: Narrated to us Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah and Abu Kurayb, they said: Narrated to us Abu Muawiyah, from Asim, he said: I asked Anas bin Malik about Qunut, so he said: There was Qunut. I said: Before bowing or after it? He said: Before it. He said: But so-and-so informed me from you that you said: After bowing? So he said: He lied, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, only performed Qunut after bowing for a month, I believe he had sent a group called the Reciters (Al-Qurra'), about seventy men, to a people of the polytheists other than those, and there was a covenant between them and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, performed Qunut for a month invoking against them.

text: It was said to Abu Abdullah: And the rest of the Hadiths, aren't they only stating after bowing? He said: Yes, all of them from Khaffaf bin Ima' bin Rakhsah and Abu Hurairah. I said to Abu Abdullah: Then why did you permit Qunut before bowing, when the Hadith is established as after bowing? He said: Qunut in Fajr is after bowing, and in Witr one chooses after bowing, but whoever performs Qunut before bowing, there is no harm; due to the action of the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and their difference (of opinion), but as for Fajr, it is after bowing (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) "Zad al-Ma'ad" 1/281-282, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 1/247, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/276, "Al-Tanqih" by Al-Dhahabi 3/341-342. I say: And this Hadith, a group of scholars have spoken about it. Ibn Rajab said in "Al-Fath" 6/275 after mentioning the differences upon Asim regarding the place of Qunut, he said: The narration of Asim from Anas regarding the place of Qunut and the implication of its permanence is confused [Mudtarib] and contradictory, and Asim himself was spoken about by Al-Qattan, and he used to consider him weak and did not narrate from him, and he said: He was not a Hafiz (preserver), so the narration of Asim from Anas, with its confusion, is not judged over the narrations of the companions of Anas; rather the matter is the opposite. And he quoted Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in the book "Al-Qunut" saying: As for the Hadith of Asim Al-Ahwal from Anas, he was alone in his narration and the entirety of the companions of Anas contradicted him, so they narrated from him Qunut after bowing, and the judgment is for the group over the single individual. I say: Ibn al-Qayyim defended the authenticity of this Hadith in "Zad al-Ma'ad" 1/282. And Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/569: Regarding reconciling between the Hadith of Anas mentioned previously and the Hadith of Anas in the Book of Maghazi with the wording: A man asked Anas about Qunut: Is it after bowing or upon finishing the recitation? He said: Rather, upon finishing the recitation. He said: And the sum of what came from Anas regarding that is that Qunut for a specific need (Nazilah) is after bowing, there is no disagreement from him regarding that, and as for other than a need, the correct view from him is before bowing, and there has been difference regarding that, and it appears that it is of the permissible difference.

text: 281 - What has been related regarding Qunut in Witr. Hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to perform Witr and perform Qunut before bowing (1). Imam Ahmad said: Nothing is authenticated [Sahih] from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding Qunut of Witr being before or after, but Umar would perform Qunut from year to year (2). And he said once: I choose Qunut to be after bowing, surely everything established from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding Qunut is only in Fajr when he raised his head from bowing, and the Qunut of Witr I choose it to be after bowing (3). 282 - What has been related regarding Qunut in Fajr and Maghrib. Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to perform Qunut in the Morning (Subh) and Maghrib (4). Imam Ahmad said: It is not mentioned that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, performed Qunut in Maghrib except in this Hadith (5).

Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: So he said Takbir then recited until when he finished he said Takbir and bowed, then he raised his head and supplicated a long supplication (1). Imam Ahmad said: When he was asked about Hanzalah Al-Sadusi, he said: Hanzalah - and he stretched his voice with it. Then he said: That one is Denounced in Hadith [Munkar al-Hadith], he narrates wonders; he narrated from Anas, then he mentioned this Hadith of Qunut and others (2). And he said once: This is a denounced [Munkar] Hadith (3).

text: Chapters on Travel 284 - What has been related regarding the travel of a woman. There are two Hadiths in it: First: From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "A woman does not travel for three days except with a Mahram (male guardian)" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Al-Umari Al-Saghir - meaning Abdullah bin Umar - narrated it and did not raise it (to the Prophet). Imam Ahmad said: Yahya Al-Qattan said I looked into the book of Ubayd - meaning: Ibn Umar - and I did not find anything in it that I disapprove of except the Hadith 'A woman does not travel for three' (2). And he said once: He did not hear it except from Ubaydullah - meaning: Yahya bin Sa'id - so when it reached him from Al-Umari he authenticated it (3). Second: Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: Like it (4). Imam Ahmad said: This is an error, it is only the Hadith of Abu Salih, from Abu
foot_note:

text: Sa'id (1), Al-A'mash narrates it from him (2). 285 - What has been related regarding shortening (Qasr) the prayer in travel. Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: I prayed with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at Mina two Rak'ahs, and Abu Bakr, and Umar, and Uthman for a beginning part of his leadership, then he completed it (3). Imam Ahmad said: Denounced [Munkar], and he denied it severely. And he said: This is from the side of Yahya bin Sulaim (4).

And Abdullah said: If I were to pray before it or after it, I would have completed it.

I say: The text is established; Al-Bukhari (1082) narrated it, he said: Narrated to us Musaddad, he said: Narrated to us Yahya, from Ubaydullah, he said: Informed me Nafi', from Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I prayed with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at Mina two Rak'ahs, and Abu Bakr and Umar, and with Uthman for a beginning part of his leadership then he completed it. And Al-Bukhari also narrated it (1101) from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, he said: I accompanied the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and I did not see him perform voluntary prayers (Tasbih) in travel, and Allah, Majestic is His Mention, said: {There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern} [Al-Ahzab: 21].

text: 286 - What has been related regarding the prohibition of shortening in travel. Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "Three do not shorten in prayer: The merchant in his horizon (business travel), the woman visiting her family, and the shepherd" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Al-Hakam bin Abdullah, all his Hadiths are fabricated [Mawdu'] (2). 287 - Whoever leaves shortening in travel not out of dislike for the Sunnah. In it are two paths from Aisha: First: From Ata' from her: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to shorten in travel and complete (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is a denounced [Munkar] Hadith (4). And he said once: People narrate it from Ata' as Mursal (5). And he said once: People narrate it from Ata' from another man, it is not from

text: 288 - Combining prayers without fear nor travel. Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed eight together and seven together without fear nor travel (1). Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Abbas has affirmed this or authenticated it, and others say: Ibn Umar (2) and Mu'adh (3) and more than one say: It is in travel. So it was said to him: Should a person do it? He said: He only did it so as not to burden his Ummah (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (705), he said: Narrated to us Yahya bin Yahya, he said: I read to Malik, from Abu Al-Zubayr, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed... the Hadith. 
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1106) from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to combine between Maghrib and Isha when the journey became urgent for him. 
3. Narrated by Muslim (706) from the Hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, combined in the campaign of Tabuk between Dhuhr and Asr and between Maghrib and Isha. He said: So I said: What carried him to do that? He said: He wanted not to burden his Ummah. 
4. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/95. Issue: The approaches of scholars have differed regarding this Hadith of Ibn Abbas on combining without fear nor travel, and they have multiple approaches regarding it. The First Approach: That it is abrogated by the consensus on the contrary, and Al-Tirmidhi narrated at the end of his book that no one of the scholars held this view, and these people do not say: That consensus abrogates as narrated from some of them, rather they say: It indicates the existence of an abrogating text. The Second Approach: Contradicting it with what opposes it, and Imam Ahmad opposed it with the Hadiths of the timings and his saying: "The time is what is between these two" and with the Hadith of Abu Dharr regarding the leaders who delay the prayer from its time and his command to pray in the time, and if combining were permissible without an excuse he would not have needed =

text: 289 - Combining between two prayers without fear nor rain. Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, combined between Dhuhr and Asr and Maghrib and Isha in Madinah without fear nor rain. He said: So it was said to Ibn Abbas: Why did he do that? He said: He wanted expansion (ease) for his Ummah (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is only the Hadith of Dawud bin Qays (2), it is not from the Hadith of Ibn Abi Dhi'b (3).
foot_note:
1. = to that, and with the Hadith: "There is no negligence in sleep, rather negligence is on the one who does not pray the prayer until the time of the other prayer comes." The Third Approach: Interpreting it that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed Dhuhr to the end of its time, so it fell in the last part of the time and he advanced Asr to the beginning of its time so he prayed it in the first part of the time, so the two prayers occurred combined in form but in meaning, every prayer occurred in its time, and he did this to show the permissibility of delaying the prayer to the end of its time. The Fourth Approach: That this was combining between two prayers due to rain, and this is what Ayyub Al-Sakhtiyani interpreted it as, as in Al-Bukhari, and it is what Malik also interpreted it as, and whoever went to this approach then he challenges the narration of those who narrated: "without fear nor rain" as Al-Bazzar and Ibn Abd al-Barr and others said. 
1. Narrated by Abu Dawood as a comment following Hadith (1214): via Amr bin Dinar, from Jabir bin Zaid, from Ibn Abbas... the Hadith. Then Abu Dawood said: And Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah narrated it, from Ibn Abbas. He said: In other than rain. And Abdullah bin Ahmad said in his "Ilal": Waki' narrated it, from Ibn Abi Dhi'b, from Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah, from Ibn Abbas raised (to the Prophet). 
2. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/344, he said: Narrated to us Waki', he said: Narrated to us Dawud bin Qays Al-Farra', from Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah, from Ibn Abbas, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
3. "Al-'Ilal" by Abdullah (1453).

text: 290 - Permissibility of combining Dhuhr and Asr due to rain. The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): That the Prophet (peace be upon him) combined Dhuhr and Asr in Medina due to rain (1). Imam Ahmad said: I have not heard it (2). 291 - The traveler shortens prayer as long as he does not intend a stay. The Hadith of Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him): I raided with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and witnessed the Conquest with him, so he stayed in Mecca for eighteen nights praying only two rak'ahs (3). Imam Ahmad said: This has no basis; he only intended to go out to Hunayn and did not intend Hajj (4). And Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he stayed for ten [days] (5), and the Hadith of Ibn Abbas is also concerning this.
foot_note:
1. (1) Ibn Abd al-Hadi mentioned it in "Al-Tanqih" 1/62 via the path of Yahya bin Wadih, from Musa bin Uqbah, from Ibn Umar, raised [to the Prophet].
2. "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd al-Hadi 1/63, "Al-Mughni" 2/58.
3. Narrated by Abu Dawud (1229), he said: Musa bin Isma'il told us, Hammad told us (H), and Ibrahim bin Musa told us, Ibn Ulayyah informed us—and this is his wording: Ali bin Zaid informed us, from Abu Nadrah, from Imran bin Husain who said: I raided with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and witnessed the Conquest with him, so he stayed in Mecca for eighteen nights praying only two rak'ahs and saying: "O people of the land, pray four, for we are a traveling people." Al-Bayhaqi added 3/153: And he raided Ta'if and Hunayn and prayed two rak'ahs.

text: Chapters on Voluntary Prayers. 292 - What has been narrated regarding the Duha (Forenoon) prayer. The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): He used to pray Duha four rak'ahs and add whatever Allah willed (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is Munkar (denounced). He said that what is authentic from Aisha is that she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) never prayed the Duha prayer (2). He said once: It is weak (3). 293 - What has been narrated regarding the ease in omitting it. The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): I never saw the Prophet (peace be upon him) pray Duha at all (4). Imam Ahmad said: We only heard it from Waki', and its chain is good (Jayyid) (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (719), he said: Shaiban bin Farrukh told us, Abd al-Warith told us, Yazid al-Rishk told us, Mu'adhah told me that she asked Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): How many did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) use to pray for Duha? She said: Four rak'ahs and he would add whatever Allah willed.
2. "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab 412. I say: The authentic Hadith indicated by Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, was narrated by Al-Bukhari (1128) and Muslim (718) from the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) pray the Duha prayer, but I establish it.
3. "Al-Nasikh wa al-Mansukh" by Al-Athram 97.
4. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i in "Al-Kubra" 1/180, he said: Mahmud bin Ghailan informed us, from Waki', from Sufyan, from Asim bin Kulaib, from his father, from Abu Hurairah, raised [to the Prophet].
5. "Bada'i' al-Fawa'id" by Ibn al-Qayyim 4/114.

text: 294 - Salat al-Tasabih (Prayer of Glorification) (1). The Hadith of Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib: "O Abbas, O my uncle. Shall I not give you? Shall I not grant you? Shall I not present to you?" Imam Ahmad said: The Prayer of Tasabih is not established according to me, and they have differed regarding its chain; it is not established according to me. It is as if he weakened Amr bin Malik al-Nukri (2). He said once: It does not impress me. It was said to him: Why? He said: There is nothing in it that is authentic. And he shook his hand as if rejecting it (3). He said once: It is weak (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) The Hadith has several paths, the most famous being the path of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him). Narrated by Abu Dawud (1297), he said: Abd al-Rahman bin Bishr bin al-Hakam al-Naysaburi told us, Musa bin Abd al-Aziz told us, al-Hakam bin Aban told us, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib: "O Abbas, O my uncle, shall I not give you? Shall I not grant you? Shall I not present to you? Shall I not do ten things for you? If you do that, Allah will forgive you your sin: the first and the last of it, the old and the new of it, the mistake and the deliberate of it, the small and the large of it, the secret and the public of it. Ten qualities: You pray four rak'ahs, reading in every rak'ah the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatiha) and a Surah. When you finish reading in the first rak'ah while standing, you say: 'Subhan Allah, wal-Hamdu Lillah, wa la ilaha illa Allah, wallahu Akbar' fifteen times. Then you bow and say it while bowing ten times. Then you raise your head from bowing and say it ten times. Then you go down in prostration and say it while prostrating ten times. Then you raise your head from prostration and say it ten times. Then you prostrate and say it ten times. Then you raise your head and say it ten times. That is seventy-five in every rak'ah. You do that in four rak'ahs. If you are able to pray it once every day, then do so. If you do not do so, then once every Friday. If you do not do so, then once every month. If you do not do so, then once every year. If you do not do so, then once in your lifetime."
2. "Masa'il al-Imam Ahmad" narration of Abdullah (315), "Masa'il al-Kawsaj" (3309).
3. "Al-Mughni" 1/768.
4. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (520), "Al-Fatawa" by Ibn Taymiyyah 11/579, "Bada'i' al-Fawa'id" 4/114.

text: He said once: It has no basis; I do not like for one to pray it, let him pray something else (1). 295 - Salat al-Istikhara (Prayer of Guidance). It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "If one of you is concerned about a matter, let him kneel two rak'ahs other than the obligatory prayer, then let him say: O Allah, I seek Your counsel through Your knowledge..." (2). Imam Ahmad said: It is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith. He said: No one narrates it except Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Mawal, and there is no harm in him. The people of Medina, if a Hadith is erroneous, say: Ibn al-Munkadir from Jabir. And the people of Basra say: Thabit from Anas; they attribute it [the mistake] to them (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Bada'i' al-Fawa'id" 4/114.
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1166), he said: Qutaibah told us, he said: Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Mawali told us, from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir, from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to teach us Istikhara in all matters as he would teach us a Surah from the Quran, saying: "If one of you is concerned about a matter, let him kneel two rak'ahs other than the obligatory prayer, then let him say: O Allah, I seek Your counsel through Your knowledge, and I seek Your assistance through Your power, and I ask You from Your immense favor, for You are capable and I am not, and You know and I do not, and You are the Knower of the Unseen. O Allah, if You know that this matter is good for me in my religion, my livelihood, and the outcome of my affair—or he said: my immediate and future affair—then ordain it for me and facilitate it for me, then bless it for me. And if You know that this matter is bad for me in my religion, my livelihood, and the outcome of my affair—or he said: my immediate and future affair—then turn it away from me and turn me away from it, and ordain for me the good wherever it may be, then make me content with it." He said: "And he names his need."
3. "Al-Kamil" by Ibn Adi 4/307-308, "Bahr al-Dam" (614), "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 3/427.

text: And he said once: When asked about Ibn Abi al-Mawal, he said: He narrates a Hadith that no one else narrates—meaning the Hadith of Istikhara—from Jabir, and he used to weaken it (1). The Second: The Hadith of Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to say when he wanted a matter: "O Allah, choose for me and select for me" (2). Imam Ahmad said: It contains Zanfal, I do not know him (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Harb" p. (473).
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (3516), he said: Muhammad bin Bashar told us, Ibrahim bin Umar bin Abi al-Wazir told us, Zanfal bin Abdullah Abu Abdullah told us, from Ibn Abi Mulaikah, from Aisha, from Abu Bakr al-Siddiq that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to say when he wanted a matter: "O Allah, choose for me and select for me."
3. "Su'alat Abi Dawud li-Ahmad" (236). I say: The text has a correct witness (Shahid) in "Sahih Muslim" without this length from the Hadith of Anas who said: When Zaid's waiting period (iddah) ended, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to Zaid: "Mention her to me." He said: So Zaid went until he came to her while she was fermenting her dough. He said: When I saw her, she seemed great in my chest, so much that I could not look at her because the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) had mentioned her. So I turned my back to her and retreated on my heels and said: O Zainab, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent [me] to mention you. She said: I am not doing anything until I consult my Lord. So she stood to her place of prayer and the Quran was revealed... The Hadith.

text: 296 - Salat al-Kusuf (Eclipse Prayer). It contains four Hadiths: First: The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed six rak'ahs and four prostrations (1). Second: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both), he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed when the sun eclipsed eight rak'ahs in four prostrations, and similarly from Ali (2). Third: The Hadith of Al-Nu'man bin Bashir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed in an eclipse similar to your prayer, bowing and prostrating (3). Imam Ahmad said: All these forms are not correct, and I consider it an error (4). He said once: There is much difference in it (5). He said once: The reports narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) regarding the Eclipse Prayer are all Hassan (good), and whichever the people act upon is permissible for them, except that the choice among them is for this Hadith of Ibn Abbas and what is similar to it (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (901), he said: Abu Ghassan al-Misma'i and Muhammad bin al-Muthanna told us, they said: Mu'adh—meaning Ibn Hisham—told us, my father told me, from Qatadah, from Ata bin Abi Rabah, from Ubaid bin Umair, from Aisha that the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him)... The Hadith.
2. Narrated by Muslim (908), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah told us, Isma'il bin Ulayyah told us, from Sufyan, from Habib, from Tawus, from Ibn Abbas, raised [to the Prophet].
3. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/352, he said: Waki' told us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Asim, from Abu Qilabah, from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, raised [to the Prophet].

5. "Masa'il Ishaq bin Mansur al-Kawsaj" by Imam Ahmad 408.
6. Ibn Abd al-Barr in "Al-Tamhid" 3/314.

text: And he said once regarding the Hadith of Ibn Abbas: Waki' used to say: Six rak'ahs in four prostrations. I said to him: Isma'il bin Ulayyah and Yahya bin Sa'id said: Eight rak'ahs in four prostrations. So when it was after that, he returned to [saying] eight (1). Fourth: The Hadith of Jabir: He prayed six rak'ahs in four prostrations (2). Imam Ahmad said: Abd al-Malik bin Juraij contradicted [others] regarding Ata; he said: from Ubaid bin Umair, he said: Tell me who I should believe, meaning Aisha (3). Then he said: Qatadah narrated it from Ata from Ubaid bin Umair from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). Then he said: I judge for Ibn Juraij over Abd al-Malik regarding the Hadith of Ata (4).
foot_note:
1. = I say: Among those who also weakened these Hadiths are: Al-Bukhari, Al-Shafi'i, and Ibn Abd al-Barr. What is agreed upon by the Imams is four rak'ahs in four prostrations, which is what Al-Bukhari (1044) and Muslim (901) narrated from the path of Malik from Hisham bin Urwah, from his father, from Aisha that she said: The sun eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed with the people. He stood and prolonged the standing, then he bowed and prolonged the bowing, then he stood and prolonged the standing, which was less than the first standing, then he bowed and prolonged the bowing, which was less than the first bowing, then he prostrated and prolonged the prostration. Then he did in the second rak'ah similar to what he did in the first. Then he finished and the sun had cleared. So he addressed the people, praised Allah and extolled Him, then said: "Indeed the sun and the moon are two signs of Allah..." The Hadith.
1. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (633), "Su'alat Abu Dawud" (4).
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud (117), he said: Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, Yahya told us, from Abd al-Malik, Ata told me, from Jabir who said: The sun eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and that was on the day Ibrahim died... The Hadith. And in it: Six rak'ahs in four prostrations.
3. Narrated by Muslim (901) and it has been discussed in the previous Hadith.
4. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah (5123), "Sunan Al-Bayhaqi" 3/328, "Mukhtasar Khilafiyat Al-Bayhaqi" 2/382.

text: 297 - Salat al-Khauf (Prayer of Fear). It contains three Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Sahl bin Abi Hathmah (may Allah be pleased with him): "The Imam stands facing the Qiblah and a group of them are with him, and a group are facing the enemy with their faces towards the enemy. So he prays one rak'ah with those who are with him." Imam Ahmad said: Abd al-Rahman (1) raised it [to the Prophet] and Yahya (2) did not raise it. Then he said: Abd al-Rahman is sufficient for you; he is trustworthy, trustworthy (Thiqa Thiqa). It was said to him: Did anyone other than Shu'bah narrate it from Abd al-Rahman? He said: I do not know. Then he said: Yazid bin Ruman (3) has narrated it from Salih bin Khawwat, from the one who prayed with the Prophet (peace be upon him), so this one strengthens that one (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (4131), he said: Musaddad told us, Yahya told us, from Shu'bah, from Abd al-Rahman bin al-Qasim, from his father, from Salih bin Khawwat, from Sahl bin Abi Hathmah, from the Prophet (peace be upon him).
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (4131), he said: Musaddad told us, Yahya bin Sa'id al-Qattan told us, from Yahya bin Sa'id al-Ansari, from Al-Qasim bin Muhammad, from Salih bin Khawwat, from Sahl bin Abi Hathmah who said: The Imam stands facing the Qiblah and a group of them are with him and a group are facing the enemy with their faces towards the enemy. So he prays with those who are with him one rak'ah; they stand and bow for themselves one rak'ah and prostrate two prostrations in their place. Then these go to the position of those, and those come, so he bows with them one rak'ah, so he has two, then they bow and prostrate two prostrations.
3. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (4129), he said: Qutaibah bin Sa'id told us, from Malik, from Yazid, from Salih bin Khawwat, from one who witnessed with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).
4. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/38-39. Al-Tirmidhi also pointed out in his "Jami'" 2/456 the difference regarding its raising and stopping.

text: The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): So the people lined up behind him in two rows: a row parallel to the enemy and a row behind him (1). Imam Ahmad said: Authentic. And he said once: One rak'ah and two rak'ahs have been narrated. Ibn Abbas says: One rak'ah, one rak'ah, except that for the Prophet (peace be upon him) it was two rak'ahs and for the people one rak'ah. And whatever is narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) are all authentic (2). He said once: I do not know that anything has been narrated regarding the Fear Prayer except established Hadith; they are all established (3). The Third: The Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) regarding the Fear Prayer (4). Imam Ahmad said: It is disputed regarding Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both). Malik bin Anas used to favor the Hadith of Sahl, and it is more similar to the verse {then let another group come who have not prayed} (1) [Al-Nisa: 102].

So he prayed with the row that was next to him one rak'ah, then these retreated to the position of those, and those [came] to the position of these, so he prayed with them another rak'ah.

4. Narrated by "Muslim" (840), he said: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Numair told us, my father told us, Abd al-Malik bin Abi Sulaiman told us, from Ata, from Jabir... The Hadith.

text: 298 - Reading aloud in Salat al-Istisqa (Rain Prayer). The Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding reading aloud in the Rain Prayer (2). Imam Ahmad said: I used to deny it until I saw the narration of Ma'mar (3) from Al-Zuhri as Ibn Abi Dhi'b said (4). Meaning: that he read aloud. 299 - What has been narrated regarding the supplication for rain. The Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both): "O Allah, give us rain that is relieving, satisfying, productive, beneficial not harmful, immediate not delayed" (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Ishaq bin Mansur al-Kawsaj" (406).
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1024), he said: Abu Nu'aym told us, Ibn Abi Dhi'b told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Abbad bin Tamim, from his uncle who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) went out to pray for rain, so he faced the Qiblah supplicating and turned his cloak inside out, then prayed two rak'ahs in which he read aloud.
3. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 4/39, he said: Abd al-Razzaq told us, he said: Ma'mar told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Abbad bin Tamim, from his uncle who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out... The Hadith.
4. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 6/286. I say: The methodology of Imam Ahmad is not to accept the solitary report of a trustworthy narrator unless there are indicators like corroboration etc., and it is the methodology of Yahya bin Sa'id and Abu Dawud and others if the trustworthy narrator is a Hafiz (preserver) even if he does not contradict. Issue: There is no difference among scholars who narrate the Rain Prayer that reading aloud is done in it, and most of them also hold that one reads in them what is read in the Eid prayers, which is the view of Al-Thawri, Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and Ahmad.

text: 300 - The virtue of praying on the night of the middle of Sha'ban. The Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): Whoever prays such and such has such and such, and whoever reads such and such has such and such (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is false (Batil) and fabricated (Mawdu'); I saw Ibn al-Jarrah and I saw with him Hadiths that were fabricated for him, and he did not know what Hadith was (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) I did not find it with this wording from the path of Muhammad bin al-Jarrah, but I found a narration agreeing with the chain of the Hadith and its meaning indicated by Imam Ahmad in "Al-Mawdu'at" by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/127, he said: Muhammad bin Nasir al-Hafiz informed us, Abu Ali al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin al-Hasan al-Haddad informed us, Abu Bakr Ahmad bin al-Fadl bin Muhammad al-Muqri informed us, Abu Amr Abd al-Rahman bin Talhah al-Talihi informed us, Al-Fadl bin Muhammad al-Za'farani informed us, Harun bin Sulaiman told us, Ali bin al-Hasan told us, from Sufyan al-Thawri, from Layth, from Mujahid, from Ali bin Abi Talib, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: "O Ali, whoever prays a hundred rak'ahs on the night of the middle [of Sha'ban], reading in every rak'ah the Opening of the Book and 'Say, He is Allah, One' ten times." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "O Ali, no servant prays these prayers except that Allah Almighty fulfills for him every need he requested that night." It was said: O Messenger of Allah, even if Allah had made him wretched (Shaqi), would He make him happy (Sa'id)? He said: "By the One in Whose hand is my soul, O Ali, indeed it is written in the Tablet that so-and-so son of so-and-so was created wretched, Allah Almighty erases it and makes him happy, and Allah sends to him seventy thousand angels writing good deeds for him and erasing bad deeds from him and raising degrees for him until the beginning of the year, and Allah Almighty sends into the Gardens of Eden seventy thousand angels"—or seven hundred thousand angels—"building cities and palaces for him and planting trees for him. No eye has seen, no ear has heard, and it has not occurred to the heart of mortals the likes of these gardens, in every garden is according to what I described to you of cities, palaces, and trees." The Hadith.
2. "Ilal Al-Marwazi" (271).

text: 301 - Prayer during Panic (Faza'). The Hadith of Suhaib (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to, when he prayed, whisper something we did not understand... And in it: And they used to flee (Yafza'un) to prayer if they were frightened (Fazi'u) (1). Imam Ahmad said: Affan told us, he said: Hammad bin Salamah told us, with this Hadith, exactly with this entire speech and with this chain, but he did not say in it: They used to flee to prayer if they were frightened (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 4/333, he said: Affan told us from his book, he said: Sulayman bin al-Mughirah told us, he said: Thabit told us, from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Laila, from Suhaib who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to, when he prayed, whisper something we did not understand and he did not tell us about it. He said: So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Did you notice me?" A speaker said: Yes. He said: "I remembered a Prophet from the Prophets who was given soldiers from his people, so he said: Who can match these? - or who can stand against these, or a word similar to this, Sulayman doubted what he said - So Allah revealed to him: Choose for your people between one of three: Either I set upon them an enemy from other than themselves, or hunger, or death. -He said- So he consulted his people regarding that, and they said: You are the Prophet of Allah, we entrust that to you, so choose for us. -He said:- So he stood to his prayer. -He said: And they used to flee to prayer if they were frightened. He said: So he prayed- He said: -As for an enemy from others, no; or hunger, no; but death.- He said: So death was set upon them for three days, and seventy thousand of them died. So my whispering which you see is that I say: O Allah, O Lord, by You I fight and by You I assault, and there is no power or strength except by Allah."
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 4/333.

text: Chapters on Making Up Missed Prayers. 302 - No prayer for the one who owes a prayer. The Hadith: "There is no prayer for the one who owes a prayer" (1). Ibrahim Al-Harbi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I asked Ahmad about it. He said: I do not know this wording at all. Ibrahim said: Nor have I heard this from the Prophet (peace be upon him) (2). 303 - Repeating the prayer for the one who owes a prayer. The Hadith of Abu Qatadah (may Allah be pleased with him): "You will travel your evening and your night." "And in it: Negligence is only upon the one who does not pray the prayer until the time of the other prayer comes. So whoever does that, let him pray it when he wakes up to it, and if it is tomorrow let him pray it at its time" (3). Imam Ahmad said: He only makes up what he missed; the Hadiths are all contrary to what Abu Qatadah said (4).

2. "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 1/272, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/193, "Al-Manar Al-Munif" 122, "Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" 1/439, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 3/366, "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 1/645.

The Hadith.
4. "Masa'il al-Kawsaj" (308).

text: 304 - What has been narrated regarding the non-acceptance of prayer. The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): "Whoever buys a garment containing a forbidden dirham, no prayer will be accepted from him" (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is nothing; it has no chain (2). He said once: I do not know Yazid bin Abdullah, nor Hashim al-Awqas (3).
foot_note:
1. = I say: As for what Imam Ahmad indicated, Al-Bukhari (597) and Muslim (684) narrated from the path of Qatadah, from Anas that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever forgets a prayer, let him pray it when he remembers it; there is no expiation for it except that." Benefit: Al-Bukhari titled a chapter "Whoever forgets a prayer let him pray it when he remembers it, and he does not repeat except that prayer." Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 2/85: It is possible that Al-Bukhari indicated by his saying "and he does not repeat except that prayer" to the weakening of what occurred in some paths of Abu Qatadah's Hadith in Muslim regarding the story of sleeping through the prayer.
1. Narrated by Ahmad 2/98, he said: Aswad bin Amir told us, Baqiyyah bin al-Walid al-Homsi told us, from Uthman bin Zufar, from Hashim, from Ibn Umar who said: "Whoever buys a garment for ten dirhams and in it is a forbidden dirham, Allah will not accept a prayer from him as long as it is upon him." He said: Then he put his fingers in his ears and said: Let them go deaf if I did not hear the Prophet (peace be upon him) say it.
2. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/215, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/380, "Al-Farusiyyah" p. 197, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 1/304.
3. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 2/216, "Al-Farusiyyah" p. 197. Benefit: Most scholars hold that acts of worship are not invalidated by committing what is forbidden if the prohibition is not specific to that act of worship. They are only invalidated by what is specific to the prohibition. Thus, prayer is invalidated by failure to purify for it, carrying impurity, and uncovering the Awrah even in seclusion, but it is not invalidated by looking at forbidden things in it, nor by misappropriating the property of others in it, and similar things where the prohibition is not specific to prayer. Likewise fasting, Hajj, I'tikaf, and others. Quoted from Ibn Rajab in "Al-Fath".

text: Chapters on Jumu'ah (Friday Prayer). 305 - Who said: No Jumu'ah and no Tashriq except in a congregational city (Misr Jami'). The Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): "No Jumu'ah and no Tashriq except in a congregational city" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is not a [strong] Hadith (2). Al-A'mash narrated it from Abu Sa'id al-Maqburi, and he did not meet him. Ahmad said: Al-A'mash did not hear from Abu Sa'id; it is only from Ali, and the statement of Umar (3) contradicts it (4).

(1) Narrated by Abu Yusuf in "Al-Athar" 1/60, he said: Yusuf bin Abi Yusuf told us, from his father, from Abu Hanifah, from Hammad, from Ibrahim, from Abu al-Ahwas, from Ibn Mas'ud that he said regarding Takbir before Tashriq: And in it, Abu Hanifah claimed that it reached him from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "No Jumu'ah..." The Hadith. Al-Zayla'i said in "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/234: Strange as elevated [to the Prophet]; we only found it as stopped at Ali.
2.
