And Sheikh Al-Albani, may Allah have mercy on him, quoted in "Al-Da'ifah" (917) the statement of Imam Ahmad that Al-A'mash did not hear it from Sa'd (instead of Abu Sa'id) from "Masa'il Ahmad" narration of Al-Kawsaj.
3. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/11, he said: Abdullah bin Idris told us, from Shu'bah, from Ata bin Abi Maymunah, from Abu Rafi', from Abu Hurairah that they wrote to Umar asking him about Jumu'ah, so he wrote: Hold Jumu'ah wherever you are. I say: Imam Ahmad said: Its chain is good (Jayyid). "Al-Mughni" 2/175, "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/389.
4. "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/175, "Masa'il al-Kawsaj" (3441), but instead of Abu Sa'id: Abu Sa'd.

text: 306 - Upon whom is Jumu'ah obligatory. The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Jumu'ah is upon whomever the night shelters to his family" (1). They mentioned this Hadith to Imam Ahmad, so he got angry and said to the questioner: Ask forgiveness from your Lord, ask forgiveness from your Lord. Al-Tirmidhi said: Ahmad bin Hanbal only did this because he did not consider this Hadith to be anything, and he weakened it due to the status of its chain (2). And he said once: He denied it most strongly (3). And he said once: He weakened it (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (502): Ahmad bin al-Hasan said: Hajjaj bin Nusair told us, Ma'arik bin Abbad told us, from Abdullah bin Sa'id al-Maqburi, from his father, from Abu Hurairah, raised [to the Prophet].
2. "Sunan Al-Tirmidhi" 2/377, "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" by Ibn Rajab 75, "Bahr al-Dam" (999), "Al-Mughni" by Ibn Qudamah 2/215, "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn al-Jawzi 4/116, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 28/144.
3. "Fath al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab 5/408, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/66.
4. "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 2/54. Issue: Scholars differed on who is obligated to attend Jumu'ah. Some said: Upon whomever the night shelters to his home, which is the view of Ibn Umar, Abu Hurairah, Anas, Ata, Nafi', Ikrimah, Al-Hakam, and Al-Awza'i. And some said: Jumu'ah is only obligatory on whoever hears the call, which is the view of Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath": What the majority went to is that it is obligatory on whoever hears the call or is within the capability of hearing, whether inside the town or outside it.

text: 307 - Mention of the number for Jumu'ah. The Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both): The Sunnah has passed that in every three is an Imam, or in every forty and above that is Jumu'ah, Adha, and Fitr, and that is because they are a congregation (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Abd al-Aziz bin Abd al-Rahman, strike out his Hadith; it is a lie, or he said: it is fabricated (2). 308 - Ghusl (washing) on Friday. The Hadith of Hafsah (may Allah be pleased with her): "Going to Jumu'ah is upon every dreamer (pubescent), and upon everyone who goes to Jumu'ah is Ghusl" (3). Imam Ahmad said: The correct version is without mentioning Hafsah (4). 309 - The Imam greeting the people when he ascends the pulpit. The Hadith of Al-Sha'bi: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to greet the people when he ascended the pulpit (5).

text: Imam Ahmad said: Hushaym did not hear it from Mujalid (1). 310 - The virtue of one who listens and remains silent during the sermon. The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever performs ablution and perfects the ablution then comes to Jumu'ah and listens and remains silent, he is forgiven what is between him and the [next] Jumu'ah and an increase of three days" (2). Imam Ahmad said: He interpolated (adraja): "and an increase of three days" (3). 311 - Whoever misses a rak'ah of Jumu'ah. The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) stopped at him: If a man catches one rak'ah on Friday, he prays another rak'ah to it. If he finds them sitting, he prays four (4). Imam Ahmad said: How strange it is (5).

text: 312 - Sunnah of Jumu'ah. The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever is praying after Jumu'ah, let him pray four. If his need rushes him, he prays two rak'ahs in the mosque and two rak'ahs in his house" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Idris said: "prays two rak'ahs in his house" is from the speech of Abu Salih (2). 313 - What has been narrated regarding the Hour that is on Friday. The Hadith of Abdullah bin Salam (may Allah be pleased with him): "Indeed, on Friday there is an hour which no Muslim servant encounters while he is in prayer asking Allah Almighty for something except that He gives him what he asked" (3). Imam Ahmad said when asked: Did Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman hear from Abdullah bin Salam regarding the hour that is on Friday? He said: As for him, he caught up with Uthman (may Allah be pleased with him) (4).

text: 314 - If Friday Coincides with the Day of Eid. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Two Eids have come together on this day of yours. So whoever wishes, it suffices for him from the Jumu'ah (Friday prayer), but we will gather" (1). Imam Ahmad said: From where did Baqiyyah bring this? He seemed surprised by it, then said: It was written from Yazid bin Abd Rabbih, from Baqiyyah, from Shu'bah two Hadiths, this is not among them. Rather, it was narrated by a group from Abd al-Aziz, from Abu Salih, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) as Mursal, and they did not mention Abu Hurayrah (2). 315 - Expiation for Whoever Abandons Jumu'ah Without an Excuse. The Hadith of Samurah bin Jundub (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever abandons Jumu'ah without an excuse, let him give a dinar in charity" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Qudamah bin Wabrah narrates it, and he is not known. Ayyub Abu al-Ala narrated it but did not connect its chain (4), while Hammam connected it and said: Half a dirham or a dirham. He contradicted him

text: Chapters on the Two Eids. 317 - Takbir When Going Out to the Eid. The Hadith of Al-Zuhri (may Allah have mercy on him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to go out on the day of Fitr and say Takbir from the time he left his house until he reached the prayer place (Musalla) and until he finished the prayer. When he finished the prayer, he stopped the Takbir. As for Adha, he used to say Takbir from the Dhuhr prayer on the Day of Arafah until the Dhuhr prayer of the last days of Tashriq (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith. Then he said: Shu'bah entered upon Ibn Abi Dhi'b and forbade him from narrating it and said: Do not narrate this. And Shu'bah denied it (2). 318 - Eating on the Day of Eid Before Going Out to Prayer. The Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used not to go out in the morning on the day of Fitr until he ate
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah in his "Musannaf" 2/71 regarding the first part of the text, then in 2/73 regarding the last part of it, both from the path of Yazid bin Harun, from Ibn Abi Dhi'b, from Al-Zuhri that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... the Hadith.
2. "Al-Ilal" by Abdullah bin Ahmad (2376). Issue: The majority of scholars hold that Takbir on Eid al-Fitr is from the time of going out to the prayer until the beginning of the sermon, and weak Hadiths have been narrated regarding that. Al-Hakim said: This is a Sunnah circulated among the people of Hadith. Malik, Ahmad, Ishaq, and Abu Thawr held this view. And on Eid al-Adha from the morning of the Day of Arafah until the Asr of the last day of the days of Tashriq. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath": No Hadith regarding any of that is established from the Prophet (peace be upon him), and the most authentic report from the Companions is the statement of Ali and Ibn Mas'ud, and this was adopted by Al-Shafi'i and Ahmad, and it is the school of Umar and Ibn Abbas.

text: And it was said: Imam Ahmad authenticated the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib, from his father, from his grandfather regarding Takbir in the two Eids (1).

1. "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/84. As for the Hadith, it was narrated by Ibn Majah (1278), he said: Abu Ghuraib Muhammad bin al-Ala' told us, Abdullah bin al-Mubarak told us, from Abdullah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Ya'la, from Amr bin Shu'aib, from his father, from his grandfather that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said Takbir in prayer seven and five times. I say: As for what Al-Hafiz quoted in "Al-Talkhis", I searched for Al-Tirmidhi's quote or the saying of Imam Ahmad in his books and his "Ilal" and the narrations of his companions and in the likely places, but I did not find anything. Imam Ahmad said: I adopt it. This phrase is not used for authentication (Tashih) but for jurisprudential practice. Al-Maimuni narrated from Ahmad, he said: The Takbir in the two Eids is seven in the first and five in the second, and the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) differed in the Takbir, and all of it is permissible. So Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, took the Athar of the Companions, not the elevated Hadith, and his statement which his companions narrated from him "nothing is authentic regarding it" means: as elevated. I say: Al-Mubarakfuri said in "Tuhfat al-Ahwadhi" 2/69: Al-Maimuni said: As for Imam Ahmad's authentication, it is opposed by what Ibn al-Qattan said in his book, and Ahmad bin Hanbal said: There is no authentic Hadith from the Prophet (peace be upon him) regarding the Takbir of the two Eids. Al-Mubarakfuri went to lengths to interpret and reconcile the two sayings, and it is far-fetched as previously explained, and Allah knows best.

The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): That the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar used to pray the two Eids before the sermon (1). Imam Ahmad said: I have not heard anyone say in this Hadith: Abu Bakr and Umar, except Abdah. Ibn Rajab said: And it seems he did not hear it from Abu Usamah (2). 322 - Sitting for the Eid Sermon. The Hadith of Abdullah bin al-Sa'ib (may Allah be pleased with them both): "We are delivering a sermon, so whoever likes to sit for the sermon let him sit, and whoever likes to go let him go" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Mursal (4).

Imam Ahmad said: It is Munkar (2). 324 - Congratulations after Eid. The Hadith of Abu Umamah al-Bahili (may Allah be pleased with him): May Allah accept from us and from you (3). text: Book of Funerals. 325 - What has been narrated regarding the remembrance of death. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Increase the remembrance of the destroyer of pleasures," meaning: death (1). Imam Ahmad denied it and said: This is from the side of Muhammad bin Amr, meaning: its connection (Tawsil) (2). 326 - The Right of a Muslim upon a Muslim. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "The right of a Muslim upon a Muslim are five: returning the greeting when he meets him, replying to him when he sneezes, visiting him when he is sick, attending his funeral when he dies, and accepting his invitation when he invites him" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Gharib (strange). Meaning: this Hadith (4).

text: 327 - What has been narrated regarding the Prophet (peace be upon him) announcing his own death. The Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): Our Prophet and beloved (peace be upon him) - may my father and mother be sacrificed for him - announced his death to us a month before his death (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 4/386 (3996), he said: Ali bin Sa'id al-Razi told us, he said: Muhammad bin Abyan al-Balkhi told us, he said: Amr bin Muhammad al-Anqazi told us, he said: Abd al-Malik al-Asbahani told us, from Khallad al-Saffar, from Al-Ash'ath bin Taliq, from Al-Hasan al-Qarni, from Murrah al-Hamdani, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud who said: Our Prophet and beloved (peace be upon him) - may my father and mother be sacrificed for him - announced his death to us a month before his death. When the separation drew near, he gathered us in the house of our mother Aisha, then looked at us and his eyes teared up, and he strengthened himself and said: "Welcome to you, may Allah greet you, may Allah have mercy on you, may Allah provide for you, may Allah grant you success, may Allah grant you peace, may Allah accept from you. I advise you to fear Allah, and I commend you to Allah, and I appoint Him as successor over you. Indeed, I am a clear warner to you from Him, do not be arrogant against Allah in His servants and His lands, for Allah said to me and to you: {That home of the Hereafter We assign to those who do not desire exaltedness upon the earth or corruption. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous} [Al-Qasas: 83]. Then he recited: {And on the Day of Resurrection you will see those who lied about Allah [with] their faces blackened. Is there not in Hell a residence for the arrogant?} Then he said: "The term has approached, and the return is to Allah, and to Sidrat al-Muntaha, and to the Garden of Refuge, and to the Highest Companion, and the fullest cup, and the fortune and life." We said: Who will wash you, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "The men of my household, the closest then the closest." We said: How should we shroud you? He said: "In these clothes of mine if you wish, or in a Yemeni suit, or in Egyptian white cloth." We said: Who will pray over you among us? We wept and he wept, then he said: "Gently, may Allah forgive you, and reward you with good on behalf of your Prophet. When you have washed me and shrouded me, place me on my bed in this house of mine on the edge of my grave, then leave me for an hour. For the first who will pray over me is my companion and friend Jibril, then Mika'il, then Israfil, then the Angel of Death with his soldiers. Then enter upon me group by group, pray over me and submit with peace, and do not harm me with a wailing woman, nor noise, nor crying out. Let the prayer begin with the men of my household and their women, then you convey my greetings abundantly to those of my companions who are absent, for I have greeted whoever pledges allegiance to me on my religion until the Day of Resurrection." We said: Who will place you in your grave? He said: "My family with many angels who see you from where you do not see them."

text: 328 - Prompting the Dying to Say the Shahada. The Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Awfa (may Allah be pleased with him): There is a boy here who is dying, it is said to him: Say: La ilaha illa Allah, but he cannot say it. He said: "Did he not use to say it in his life?" He said: Yes. He said: "So what prevented him from it at his death..." (1). Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad said: My father did not narrate this Hadith; he crossed it out from his book, because he was not pleased with the Hadith of Fa'id bin Abd al-Rahman, or he was considered abandoned (Matruk) in Hadith by him (2). 329 - What has been narrated regarding the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him). It contains three Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) regarding the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him) (3). Imam Ahmad denied that Abd al-Aziz heard anything from Hisham (4). The Second: The Hadith of Daghfal bin Hanzalah: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) died while he was sixty-five
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 4/382, he said: Yazid bin Harun told us, Fa'id bin Abd al-Rahman informed us, he said: I heard Abdullah bin Abi Awfa say: A man came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah... The Hadith.
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 4/382.
3. I did not find it from the mentioned path, Sabih, from Abd al-Aziz bin Abd al-Samad, from Hisham, from his father, from Aisha... The Hadith. I say: In "Al-Muntakhab min al-Ilal lil-Khallal" (98) it is with the wording: regarding the description of the Prophet (peace be upon him), instead of: regarding the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and also without mentioning Aisha, so Allah knows best.
4. "Masa'il Abu Dawud" (1932), "Al-Muntakhab min al-Ilal lil-Khallal" (98).

text: And he said once: Hafs erred in it and connected it, while Al-Thawri and Ibn Juraij narrated it as Mursal (1). 331 - What has been narrated regarding carrying the funeral bier. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever follows a funeral, let him carry at the four sides of the bier." Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Al-Mas'udi, from Abu Ubaidah, from Abdullah regarding carrying the funeral bier, this is a mistake from Al-Mas'udi (2). The Hadith is the Hadith of Al-Thawri and others, from Mansur, from Ubaid bin Nistas (3), from Abu Ubaidah, from Abdullah (4). The Second: The Hadith of Muhammad bin Ali: That Ibrahim the son of the Prophet (peace be upon him), his funeral bier was carried on the saddle-cloth of a horse (5). Imam Ahmad said: They denied it from him (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 2/271. I say: The first part of this text appeared in "Sahih Muslim" (1206) from the path of Mansur, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, but with the wording of prohibition: "Do not cover his face." However, Al-Bayhaqi said in "Al-Sunan" 3/393: It is a mistake from some of its narrators in both the chain and text. Then he mentioned that the correct version is the narration of Al-Bukhari from the path of Mansur, from Al-Hakam bin Utaibah, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, elevated [to the Prophet], which contains: "And do not cover his head."
2. I did not find it from the mentioned path.
3. Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq in his "Musannaf" 3/512 number (6517), he said: From Al-Thawri and Ma'mar, from Mansur, from Ubaid bin Nistas, from Abu Ubaidah who said: Abdullah bin Mas'ud said...

text: 332 - What has been narrated regarding walking in front of the funeral procession. It contains three Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): I saw the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar walking in front of the funeral procession. Imam Ahmad said: As for Sufyan, he mostly said: From Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from his father that he saw the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar (1). Aqil bin Khalid (2) narrated it from Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from Ibn Umar that he used to walk in front of the funeral procession, and that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar used to walk in front of the funeral procession. Ibn Juraij (3) also narrated it and agreed with Aqil exactly as he said (4). And he said once: It is only from Al-Zuhri (5) as Mursal, and the Hadith of Salim is the action of Ibn

3. text: 333 - Lowering the Voice at Funerals. The Hadith of Zaid bin Arqam (may Allah be pleased with him): "Allah loves the lowering of the voice on three occasions: When reciting the Quran, at a funeral, and when two armies meet" (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic. He said: And Thabit bin Zaid has Munkar (denounced) Hadiths (2). 334 - What has been narrated regarding hastening the funeral. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Hasten your funerals; for if it was righteous, you hasten it to good, and if it was otherwise, you put it down from your necks" (3).
foot_note:
1. = Issue: Ibn Abd al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" 12/94-95: The jurists differed regarding walking in front of the funeral procession and behind it, and which of that is better. Malik, Al-Layth, and Al-Shafi'i said: The Sunnah is walking in front of the funeral procession, and it is better. Abu Hanifah and his companions said: Walking behind it is better, and there is no harm according to them in walking in front of it, and Al-Awza'i said similarly. Ahmad bin Hanbal said: Walking in front of it is better. He used as evidence Umar bin Al-Khattab putting the people in front in the funeral of Zainab bint Jahsh. Al-Thawri said: There is no harm in walking behind it or in front of it, and the merit in that is equal. Al-Zuhri said: Walking behind the funeral procession is a mistake against the Sunnah.
1. Narrated by Al-Tabarani 5/213 number (5130), he said: Ibrahim bin Hashim al-Baghawi told us, Umayyah bin Bistam told us, Mu'tamir bin Sulaiman told us, Thabit bin Zaid told us, from a man, from Zaid bin Arqam, elevated [to the Prophet].
2. "Al-Ilal al-Mutanahiyah" by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/94.
3. Narrated by Ahmad 2/280, he said: Abd al-Razzaq told us, Ma'mar told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Ibn al-Musayyib, from Abu Hurayrah elevated [to the Prophet].

text: Imam Ahmad said: Yunus contradicted (1); he said: Abu Umamah told me (2). 335 - What has been narrated regarding blocking the path of the funeral. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) blocked the path of the funeral of Abu Talib, then said: "A womb connection has been maintained, and may you be rewarded with good, O uncle" (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith; this is an unknown (Majhul) man (4).

text: 336 - Praying over the Funeral in the Mosque. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever prays over a funeral in the mosque, there is nothing for him" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is a weak Hadith; Salih the Mawla of al-Taw'amah was unique in narrating it, and he is weak (2). And he said once: Until the Hadith of Salih the Mawla of al-Taw'amah is established. As if, according to him, it is not established or not authentic (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 2/444, he said: Waki' told us, he said: Ibn Abi Dhi'b told us, from Salih the Mawla of al-Taw'amah, from Abu Hurayrah elevated [to the Prophet].
2. "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/326, "Zad al-Ma'ad" 1/500, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/144.
3. "Masa'il al-Imam Ahmad" narration of Abdullah (527). Issue: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 3/237 (abridged): The Hadith of Ibn Umar which Al-Bukhari narrated indicates that the Jews came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) with a man and a woman from among them who committed adultery, so he ordered them to be stoned near the place of funerals by the mosque. Also, Al-Bukhari mentioned the Hadith of Najashi, in which: The Prophet (peace be upon him) lined them up at the Musalla and said four Takbirs over him. This indicates that there was a place prepared for funerals to pray over them. It may be derived from this that the prayer over some funerals in the mosque occurred due to an incidental matter or to show permissibility. The legitimacy of praying over funerals in the mosque is supported by the Hadith of Aisha: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not pray over Suhail bin Baida' except in the mosque. Narrated by Muslim. This is the view of the majority. Malik said: It does not please me. Ibn Abi Dhi'b and Abu Hanifah disliked it.

text: What has been narrated regarding Takbir over the Funeral. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): The last funeral the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed over, he said four Takbirs over it (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Muhammad narrated fabricated Hadiths, among them is this one. And he found it grave. He said: Abu al-Malih was the most pious of people and more authentic in Hadith than to narrate something like this. He said: This Hadith was only narrated by Muhammad bin Ziyad al-Tahhan (2), and he used to manufacture Hadith (3). And he said once: This is a lie with no basis; it was only narrated by Muhammad bin Ziyad, and he used to fabricate Hadith (4). And he said once: The Takbir over the deceased is four, according to me, is more established (5).

2. Narrated by Al-Uqayli in "Al-Du'afa" 4/67, he said: Muhammad told us, Abbas told us, he said: I heard Yahya say: Muhammad bin Ziyad al-Maimuni said: I heard Maymun bin Mihran say: I heard Ibn Abbas say: The angels said four Takbirs over Adam. I say: It is possible that both narrations are for one text; Al-Daraqutni 2/72 narrated it and combined both narrations, and Allah knows best.

text: 337 - Supplication for the deceased between the fourth Takbir and the Taslim. Imam Ahmad said: I do not know anything regarding it; because if there was a legislated supplication in it, it would have been transmitted (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) "Al-Mughni" 2/372. I say: Al-Bayhaqi 4/42 extracted a Hadith in this chapter, saying: Abu Abdullah Al-Hafiz and Abu Sa'id bin Abi Amr informed us, they said: Abu Al-Abbas Muhammad bin Ya'qub told us, Ibrahim bin Marzuq told us, Wahb bin Jarir told us, Shu'bah told us, from Al-Hajari - meaning Ibrahim - from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa who said: A daughter of his died, so he went out in her funeral procession on a mule behind the bier. The women began to wail, so Abdullah bin Abi Awfa said: Do not wail; for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade wailing, but let one of you shed from her tears whatever she wishes. He said: Then he prayed over her and said four Takbirs, and stood after the fourth Takbir for the duration between two Takbirs asking forgiveness for her and supplicating. Then he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to do like this. Benefit: Perhaps Imam Ahmad's statement: "I do not know anything regarding it" means "I do not know anything authentic regarding it," and Allah knows best. Imam Ahmad said in "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1024) when asked about supplication in the fourth Takbir: You supplicate then say Taslim. Ibn Qudamah quoted in "Al-Mughni" 2/372 from Imam Ahmad that he supplicates or says Taslim; because it is standing in prayer, so there is a legislated remembrance in it like that before the fourth Takbir. Imam Ahmad said in "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (931) when asked about the prayer over the funeral: He recites Al-Hamd in the first Takbir, then sends blessings upon the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the second, then supplicates for the deceased and the believing men and women in the third and points with his index finger, then says Taslim in the fourth. Ibn Hani said in his "Masa'il" (932) abridged: I prayed next to Abu Abdullah over a funeral... and in it: Then he said the fourth Takbir and did not say anything until he said one Taslim to his right, making those next to him hear. Issue: The Shafi'is and Imam Ahmad hold the view of supplicating in the fourth Takbir, while Abu Hanifah holds that he says the fourth Takbir and says Taslim without any remembrance between them.

text: 338 - Exiting the funeral prayer with one Taslim. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed over a funeral, said four Takbirs, and said one Taslim (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith, in my view, is fabricated (2). 339 - What has been narrated regarding praying over children. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah (may Allah be pleased with him): "The rider is behind the funeral procession, and the walker is wherever he wishes from it, and the child is prayed over" (3). Imam Ahmad said: Authentic, elevated (Marfu') (4).

text: The Second: The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): Ibrahim, the son of the Prophet (peace be upon him), died when he was eighteen months old, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not pray over him (1). Imam Ahmad said: Very Munkar (denounced), and he weakened Ibn Ishaq (2). 340 - What has been narrated regarding omitting prayer over the martyr. The Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not pray over the slain of Uhud nor did he wash them. Imam Ahmad said: They differed regarding it. Abd Rabbih bin Sa'id said: From Al-Zuhri from Jabir (3). And Al-Awza'i said: From whoever told him from Jabir (4). And Ibn Abi
foot_note:

I say: In "Musnad Ahmad" and others there is the addition: Ibn Jabir, so perhaps it fell from "Masa'il Ibn Hani", and Allah knows best.
4. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1348), he said: Ibn Muqatil told us, Abdullah informed us, Al-Awza'i informed us, from Al-Zuhri, from Jabir... The Hadith, and it does not contain mention of prayer and washing.

text: Su'air: The Hadith of Muhammad bin Ishaq: That Abu Su'air said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said (1). And Al-Layth bin Sa'd said: From Al-Zuhri, from Abdur-Rahman bin Ka'b bin Malik, from Jabir (2). And Zaid bin Aslam said: From Al-Zuhri, from Anas (3). They have differed regarding it (4).

foot_note: 1. = Ibn Al-Mubarak narrated it from Al-Awza'i, from Al-Zuhri as Mursal, from Jabir. And Sulayman bin Kathir said: From Al-Zuhri, 'someone who heard Jabir told me'. And Ma'mar said: From Al-Zuhri, from Ibn Abi Su'air, from Jabir. It is Mudtarib (disturbed). Al-Hafiz defended this Hadith against Idtirab in "Muqaddimat Al-Fath" p. 374, saying: Al-Daraqutni stated absolutely that this Hadith is Mudtarib despite the possibility of negating Idtirab from it, by interpreting the ambiguous narrator in Sulayman's narration as the named one in Al-Layth's narration, and interpreting Ma'mar's narration that Al-Zuhri heard it from two Sheikhs. As for Al-Awza'i's Mursal narration, he shortened it by omitting the intermediary. This is the method of those who negate Idtirab from it. Al-Bukhari cited the difference in it, but he extracted Al-Awza'i's narration despite its disconnection because the Hadith with him is from Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, from Al-Layth and Al-Awza'i together, from Al-Zuhri. Al-Awza'i omitted Abdur-Rahman bin Ka'b, and Al-Layth affirmed him, and they are equal regarding Al-Zuhri, and they both declared hearing it from him, so Al-Layth's addition was accepted due to his trustworthiness. Then he said after that: And Sulayman bin Kathir narrated it from Al-Zuhri, from whoever heard Jabir. He intended by that to affirm the intermediary between Al-Zuhri and Jabir in general and to confirm Al-Layth's narration with that, and he did not see it as a defect necessitating Idtirab. As for Ma'mar's narration, Sufyan bin Uyainah agreed with him on it, narrating it from Al-Zuhri, from Ibn Abi Su'air, and said: Ma'mar confirmed me in it. So his narration returns to Ma'mar's narration. Regarding Al-Zuhri, there is another difference Al-Daraqutni did not mention; it was said: From Usamah bin Zaid, from Al-Zuhri, from Anas. From this path Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi extracted it. Al-Tirmidhi quoted in "Al-Ilal" from Al-Bukhari that he said: Usamah's Hadith is a mistake he erred in - meaning the correct version involves Al-Layth's variation. Al-Hakim erred and extracted this Hadith of Usamah in his "Mustadrak". And regarding Al-Zuhri there is another difference, narrated by Al-Bayhaqi from the path of Abdur-Rahman bin Abdul-Aziz Al-Ansari, from Al-Zuhri, from Abdur-Rahman bin Ka'b bin Malik, from his father, which is also a mistake, and this Abdur-Rahman is weak. It is not hidden from the astute that Al-Layth's narration is the most likely of these narrations as we established, and that Al-Bukhari does not deem a Hadith defective merely due to difference.

text: 341 - Praying over the grave. It contains two Hadiths: Both from the path of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): The First: From Al-Sha'bi from him: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed over a grave after he was buried (1). Imam Ahmad denied it. He said: This is not from the Hadith of Ismail (2). The Second: From Ikrimah from him: The Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed over Umm Sa'd a month after her death (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is only Qatadah from Sa'id. It was said to Ahmad: Suwaid narrated it from Yazid bin Zurai'. He said: Yazid does not narrate the likes of this (4).

text: And he said once: Prayer over the grave is narrated from six perspectives, all of them Hasan (good) (1). 342 - What has been narrated regarding sitting on the grave and praying towards it. The Hadith of Abu Marthad Al-Ghanawi (may Allah be pleased with him): "Do not sit on graves and do not pray towards them" (2). Imam Ahmad said: Wathilah is not that old; this should be from Ibn Jabir, meaning the narration of Ibn Mubarak (3), from Ibn Jabir, from Busr bin Ubaidullah, from Abu Idris, from Wathilah. Meaning: inserting Abu Idris between Wathilah and Busr (4).

text: 343 - What has been narrated regarding prompting (Talqin) the deceased. The Hadith of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him): "If one of your brothers dies and you have leveled the earth over his grave, let one of you stand at the head of his grave then say: O So-and-so son of So-and-so [mother's name]" (1). Imam Ahmad said: I have not seen anyone do this except the people of Sham; when Abu Al-Mughirah died, a person came and said that. Abu Al-Mughirah used to narrate regarding it from Abu Bakr bin Abi Maryam from their sheikhs that they used to do it, and Ibn Ayyash used to narrate regarding it. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: Meaning the Hadith of Abu Umamah (2).

The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered us saying: "If one of your brothers dies and you have leveled the earth over his grave, let one of you stand at the head of his grave, then say: O So-and-so son of So-and-so [mother's name], for he hears it but does not answer. Then say: O So-and-so son of So-and-so, for he sits up. Then say: O So-and-so son of So-and-so, for he says: Guide us, may Allah have mercy on you, but you do not perceive. So let him say: Remember what you left the world upon, the testimony that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, and that you are pleased with Allah as Lord, Islam as religion, Muhammad as Prophet, and the Quran as Imam. For Munkar and Nakir take each other by the hand and say: Let us go, we will not sit with one who has been prompted his argument, so Allah becomes his arguer instead of them." A man said: O Messenger of Allah, what if he does not know his mother? He said: "[Attribute him] to Eve, O So-and-so son of Eve."
2. "Zad Al-Ma'ad" 1/523, "Al-Maqasid Al-Hasanah" 163.

text: 344 - What has been narrated regarding walking with sandals between graves. The Hadith of Bashir bin Al-Khasasiyah (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding removing sandals between graves (1). Imam Ahmad said: The chain of the Hadith of Bashir bin Al-Khasasiyah is good (Jayyid); I adopt it unless there is a valid reason [not to] (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawud (3230), he said: Sahl bin Bakkar told us, Al-Aswad bin Shaiban told us, from Khalid bin Sumair Al-Sadusi, from Bashir bin Nahik, from Bashir the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) - his name in Jahiliyyah was Zahm bin Ma'bad, so he migrated to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "What is your name?" He said: Zahm. He said: "Rather you are Bashir" - he said: While I was walking with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), he passed by the graves of the polytheists and said: "Indeed these have missed much good" three times. Then he passed by the graves of the Muslims and said: "Indeed these have attained much good." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) glanced and saw a man walking among the graves wearing sandals. He said: "O owner of the Sibtiyyah (tanned leather sandals), woe to you, throw off your Sibtiyyah." The man looked, and when he recognized the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), he took them off and threw them.
2. "Al-Mughni" 2/423, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 2/158-159. Issue: Ibn Qudamah said in "Al-Mughni" abridged: Most scholars do not see any harm in that. Jarir bin Hazim said: I saw Al-Hasan and Ibn Sirin walking between graves in their sandals. Some argued using the saying of the Prophet (peace be upon him): "When the servant is placed in his grave and his companions turn away from him, he indeed hears the tapping of their sandals" narrated by Al-Bukhari. Abu Al-Khattab said: It seems that the Prophet (peace be upon him) only disliked walking in sandals for the man because of the pride in them, for Sibtiyyah sandals were the dress of the people of luxury. Al-Nawawi said: Its lowest state is recommendation because removing sandals is closer to humility and the dress of the people of modesty. The Prophet informing that the deceased hears the tapping of their sandals does not negate dislike, for it indicates the occurrence of this from them, and there is no dispute in its occurrence and their doing it despite its dislike. However, if the walker has an excuse preventing him from removing his sandals, such as thorns he fears for his feet or impurity touching them, walking in sandals is not disliked. Ahmad said regarding the man entering graveyards containing thorns while removing his sandals: This restricts people until the man walks on thorns. It was narrated from Ahmad that when he wanted to go out to a funeral, he wore his Khuff (leather socks) despite his command to remove sandals. See: "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (953).

text: 345 - What has been narrated regarding the Lahd (niche) and the Shaqq (trench). It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): "The Lahd is for us and the Shaqq is for others" (1). Imam Ahmad said: There is no established Hadith standing regarding it (2). The Second: The Hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): A Lahd was made for the Prophet (peace be upon him) and for Abu Bakr and Umar (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is not from the Hadith of Yahya and Ibn Ajlan (4). 346 - What has been narrated regarding deepening the grave. The Hadith of Hisham bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him): "Dig and widen, and bury two and three in a grave" (5).

text: 349 - What has been narrated regarding taking graves as mosques. The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "May Allah fight the Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abdur-Rahman did not elevate it (2). 350 - What has been narrated regarding the reward of one who consoles an afflicted person. The Hadith of Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever consoles an afflicted person has a reward similar to his" (3). It was said to Imam Ahmad: Did anyone other than Ali bin Asim narrate it? He said: We do not know anyone else who narrated it. It was said to him: Nor as Mawquf? He said: No one else narrates it. It was said to him: Muhammad bin Al-Fadl bin Atiyah? He did not pay attention to him (4). And he said once: I have no doubt about it, except that I tore up his Hadith - meaning: Abdur-Rahman bin Malik bin Maghul - then he mentioned this Hadith (5).

text: Book of Zakah. 354 - What has been narrated regarding hoarders of wealth and the stern warning against them. The Hadith of Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him): "Give glad tidings to the hoarders of branding on the foreheads, branding on the backs, and branding on the sides" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abu Kamil (2) narrated it from Hammad, and did not mention: 'except something they heard from their Prophet (peace be upon him)'. Affan narrated it with the addition, and I do not see Affan except having erred and gone to the Hadith of Abu Al-Ashhab (3), because Affan added it and it was not with us (4).

text: 355 - What has been narrated that whatever Zakah has been paid on is not hoarded treasure. The Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whatever wealth its Zakah has been paid is not hoarded treasure" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Strike out the Hadith of Abdul-Aziz Al-Balisi for he is a liar. Or he said: A fabricator (2). 356 - What has been narrated regarding hastening Zakah. It contains two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): "As for Khalid, you wrong Khalid; he has reserved his armor and equipment for the sake of Allah" (3). Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Warqa' from Abu Al-Zinad, from Al-A'raj, from Abu Hurayrah: "My equipment (A'wady) is an endowment."
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Khatib in "Tarikh Baghdad" 8/12, he said: Abu Al-Fath informed us, Abu Abdullah Al-Husain bin Ahmad bin Hamid bin Muhammad bin Thabit bin Farghan Al-Dhahabi informed us, Abu Isa Abdur-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Harun Al-Anbari told us, Ishaq bin Khalid bin Yazid Al-Balisi told us, Abdul-Aziz bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Balisi told us, Khasif bin Abdur-Rahman told us, from Abu Al-Zubair, from Jabir, elevated [to the Prophet].
2. "Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" by Ibn Al-Jawzi 2/4.
3. Narrated by Muslim (983), he said: Zuhair bin Harb told me, Ali bin Hafs told us, Warqa' told us, from Abu Al-Zinad, from Al-A'raj, from Abu Hurayrah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent Umar to collect charity. It was said: Ibn Jamil, Khalid bin Al-Walid, and Al-Abbas the uncle of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) refused. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Ibn Jamil only refuses because he was poor and Allah enriched him. As for Khalid, you wrong Khalid; he has reserved his armor and equipment for the sake of Allah. As for Al-Abbas, it is upon me and the like of it with it." Then he said: "O Umar, did you not know that a man's uncle is the twin half of his father?"

text: He said: Warqa' erred in it and Ibn Abi Al-Zinad was correct. He said: "My slaves (A'budy) (1) are an endowment." Then he said: Ibn Abi Al-Zinad is more beloved to me than Warqa' (2). The Second: The Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him): That Al-Abbas asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about hastening his charity before it was due, so he granted him a concession in that (3). Imam Ahmad said: Weak. And he said: That is nothing (4). 357 - What has been narrated regarding Zakah on the orphan's wealth. The Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both): "Lo, whoever is a guardian of an orphan who has wealth, let him trade with it and not leave it until charity consumes it" (5). Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic; Al-Muthanna narrates it from Amr (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Ubaid in "Al-Amwal" 585, he said: Abu Ayyub told us from Ibn Abi Al-Zinad, from his father, from Al-A'raj, from Abu Hurayrah elevated... and in it "and his slaves (A'budah) are an endowment".
2. In "Ilal Al-Marwazi" (146) "and his equipment (A'tuduh)". I say: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 3/290: It is said that some narrators of Al-Bukhari have "and his slaves (A'budah) are an endowment", plural of 'Abd', narrated by Iyad, but the first is the famous one. And in "Sahih Ibn Khuzaymah" (2330) from the same path of Al-Bukhari with the wording "and his slaves (A'budah) are an endowment", so Allah knows best.
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (678), he said: Abdullah bin Abdur-Rahman told us, Sa'id bin Mansur informed us, Ismail bin Zakariya told us, from Al-Hajjaj bin Dinar, from Al-Hakam bin Utaibah, from Hajiyyah bin Adi, from Ali... he mentioned it.
4. "Al-Farusiyyah" by Ibn Al-Qayyim p. 199.
5. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (641), he said: Muhammad bin Ismail told us, Ibrahim bin Musa told us, Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, from Al-Muthanna bin Al-Sabah, from Amr bin Shu'aib, from his father, from his grandfather that the Prophet (peace be upon him) addressed the people saying... he mentioned it.
6. "Al-Talkhis Al-Habir" 2/157, "Nasb Al-Rayah" 2/388, "Tanqih Al-Tahqiq" 2/187.

text: And he said once: I do not know any authentic thing regarding it from the companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) (1). And once: Ibn Juraij did not meet Amr bin Shu'aib regarding Zakah on the orphan's wealth nor Abu Al-Zinad (2). 358 - What has been narrated regarding Zakah to relatives. The Hadith of Zainab the wife of Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with them both): That she had orphans of her brother in her care, can she give them her Zakah? He said: "Yes" (3). Imam Ahmad said: As for mentioning Zakah, it is not preserved (Mahfuz) in my view; that was only charity other than Zakah (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (552).
2. "Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala" 6/332. Issue: Al-Tirmidhi 3/24 said: Scholars differed in this chapter: More than one of the companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) saw Zakah in the orphan's wealth, among them: Umar, Ali, Aisha, and Ibn Umar. This is the saying of Malik, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq. A group of scholars said: There is no Zakah in the orphan's wealth. This is the saying of Sufyan Al-Thawri and Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak.
3. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah 2/412, he said: Mughirah told us, from Ibrahim, who said: Abdullah's wife came... The Hadith.
4. "Al-Mughni" 2/514. I say: The text has a correct witness in Al-Bukhari (1466) from Zainab the wife of Abdullah... and in it: Bilal passed by us so we said: Ask the Prophet (peace be upon him) does it suffice for me to spend on my husband and orphans under my care? And we said: Do not inform him about us. So he entered and asked him, so he said: "Who are they?" He said: Zainab. He said: "Which Zainab?" He said: The wife of Abdullah. He said: "Yes, and she has two rewards: the reward of kinship and the reward of charity."

text: 359 - Charity to the freed slaves of the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him). The Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): And in it: "It is charity for her and it is a gift for you, so eat it" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Between Al-Qasim and Hisham bin Urwah (2) is Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Qasim (3). 360 - What has been narrated regarding the spending of the slave from his master's wealth. The Hadith of Umair the freed slave of Abi Al-Lahm: I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): Can I give charity from my masters' wealth? He said: "Yes, and the reward is split half between you" (4). Imam Ahmad was asked about this Hadith and he did not say anything regarding it (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Mentioned in "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2138) from the Hadith of Abu Hammam from Ibn Fadl who said: Hisham bin Urwah told us, from Al-Qasim bin Muhammad, from Aisha who said: Barirah had three issues; her people wanted to sell her and stipulate her loyalty (Wala'), so I mentioned that to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he said: "Buy her and free her, for loyalty belongs to the one who frees." She said: So I freed her. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) gave her the choice so she chose herself. She said: And people used to give charity to her and she would gift to us, so I mentioned that to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he said... he mentioned it.
2. Narrated by Muslim (1504), he said: Zuhair bin Harb and Muhammad bin Al-Ala' - wording is Zuhair's - told us, they said: Abu Mu'awiyah told us, Hisham bin Urwah told us, from Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Qasim, from his father, from Aisha... The Hadith.
3. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2138).
4. Narrated by Muslim (1025), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah, Ibn Numair, and Zuhair bin Harb all told us, from Hafs bin Ghiyath. Ibn Numair said: Hafs told us, from Muhammad bin Zaid, from Umair the freed slave of Abi Al-Lahm, who said: I was a slave. So I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... The Hadith.
5. "Masa'il Harb" p. 471.

text: 361 - What has been narrated regarding Zakah on debt. The Hadith of Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): The time of my Zakah comes and I have debt, so I order him to pay Zakah on it (1). Imam Ahmad said: Abdul-Malik bin Abi Bakr, from Umar, is Mursal (2). 362 - What has been narrated regarding acquired wealth (Al-Mal Al-Mustafad). The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) as Mawquf regarding the man who acquires wealth, he said: He pays Zakah on it when he acquires it (3). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is strange (Gharib), and Khalid bin Hayyan was okay (4). 363 - What has been narrated regarding Zakah on grazing livestock (Sa'imah) and the sin of whoever conceals it. The Hadith of Mu'awiyah bin Haidah Al-Qushairi (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding Zakah on grazing camels and in it: "In every grazing camel, in forty a Bint Labun (two-year-old she-camel), and camels should not be separated from their calculation" (5).

text: Imam Ahmad said: I do not know what its face (validity) is. Then he was asked about its chain of narrators, so he said: The chain is upright (Salih) (1). 364 - What has been related regarding the charity of camels. There are two Hadiths in it: First: The Hadith of Amr bin Hazm, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding the inheritances, the sunan (traditions), the blood monies, and the charities (2).
foot_note:
1. = his father, from his grandfather that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "In every free-grazing camel, in forty, a Bint Labun (two-year-old she-camel), and camels are not to be separated from their calculation. Whoever gives it seeking reward - Ibn al-Ala said: seeking reward through it - then he has his reward, and whoever withholds it, then we will take it and half of his wealth as a firm decree from the decrees of our Lord, Mighty and Majestic; the family of Muhammad has no share in it." 
1. "Al-Mughni" 2/436, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/258. Benefit: Al-Bayhaqi transferred 4/105 from Al-Shafi'i who said: The people of knowledge of Hadith do not establish that charity is taken along with half of the wealth's camels for his charity, and if it were established, we would have spoken by it. 
2. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi 4/89, he said: Narrated to us Abu Abd al-Rahman Muhammad bin Al-Hussein Al-Sulami, narrated to us Muhammad bin Al-Mu'ammal, narrated to us Al-Fadl bin Muhammad bin Al-Musayyib, narrated to us Al-Hakam bin Musa, H. And narrated to us Abu Abd al-Rahman Al-Sulami and Abu Nasr Umar bin Abd al-Aziz bin Umar bin Qatadah, they said: Informed us Abu Amr Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Matar, narrated to us Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Al-Hasan bin Abd al-Jabbar Al-Sufi, narrated to us Al-Hakam bin Musa, narrated to us Yahya bin Hamzah, from Sulaiman bin Dawood, narrated to me Al-Zuhri, from Abu Bakr bin Muhammad bin Amr bin Hazm, from his father, from his grandfather that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, wrote to the people of Yemen with a book containing the inheritances, the sunan, and the blood monies, and he sent it with Amr bin Hazm, and it was read to the people of Yemen, and this is its copy: "In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. From Muhammad the Prophet to Shurahbil bin Abd Kulal and Nu'aym bin Abd Kulal and Al-Harith bin Abd Kulal - it was said: Dhu Ru'ayn, Ma'afir and Hamdan - As to what follows: Your messenger has reported, and you have given from the spoils the fifth of Allah, and what Allah has prescribed upon the believers regarding the tithe (Zakat) on land property: what the sky waters and was naturally flowing or rain-fed, then in it is the tithe (one-tenth) if it reaches five Awsuq (loads), and what was watered by the bucket =

text: Imam Ahmad said: I hope that it is authentic [Sahih] (1). And he said once: Authentic (2). And he said once when this Hadith was presented to him: Sulaiman bin Dawood, this one is nothing (3).
foot_note:
1. = and the waterwheel, then in it is half of the tithe (one-twentieth) if it reaches five Awsuq. And in every five free-grazing camels, a sheep, until it reaches twenty-four. So if it increases by one over twenty-four, then in it is a Bint Makhad (one-year-old she-camel). If a Bint Makhad is not found, then a male Ibn Labun (two-year-old male camel), until it reaches forty-five. If it increases by one over forty-five, then in it is a Hiqqah (three-year-old she-camel) ready for the stallion, until it reaches sixty. If it increases by one over sixty, then in it is a Jadh'ah (four-year-old she-camel) until it reaches seventy-five. If it increases by one over seventy-five, then in it are two Bint Labuns until it reaches ninety. If it increases by one over ninety, then in it are two Hiqqahs ready for the stallion until it reaches one hundred and twenty. So whatever exceeds one hundred and twenty, then in every forty is a Bint Labun, and in every fifty is a Hiqqah ready for the stallion. And in every thirty free-grazing cows is a Tabi' Jadh' or Jadh'ah (two-year-old bull/cow), and in every forty free-grazing cows is a cow (Musinnah). And in every forty free-grazing sheep is a sheep until it reaches one hundred and twenty. If it increases over one hundred and twenty by one, then in it are two sheep until it reaches two hundred. If it increases by one, then in it are three until it reaches three hundred. If it increases, then in every one hundred sheep is a sheep. And an old decrepit animal is not taken in charity, nor a defective one, nor one with a defect, nor the male goat. And separate things should not be gathered, nor should gathered things be separated for fear of charity (tax). And whatever is taken from two partners, they return to each other with equality. And in every five Uqiyyah (ounces) of silver is five Dirhams, and whatever exceeds, then in every forty Dirhams is a Dirham, and there is nothing in less than five Uqiyyah. And in every forty Dinars is a Dinar. And indeed, charity is not permissible for Muhammad nor the family of his household; it is only Zakat by which their souls are purified and for the poor Muslims and in the way of Allah. And there is nothing in a slave, nor a farm, nor its workers if its charity is paid from the tithe (of the produce). And indeed there is nothing in a Muslim's slave nor in his horse..." The Hadith. 
1. "Juz' min Masa'il al-Imam Ahmad" by Al-Baghawi (38), (72), "Al-Kamil" by Ibn Adi 3/275, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 11/418, "Sunan al-Bayhaqi" 4/89-90, "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/401, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 4/18, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 2/402, "Mizan al-I'tidal" 2/390, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 1/132, "Bahr al-Dam" (395). 
2. "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/401, "Al-Tahqiq" 4/298, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/171.

text: And he said once: There is no doubt that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, wrote it - meaning the letter of Amr bin Hazm - and it is also the saying of Salman Al-Farisi and Abdullah bin Umar, and others, and no dissenter from the Companions is known to them (1). Second: The Hadith of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: "In five free-grazing camels is a sheep, and in ten are two sheep, and in fifteen are three sheep" (2). Imam Ahmad said: I said to Yazid: A person in Kufa narrates it from Yahya. He said: It reached me from Salim, and he remained silent. Then afterwards Yazid said: Where is Ibn
foot_note:
1. (1) "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 4/18, "Mizan al-I'tidal" 2/390-391, "Tarikh Abi Zur'ah" p. 214. I say: Ibn Ma'in and Al-Daraqutni have weakened this Hadith. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Talkhis" 4/18 with modification: A group of Imams have authenticated this Hadith, not from the perspective of the chain (Isnad), but from the perspective of fame. Al-Shafi'i said in his "Risalah": They did not accept this Hadith until it was established to them that it was the book of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: This book is famous among the people of biographies (Siyar), known for what is in it among the people of knowledge, a knowledge whose fame dispenses with the need for a chain; because it resembles Mutawatir (mass transmitted) in its arrival; due to the people receiving it with acceptance and knowledge. Al-Uqayli said: This is a preserved (Mahfuz) established Hadith, except that we see it is a book not heard from anyone above Al-Zuhri. Yaqub bin Sufyan said: I do not know in all the transmitted books a book more authentic than this book of Amr bin Hazm, for the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the Tabi'un return to it and leave their opinion. Al-Hakim said: Umar bin Abd al-Aziz and the Imam of his era, Al-Zuhri, testified to the authenticity of this book. 
2. "Al-Fatawa" by Ibn Taymiyyah 31/366. 
3. Narrated by Al-Daraqutni 2/97-98, he said: Narrated to us Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Quhi regarding Al-Mufattah, narrated to us Muhammad bin Musa Al-Dulabi, narrated to us Al-Qasim bin Yahya, from Ibn Arqam, from Al-Zuhri, from Salim bin Abdullah, from Ibn Umar, he said: We found in the book of Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... The Hadith.

text: Hanbal? That Hadith, Salim used to narrate it. Imam Ahmad said: I heard it myself from Ya'la bin Ubayd, from Yahya bin Sa'id (1). He said: It reached me from Salim (2). 365 - What has been related regarding the charity of sheep. The Hadith of Su'r bin Daysam, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding the charity of sheep (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah" 3/8, he said: Narrated to us Ya'la bin Ubayd, from Yahya bin Sa'id, he said: It reached us that Salim used to say: We have the book of Umar regarding the charity of camels and sheep when the book of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz came to us. It was in the book which Umar bin Abd al-Aziz wrote when he sent them to collect charity: If it exceeds one hundred and twenty, then in every fifty is a Hiqqah and in every forty is a Bint Labun. 
2. "Ilal Abdullah" (550). 
3. Narrated by Abu Dawood (1581), he said: Narrated to us Al-Hasan bin Ali, narrated to us Waki', from Zakariyya bin Ishaq Al-Makki, from Amr bin Abi Sufyan Al-Jumahi, from Muslim bin Thafnah Al-Yashkuri. Al-Hasan said: Rawh says: Muslim bin Shu'bah. He said: Nafi' bin Alqamah appointed my father over the leadership of his people, so he ordered him to collect charity from them. He said: So my father sent me with a group of them, and I came to an old man called Su'r bin Daysam. I said: My father sent me to you - meaning: to take charity from you. He said: Son of my brother, which manner (of collection) do you take? I said: We select until we inspect the udders of the sheep. He said: Son of my brother, I will tell you that I was in one of these valleys during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with sheep of mine, and two men on a camel came to me. They said to me: We are the messengers of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to you, so that you pay the charity of your sheep. I said: What is due on me in them? They said: A sheep. So I intended towards a sheep whose place I knew, full of milk and fat, and brought it out to them. They said: This is a pregnant sheep (Shafi'), and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade us from taking a pregnant one. I said: Then what will you take? They said: A young female goat (Anaq Jadh'ah) or a two-year-old (Thaniyyah). He said: So I intended towards a goat that had not conceived yet (Mu'tat) - and the Mu'tat is the one that has not given birth but it is time for her birth - and I brought it out to them. They said: Hand it to us. So they put it with them on their camel, then departed.

text: Imam Ahmad said: Waki' made a mistake in it - meaning: Muslim bin Thafnah - it is only Muslim bin Shu'bah (1). 366 - What has been related regarding the Zakat of crops. There are two Hadiths in it: First: The Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "In what the sky and springs water or was 'athari (naturally watered by roots), is the tithe (one-tenth), and what was watered by transport (animals/machinery) is half of the tithe" (2). Imam Ahmad said: In the Hadith of Yunus there are denounced things (Munkarat) from Al-Zuhri, among them: From Salim from his father raised (to the Prophet): "In what the sky waters is the tithe" (3). And once he preferred the narration of the Waqf (stopped at the companion) on Ibn Umar (4). And he said once: This Hadith, no one narrated it from Ibn Wahb except the elders (Kibar). Abu Bakr Al-Isma'ili said regarding this Hadith: Ahmad bin Hanbal spoke about Abu Hammam when he narrated it from Ibn Wahb (5).
foot_note:

3. "Siyar A'lam al-Nubala" 6/299, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 32/555, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 6/284. 
4. "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 259-260. 
5. "Tarikh Baghdad" 13/443, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 31/25-26, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 6/88. I say: The text (Matn) is established and authentic; Muslim (981) narrated it via Abu Al-Zubayr who narrated to him that he heard Jabir bin Abdullah... The Hadith, raised (to the Prophet).

text: Second: The Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib, like it (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith, I see it as fabricated; he denounced it from the Hadith of Muhammad bin Salim (2). 367 - Zakat of Vegetables. The Hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, as Mawquf (stopped at him): There is no Zakat in vegetables: herbs, cucumbers, and apples (3). Imam Ahmad said: Qais and Ma'mar narrated it from Abu Ishaq, and he said: Abd
foot_note:
1. (1) "Musnad Ahmad" 1/145 from Abdullah bin Ahmad: Narrated to me Uthman bin Abi Shaybah, narrated to us Jarir, from Muhammad bin Salim, from Abu Ishaq, from Asim bin Damrah, from Ali, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
2. "Al-'Ilal" narration of Abdullah (1332), "Musnad Ahmad" 1/145, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/170. I say: The text has a supporting evidence in "Sahih Muslim" (981) via Amr bin Al-Harith that Abu Al-Zubayr narrated to him that he heard Jabir bin Abdullah mentioning that he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "In what the rivers and clouds water is the tithes, and in what was watered by the waterwheel is half of the tithe." I say: This supporting evidence is disturbed by what Al-Nasa'i mentioned as in "Awn al-Ma'bud" 4/340. He said: And Ibn Jurayj narrated it from Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir as his statement, and we do not know anyone who raised it (to the Prophet) other than Amr bin Al-Harith, just as the Hadith of Ibn Jurayj is closer to correctness. Benefit: Ibn Rajab recounted in "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 259 - 260: If Salim and Nafi' differ regarding the Hadith of Ibn Umar, which one takes precedence? Salim raised three Hadiths which Nafi' stopped (made Mawquf), so Imam Ahmad, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Daraqutni chose the saying of Nafi' regarding the Waqf (stopping), and Ibn Abd al-Barr said: The people preferred the saying of Salim in raising them. 
3. Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq 4/120, from Qais bin Al-Rabi', from Abu Ishaq, from Asim bin Damrah, from Ali.

text: Imam Ahmad said: Denounced [Munkar]. And he said: Talhah bin Zaid had stayed with Shu'bah, he is nothing, he used to fabricate Hadith, and this Bishr bin Numair is nothing (1). 370 - What has been related regarding the virtue of Al-Manihah (lending an animal for milk). Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever grants a gift of silver (money), or grants silver, or guides through a path, or gives milk to drink, it is for him equivalent to freeing a slave or a soul" (2). Imam Ahmad said: Shu'bah did not hear from Talhah except this Hadith (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Ilal Ahmad, narration of Al-Marwazi" (275). Benefit: Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Al-Zad" 2/13-14 with modification: The people of knowledge differed regarding these Hadiths and their ruling. Al-Bukhari said: There is nothing regarding the Zakat of honey that is authentic. Al-Tirmidhi said: Not much is authentic from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in this chapter. Ibn al-Mundhir said: There is no Hadith established from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding the obligation of charity on honey, nor is there consensus, so there is no Zakat in it. Al-Shafi'i said: The Hadith stating there is a tithe (one-tenth) in honey is weak, and that the tithe is not taken from it is weak except from Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. These (scholars) said: And all Hadiths of obligation are defective. As for the Hadith of Ibn Umar, it is from the narration of Sadaqah bin Abdullah bin Musa bin Yasar, from Nafi' from him, and Ahmad and Ibn Ma'in weakened Sadaqah. Al-Bukhari said: It is from Nafi' from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, as Mursal. Al-Nasa'i said: Sadaqah is nothing, and this is a denounced Hadith. Issue: Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Al-Zad" 2/15: Malik and Al-Shafi'i held the view that there is no charity in honey, while Ahmad and Abu Hanifa and a group held the view that there is Zakat in honey, and they considered that these narrations strengthen each other. 
2. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 4/285, he said: Narrated to us Affan, narrated to us Shu'bah, he said: Talhah informed me, he said: I heard Abd al-Rahman bin Awsajah, from Al-Bara', raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
3. "Jami' al-Tahsil" 196, "Ilal Abdullah" (1919).

text: 371 - What has been related regarding the spending of a woman from her husband's house. Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "If a woman gives charity from her husband's house" (1). Imam Ahmad said: When asked: Did Abu Wa'il hear from Aisha? He said: I do not know, Masruq was introduced between him and her (2) for various things, and he mentioned this Hadith (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (671), he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Al-Muthanna, narrated to us Muhammad bin Ja'far, narrated to us Shu'bah, from Amr bin Murrah, he said: I heard Abu Wa'il narrating from Aisha, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "If a woman gives charity from her husband's house, she has a reward for it, and for the husband is the like of that, and for the storekeeper is the like of that, and none of them diminishes anything from the reward of the other; for him is what he earned and for her is what she spent." 
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1437), he said: Narrated to us Qutaybah bin Sa'id, narrated to us Jarir, from Al-A'mash, from Abu Wa'il, from Masruq, from Aisha, raised (to the Prophet) with it.

text: 372 - What has been related regarding who Zakat is lawful for and the limit of wealth (Ghin'a). There are two Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever asks people while he has what suffices him, will come on the Day of Resurrection with his asking as lacerations" or "scratches" or "scars on his face." It was said: O Messenger of Allah: And what suffices him? He said: "Fifty Dirhams or its value in gold" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Good (Hasan), and to it we go (adhere) regarding charity (2). And he said once: The Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (3) strengthens the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud (4). And once he supported it by the fact that Sufyan narrated it from Zubaid, from Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Yazid (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (650), he said: Narrated to us Qutaybah and Ali bin Hajar. Qutaybah said: Narrated to us Sharik, and Ali said: Informed us Sharik - and the meaning is one - from Hakim bin Jubayr, from Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Yazid, from his father, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... The Hadith. 
2. "Al-Tamhid" 4/123, "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 197. 
3. Narrated by Abu Dawood (1628), he said: Narrated to us Qutaybah bin Sa'id and Hisham bin Ammar, they said: Narrated to us Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Rijal, from Umarah bin Ghaziyyah, from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Sa'id Al-Khudri, from his father Abu Sa'id, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever asks while he has the value of an Uqiyyah (ounce) has indeed begged insistently." So I said: My she-camel, Al-Yaqutah, is better than an Uqiyyah. Hisham said: Better than forty Dirhams. So I returned and did not ask him for anything. Hisham added in his Hadith: And the Uqiyyah during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was forty Dirhams. 
4. "Al-Tamhid" 4/124. 
5. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (651), he said: Narrated to us Mahmud bin Ghaylan, narrated to us Yahya bin Adam, narrated to us Sufyan, from Hakim bin Jubayr with this Hadith. So Abdullah bin Uthman, the companion of Shu'bah, said to him: If only someone other than Hakim narrated this Hadith. Sufyan said to him: And what is wrong with Hakim that Shu'bah does not narrate from him? He said: Yes. Sufyan said: I heard Zubaid narrating this from Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman.

Ibn Mahdi said: His Hadiths are few and contain denounced things. Abu Zur'ah said: There is something in his opinion, his place is truthfulness if Allah wills, Shu'bah abandoned him. Al-Juzajani said: A liar. It was said to Shu'bah: Why do you not narrate from Hakim bin Jubayr? He said: I fear the Fire. Benefit: Shu'bah abandoned him because of this Hadith. Meaning: That this Hadith is not established according to Shu'bah. Ibn Hibban said in "Al-Majruhin" 1/346 after mentioning his Hadith while denouncing it: It has no known path nor narration except from the Hadith of Hakim bin Jubayr. Also, Ibn Rajab quoted in "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 197 Ibn Ma'in's denouncement of the Hadith of Zubaid and others. There is a supporting evidence for the text in "Sahih Muslim" (1040) from the path of Ibn Umar that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Asking does not cease for one of you until he meets Allah with not a shred of flesh on his face." Issue: Al-Khattabi said in "Ma'alim al-Sunan" 2/48: As for defining the wealth with which charity becomes forbidden as fifty Dirhams, a group of the people of knowledge went to this view and saw it as the limit of wealth for whom charity is forbidden, among them Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, Ahmad bin Hanbal, and Ishaq bin Rahwayh. Others refused to hold this view and weakened the Hadith for the defect mentioned by Yahya bin Adam, =

text: 373 - What has been related regarding the one for whom charity is not lawful. There are three Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Ubaydullah bin Adi bin Al-Khiyar, may Allah be pleased with him: "There is no share in it for a rich person nor for a strong earner" (1). Imam Ahmad said: How excellent is this Hadith, it is the best of them in chain (2). Second: Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Charity is not lawful for a rich person, nor for one of sound strength" (3).
foot_note:
1. = They said: What Sufyan narrated does not contain a statement that he connected it (made it Musnad), he only said: 'Zubaid narrated to us from Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Yazid' only. They said: And there is nothing in the Hadith stating that whoever possesses fifty Dirhams, charity is not lawful for him; rather, it implies that he disliked it, and that is because asking is only for necessity, and there is no necessity for one who finds what suffices him for his time to ask. Malik and Al-Shafi'i said: There is no known limit for wealth; rather, the condition of the person is considered by his capacity and ability. If he suffices with what he has, charity is forbidden for him, and if he is in need, it is lawful for him. Al-Shafi'i said: A man might be rich with a Dirham due to earnings, while a thousand would not suffice him due to his weakness in himself and his large family. The scholars of opinion (Ashab al-Ra'y) set the limit at two hundred Dirhams, which is the Nisab (minimum amount) at which Zakat becomes obligatory. We were only commanded to take Zakat from the rich and give it to the poor, and this applies if it is established that he is rich possessing the Nisab upon which Zakat is obligatory on him, then he has exited the definition of the poor person who deserves to take Zakat. 
1. They asked him for some of it, so he raised his gaze at us and lowered it, and saw us to be sturdy, so he said... and he mentioned it.

3. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1839), he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Al-Sabah, informed us Abu Bakr bin Ayyash, from Abu Husain, from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd, from Abu Hurairah raised (to the Prophet), with it.

text: Imam Ahmad said: Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd did not hear from Abu Hurairah (1). Third: Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, similar to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (2). Imam Ahmad said: I do not know anything authentic in it (3).

2. I did not find it via Amr bin Shu'aib, from his father, from his grandfather as Ibn Qudamah cited it in "Al-Mughni" and attributed it to Al-Tirmidhi and Abu Dawood. I say: This Hadith is not in them; rather there is another source. Al-Tirmidhi (652) narrated it, he said: Narrated to us Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Bashar, narrated to us Abu Dawood Al-Tayalisi, narrated to us Sufyan bin Sa'id, H. And narrated to us Mahmud bin Ghaylan, narrated to us Abd al-Razzaq, informed us Sufyan, from Sa'd bin Ibrahim, from Rayhan bin Yazid, from Abdullah bin Amr, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
3. "Al-Mughni" 2/525, 7/315. Issue: Ibn Abd al-Barr said in "Al-Tamhid" 4/120-121: Al-Athram said: I heard Abu Abdullah - meaning Ahmad bin Hanbal - being asked about begging, when is it lawful? He said: If he does not have what provides him lunch and dinner, based on the Hadith of Sahl bin Al-Hanzaliyyah. It was said to Abu Abdullah: What if he is compelled to beg? He said: It is permissible. It was said to him: What if he refrains (out of modesty)? He said: That is better. Then he said: I do not think anyone dies of hunger; Allah brings him his provision. Then he mentioned the Hadith of Abu Sa'id: "Whoever refrains, Allah makes him content" and the Hadith of Abu Dharr that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Refrain." He said: And I heard Abu Abdullah, and he mentioned the Hadith of Ubaydullah bin Adi bin Al-Khiyar regarding the two men who came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... the Hadith. Then he said: He might be strong but not earning, possessing no craft in his hand, and unable to do anything; for this person charity is lawful even if he is strong, if he is not earning. But if he is able to earn, then begging is restricted for him. If his matter is hidden from you and you do not know whether he earns or not, you give him and inform him of what is forbidden for him.

text: 374 - What has been related regarding the limit of wealth (Ghin'a). Hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever asks a request while having sufficient wealth, he asks for an abundance of the heated stones of Hell." They said: What is sufficient wealth? He said: "Dinner for a night" (1). Imam Ahmad said: His Hadiths are falsehoods (Abatil), meaning Al-Hasan bin Dhakwan; he narrates from Habib bin Abi Thabit. So it was said to him: Yes, other than a strange Hadith from Asim bin Damrah, from Ali regarding begging and the stud fee... So Imam Ahmad said: He did not hear from Habib bin Abi Thabit; these are only the Hadiths of Amr bin Khalid Al-Wasiti (2).
