text: charity is a purification, so the Jew and the Christian, what purification is there for them?! (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) "Masa'il Salih" (1151). Benefit: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 3/369-375 with modification: Ibn Abd al-Barr said: The narrators did not differ from Malik regarding this addition, except that Qutaybah bin Sa'id narrated it from Malik without it. Abu Qilabah Al-Raqashi, Muhammad bin Waddah, Ibn Al-Salah and those who followed him generalized that Malik was alone in it excluding the companions of Nafi', and this is critiqued by the narration of Umar bin Nafi' which Al-Bukhari narrated, and likewise Muslim narrated it via Al-Dahhak bin Uthman, from Nafi' with this addition. Abu Awanah said in his "Sahih": No one said in it: (from the Muslims) other than Malik and Al-Dahhak. But the narration of Umar bin Nafi' refutes him as well. Abu Dawood said after narrating it via Malik and Umar bin Nafi': Abdullah Al-Umari narrated it from Nafi' and said: (on every Muslim). And Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman Al-Jumahi narrated it from Ubaydullah bin Umar, from Nafi' and said in it: (from the Muslims). And what is famous from Ubaydullah does not contain: (from the Muslims). Al-Tirmidhi said in "Al-Jami'" after the narration of Malik: More than one narrated it from Nafi' and did not mention in it (from the Muslims). And he said in "Al-'Ilal" which is at the end of Al-Jami': Ayyub, Ubaydullah bin Umar, and more than one of the Imams narrated this Hadith from Nafi' and did not mention in it: (from the Muslims), and some of them narrated from Nafi' similar to the narration of Malik, from those whose memorization is not relied upon. Al-Nawawi said in "Sharh Muslim": Two trustworthy narrators other than Malik narrated it: Umar bin Nafi' and Al-Dahhak. Al-Hafiz said: It has reached us from the narration of a group other than them, among them Kathir bin Farqad, Yunus bin Yazid, Al-Mu'alla bin Ismail, Ibn Abi Layla, and Ubaydullah bin Umar. These paths refute Abu Dawood in his indication that Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman was alone in it from Ubaydullah bin Umar, but it is possible that some of its narrators carried the wording of Ibn Abi Layla onto the wording of Ubaydullah. And it has been differed upon regarding Ayyub as it was differed upon regarding Ubaydullah bin Umar: Ibn Abd al-Barr mentioned that Ahmad bin Khalid mentioned from some of his Sheikhs from Yusuf the judge, from Sulaiman bin Harb, from Hammad, from Ayyub, so he mentioned in it "from the Muslims". Ibn Abd al-Barr said: And this is an error, and what is preserved in it from Ayyub does not contain 'from the Muslims'. In summary, there is no one among those who narrated =

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 379 - The type which is permissible to give in Zakat al-Fitr. Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, and in it: Whoever gives wheat, it is accepted from him, and whoever gives raisins, it is accepted from him, and whoever gives sult (a type of barley), it is accepted from him (1). Imam Ahmad said: Muhammad bin Sirin did not hear from Ibn Abbas (2).
foot_note:
1. = this addition like Malik; because he did not agree with Ayyub and Ubaydullah in adding it. I say: Ibn Rajab said in "Sharh 'Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 423: What the speech of Imam Ahmad indicates in this chapter is that the addition of a wording by a trustworthy narrator in a Hadith from among other trustworthy narrators, if he is not superior in memorization and verification over others who did not mention the addition and he was not followed in it, then his solitary report is not accepted, even if he is trustworthy and superior in memorization. 
1. Narrated by Al-Daraqutni 2/144, he said: Narrated to us Al-Hussein bin Ismail, narrated to us Abu Al-Ash'ath, narrated to us Al-Thaqafi, narrated to us Hisham, from Muhammad bin Sirin, from Ibn Abbas, he said: We were commanded that the charity of Ramadan be given on the small and the large, the free and the slave, a Sa' of food... The Hadith. And in it he said: And I think he said: Whoever gives flour, it is accepted from him, and whoever gives sawiq (mush), it is accepted from him. 
2. "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/407.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 380 - What has been related regarding half a Sa' of wheat or burr (wheat). Hadith of Tha'labah bin Abi Su'ayr: "A Sa' of burr or wheat on every two" (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic. It is only Mursal (hurried/disconnected), Ma'mar and Ibn Jurayj narrate it from Al-Zuhri as Mursal. It was said to him: From whose side is this? He said: From the side of Al-Nu'man bin Rashid, he is not strong in Hadith, and he weakened the Hadith of Ibn Abi Su'ayr, and I asked him about Ibn Abi Su'ayr, is he known? He said: Who knows Ibn Abi Su'ayr?! He is not known (2). And he said once: Al-Nu'man bin Rashid narrates it and says from Tha'labah bin Abi Su'ayr from his father, and others do not raise it nor say from his father, and it is not preserved (Mahfuz), and the generality of the Hadith does not contain 'from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him' (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (1619), he said: Narrated to us Musaddad and Sulaiman bin Dawood Al-Ataki, they said: Narrated to us Hammad bin Zaid from Al-Nu'man bin Rashid, from Al-Zuhri. Musaddad said: From Tha'labah bin Abdullah Ibn Abi Su'ayr, from his father. And Sulaiman bin Dawood said: From Abdullah bin Tha'labah - or Tha'labah bin Abdullah - bin Abi Su'ayr, from his father, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "A Sa' of burr or wheat on every two, small or large, free or slave, male or female. As for your rich, Allah purifies him, and as for your poor, Allah the Exalted returns to him more than what he gave." Sulaiman added in his Hadith: "rich or poor". 
2. "Al-Mughni" 4/287, "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/409. 
3. "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/54, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/244.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 381 - What has been related regarding the definition of the Sa' (a unit of measurement). Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: The Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was established that for washing from sexual impurity (Ghusl), it is a Sa', and for ablution (Wudu), it is two Ratls, and the Sa' is eight Ratls (1). Imam Ahmad said: False [Batil] (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Daraqutni in "Al-Sunan" 2/153, he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Naqqash, narrated to us Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Al-Hajjaj bin Rishdin, narrated to us Yahya bin Sulaiman Al-Ju'fi, narrated to us Salih bin Musa Al-Talhi, narrated to us Mansur, from Ibrahim, from Al-Aswad, from Aisha, she said: The Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was established... The Hadith. 
2. "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (2161). Benefit: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath": The Sa' is a vessel that holds five and a third Ratls according to the Baghdadi standard.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Book of Fasting 382 - What has been related regarding the virtue of Ramadan. There are two Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Utbah bin Farqad, may Allah be pleased with him: "In it, the gates of Paradise are opened, the gates of the Fire are closed, the devils are chained, and a caller calls out every night: 'O seeker of good, come forth; and O seeker of evil, desist'" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Sufyan used to make a mistake in this Hadith; Utbah did not hear it from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; a man (2) narrated to Utbah from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him (3). Second: Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, similar to it, but it does not contain: "And a caller calls out" (4). Imam Ahmad said: Ibn Ishaq did not say in it: 'From his father' (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/129-130, he said: Informed us Muhammad bin Mansur, he said: Narrated to us Sufyan, from Ata' bin Al-Sa'ib, from Arfajah, he said: We visited Utbah bin Farqad and we discussed the month of Ramadan, so he said: What are you discussing? We said: The month of Ramadan. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say... The Hadith. 
2. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/130, he said: Informed us Muhammad bin Bashar, he said: Narrated to us Muhammad, he said: Narrated to us Shu'bah, from Ata' bin Al-Sa'ib, from Arfajah, he said: I was in the house of Utbah bin Farqad and I wanted to narrate a Hadith, and there was a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who seemed more entitled to the Hadith than me, so the man narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... The Hadith. 
3. "Al-'Ilal" narration of Abdullah (4738). 
4. Narrated by Ahmad 2/281, he said: Narrated to us Ya'qub, narrated to me my father, from Ibn Ishaq, he said: It was mentioned that Ibn Shihab said: Narrated to me Ibn Abi Anas that he heard Abu Hurairah... The Hadith. 
5. "Musnad Ahmad" 2/281.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 383 - Fasting the month of Ramadan upon the previous nations. Hadith of Daghfal bin Hanzalah Al-Sadusi, may Allah be pleased with him: "Fasting the month of Ramadan was obligatory upon the Christians" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Daghfal bin Hanzalah has no Companionship (Suhba); from where would he have Companionship?! This was a man of genealogy (2).
foot_note:
1. = Benefit: Imam Ahmad pointed out the error of Ibn Ishaq's narration for contradicting the companions of Al-Zuhri, among them Ma'mar, Salih, and Yunus, by mentioning 'his father' through listing the narrations of the Hadith in "Al-Musnad". Al-Nasa'i narrated this Hadith via Ibn Ishaq mentioning 'his father', then said: It is a mistake, and Ibn Ishaq did not hear it from Al-Zuhri; refer to "Al-Sunan" 4/128. I say: The text of the Hadith is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari (1899) and Muslim (1079) narrated it via Abu Hurairah, and the wording is Muslim's: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "When Ramadan comes, the gates of mercy are opened, the gates of Hell are closed, and the devils are chained." 
1. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 8/134 (8193), he said: Narrated to us Musa bin Harun, narrated to us Ishaq bin Rahwayh, narrated to us Mu'adh bin Hisham, narrated to me my father, from Qatadah, from Al-Hasan, from Daghfal bin Hanzalah Al-Sadusi, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Fasting the month of Ramadan was obligatory upon the Christians, and a king was over them who fell ill, so they said: If Allah cures him, we will surely add eight days. Then there was a king over them after him who ate meat and had pain, so they said: If Allah cures him, we will surely add eight days. Then there was a king over them after him who said: We will not leave these days without completing them and making our fast in the spring. So he did so, and it became fifty days." 
2. "Mizan al-I'tidal" 2/217, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 8/487, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 2/575, "Al-Marasil" by Ibn Abi Hatim (198).

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 384 - What has been related regarding fasting being upon sighting the crescent or completing the count. Hadith of Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Do not advance the month until you see the crescent or complete the count, then fast until you see the crescent or complete the count" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is Sufyan and others from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Meaning: Sufyan and others narrate it from Mansur, from Rib'i, from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. There is nothing of this (attribution to Hudhayfah), meaning: his saying: 'from Hudhayfah'. Meaning: Hudhayfah is not preserved [Mahfuz] in this Hadith (2). And once: Ahmad preferred the narration of Al-Thawri (3) over the narration of Jarir (4). And once: Ahmad weakened it and said: The mention of Hudhayfah is not preserved (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (2326), he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Al-Sabah Al-Bazzar, narrated to us Jarir bin Abd al-Hamid Al-Dabbi, from Mansur bin Al-Mu'tamir, from Rib'i bin Hirash, from Hudhayfah, raised (to the Prophet). 
2. "Masa'il Abu Dawood" (1873). 
3. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/13, he said: Informed us Muhammad bin Bashar, he said: Narrated to us Abd al-Rahman, he said: Narrated to us Sufyan, from Mansur, from Rib'i, from some of the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
4. "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/198. 
5. "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/439, "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/75, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd al-Hadi 2/289. I say: The text of the Hadith is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari narrated something similar number (1907) from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The month is twenty-nine nights, so do not fast until you see it, and if it is obscured from you, then complete the count as thirty."

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 385 - The month can be twenty-nine. Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him: "The month is like this, and like this, and like this" ten, and ten, and nine at one time (1). Imam Ahmad said: Authentic [Sahih]. And regarding the Hadith of Ismail bin Abi Khalid: The Hadith of Sa'd: "The month is like this, like this." Yahya Al-Qattan said (2): We wanted him to say 'from his father' but he refused. Ahmad said: Ismail used to connect its chain sometimes and sometimes he would not connect it. And Za'idah narrated it from his father. It was said to him: Waki' has narrated it, and Yahya says what he says? He said: Za'idah has narrated it. He also said: Abdullah (3) narrated it from his father, and Ibn Bishr and Za'idah (4), and others (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Muslim (1086), he said: Narrated to us Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah, narrated to us Muhammad bin Bishr, narrated to us Ismail bin Abi Khalid, narrated to me Muhammad bin Sa'd from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, with it. 
2. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/138, he said: And Yahya bin Sa'id and others narrated it from Ismail, from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... The Hadith. 
3. Narrated by Muslim (1086), he said: And narrated to me Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Quhzad, narrated to us Ali bin Al-Hasan bin Shaqiq and Salamah bin Sulaiman, they said: Informed us Abdullah - meaning: Ibn Al-Mubarak - informed us Ismail bin Abi Khalid, from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from his father, raised (to the Prophet) with it. I say: In the words of Imam Ahmad, he mentioned 'Abdullah, from his father', so perhaps the word 'his father' is a misspelling from the Fatawa, and also 'Za'idah from his father', the mention of 'his father' is an addition, so perhaps it is a misspelling, and Allah knows best. 
4. Narrated by Muslim (1086), he said: Narrated to me Al-Qasim bin Zakariya, narrated to us Hussein bin Ali, from Za'idah, from Ismail, from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from his father, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
5. "Al-Fatawa" 25/164. I say: There was a difference regarding this Hadith upon Ismail bin Abi Khalid, =

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 386 - What has been related regarding 'The day of your fasting is the day of your sacrifice.' The Hadith: "The day of your fasting is the day of your sacrifice, the day of the beginning of your year" (1). Imam Ahmad said: It has no basis (2).
foot_note:
1. = for Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan, Waki', and Muhammad bin Ubayd narrated it from him, from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, as Mursal (hurried/disconnected), omitting his father Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. And Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Za'idah, and Muhammad bin Bishr narrated it from him as connected (Mawsul). So the apparent meaning of Imam Ahmad's words is that those who narrated it as Mursal fell short in the chain, and those who narrated it as connected perfected the chain. Benefit: Al-Daraqutni found a defect in this Hadith in "Al-Ilzamat wa Al-Tatabbu'" (63) due to the Irsal (disconnection), where he said: The Hadith of Ismail, from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from his father: "The month is like this..." Yahya and Waki' narrated it as Mursal from Ismail. And Abu Hatim said in "Al-'Ilal" (754): The connected narration from Muhammad bin Sa'd, from his father, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is more likely; because the trustworthy narrators agreed upon it. I say: The addition from a trustworthy narrator may be accepted with contextual indicators; so for Imam Ahmad, it is not absolute. Rather, if a trustworthy Hafiz (preserver) added something, he would not accept it from him unless he was corroborated, as he did with the addition of "from the Muslims" in Zakat al-Fitr when Malik bin Anas was alone in it, and Allah knows best. 
1. I did not find it, and Al-Ajluni mentioned it in "Kashf al-Khafa" 2/398 (3263), "Al-Asrar Al-Marfu'ah fi Al-Akhbar Al-Mawdu'ah" (1103). 
2. "Al-Manar al-Munif" p. 119, "Asna al-Matalib" number (1157), "Al-Mawdu'at" by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/633, "Bada'i al-Fawa'id" 3/195. Benefit: Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Fatawa" 25/179-180: Some of them narrate from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: 'Narrated to us', which is not known in any of the books of Islam, nor did any scholar ever narrate that he said: "The day of your fasting is the day of your sacrifice, the day of the beginning of your year."

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 387 - What has been related regarding 'There is no fasting for the one who does not determine it from the night.' Hadith of Hafsah, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever does not determine fasting from the night before Fajr, there is no fasting for him" (1). Imam Ahmad said: That chain is not of that (strength) to me, except that from Ibn Umar (2) and Hafsah (3), they are two good chains (4). He said once when asked: He argued using the statement of Ibn Umar and Hafsah. Meaning: Mawquf (stopped) at them (5). And once it was said to Imam Ahmad: Yahya bin Ayyub Al-Misri raised it (to the Prophet), from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr, from Al-Zuhri, from Salim, from Ibn Umar, from Hafsah, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and it was as if he did not affirm it (6).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/196, he said: Informed me Al-Qasim bin Zakariya bin Dinar, he said: Narrated to us Sa'id bin Shurahbil, he said: Informed us Al-Layth, from Yahya bin Ayyub, from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr, from Salim bin Abdullah, from Abdullah bin Umar, from Hafsah, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
2. Narrated by Malik in "Al-Muwatta" p. 130, he said: Narrated to us Nafi' that Ibn Umar said: "No one fasts except the one who resolves upon fasting before Fajr." 
3. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i 4/197, he said: Informed us Muhammad bin Hatim, he said: Informed us Hibban, he said: Informed us Abdullah from Sufyan bin Uyainah and Ma'mar, from Al-Zuhri, from Hamzah bin Abdullah bin Umar, from his father, from Hafsah, she said: "There is no fasting for the one who does not resolve upon fasting before Fajr." 
4. "Al-Mughni" 4/334, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/188, "Al-Farusiyyah" p. 189, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/282. 
5. "Al-Masa'il" narration of Abdullah (705, 725), "Masa'il Abu Dawood" (614, 615). 
6. "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" by Ibn Abd al-Hadi 2/282.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: And once: Hafsah narrated it and some of them raised it (1). 388 - What has been related regarding Kohl (antimony) at the time of sleep for the fasting person. Hadith of Ma'bad bin Hawdhah, may Allah be pleased with him: That he ordered perfumed Ithmid (antimony) at the time of sleep and said: "Let the fasting person avoid it" (2). Imam Ahmad said: This is a denounced [Munkar] Hadith (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Al-Imam Ahmad" narration of Abdullah (706). Issue: Ibn Qudamah said in "Al-Mughni" 4/333: Voluntary fasting is permissible with an intention from the day according to Ahmad, Abu Hanifa, and Al-Shafi'i, and that was narrated from Abu Darda, Abu Talha, Ibn Mas'ud, Hudhayfah, Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Al-Nakha'i, and the scholars of opinion. Malik and Dawood said: It is not permissible except with an intention from the night. 
2. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2377), he said: Narrated to us Al-Nufayli, narrated to us Ali bin Thabit, narrated to me Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Nu'man bin Ma'bad bin Hawdhah, from his father, from his grandfather, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... so he mentioned it. 
3. "Masa'il Abu Dawood" (1891).

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 389 - What has been related regarding kissing for the fasting person. There are two Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him: And in it: I kissed while I was fasting. He said: "What do you think if you rinsed your mouth with water while you were fasting?" I said: There is no harm in it. He said: "Then what?" (1). Imam Ahmad weakened this Hadith. And he said: This is wind (air); there is nothing in this (2). Second: Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, would not refrain from anything of my face while he was fasting. It was said to Ahmad: The Hadith of Yahya bin Zakariya (3) and Waki' from Zakariya (4). He said: One of them is Al-Abbas bin Dharih. And he said: The other is from Salih Al-Asadi, from Al-Sha'bi, from Muhammad bin
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (2385), he said: Narrated to us Ahmad bin Yunus, narrated to us Al-Layth, H. And narrated to us Isa bin Hammad, informed us Al-Layth bin Sa'd, from Bukayr bin Abdullah, from Abd al-Malik bin Sa'id, from Jabir bin Abdullah, he said: Umar bin Al-Khattab said: I became excited and kissed while I was fasting, so I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have done a grave matter today... so he mentioned it. 
2. "Al-Mughni" 4/361. 
3. Narrated by Ahmad in his "Musnad" 6/162, he said: Narrated to us Yahya bin Zakariya, narrated to me my father, from Salih Al-Asadi, from Al-Sha'bi, from Muhammad bin Al-Ash'ath bin Qais, from Aisha... The Hadith. 
4. "Musnad Ahmad" 6/162, he said: Narrated to us Waki', from Zakariya, from Al-Abbas bin Dharih, from Al-Sha'bi, from Muhammad bin Al-Ash'ath bin Qais, from Aisha, like it.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: Al-Ash'ath, from Aisha... The Hadith. He said: Perhaps he heard it from both of them. Meaning: From Salih Al-Asadi and Abbas bin Dharih (1). 390 - Dislike of exaggerating in sniffing water (Istinshaq) for the fasting person. Hadith of Laqit bin Sabrah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Perform Wudu thoroughly, go between the fingers, and exaggerate in sniffing water unless you are fasting" (2). It was said to Imam Ahmad: Do you affirm it? He said: Asim did not hear from him a Hadith like such. Meaning: He did not hear from him with much narration. Meaning: Asim bin Laqit is not famous in narrations from him (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Abu Dawood li al-Imam Ahmad" (2021). I say: The text of this Hadith is established and authentic; Al-Bukhari (1928) narrated it via Urwah, from Aisha, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to kiss some of his wives while he was fasting, then she laughed. Issue: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 4/153: Al-Nawawi said: Kissing during fasting is not forbidden for the one whose desire is not stirred by it, but leaving it is better. As for the one whose desire is stirred, it is forbidden for him according to the more correct view, and it was said: Disliked. Ibn Wahb narrated from Malik its permissibility in voluntary fasts but not obligatory ones. Al-Nawawi said: There is no disagreement that it does not invalidate the fast unless he ejaculates because of it. 
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (788), he said: Narrated to us Abd al-Wahhab bin Abd al-Hakam Al-Baghdadi Al-Warraq and Abu Ammar Al-Hussein bin Harith, they said: Narrated to us Yahya bin Sulaim, narrated to me Ismail bin Kathir, he said: I heard Asim bin Laqit bin Sabrah, from his father, he said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, inform me about ablution. He said: "Perform Wudu thoroughly, go between the fingers, and exaggerate..." so he mentioned it. 
3. "Masa'il Abu Dawood" (1924), "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 1/264.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 391 - What has been related regarding breaking the fast intentionally. Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever breaks a day of Ramadan without a concession or illness, fasting the entire eternity will not make up for it even if he fasted it" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not correct (2). And he said once: I do not know Abu Al-Mutawwis, nor Ibn Al-Mutawwis, and I do not know his Hadith from anyone else (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (723), he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Bashar, narrated to us Yahya bin Sa'id and Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi, they said: Narrated to us Sufyan, from Habib bin Abi Thabit, narrated to us Abu Al-Mutawwis, from his father, from Abu Hurairah... The Hadith. 
2. "Al-Mughni" 4/367. 
3. "Al-Farusiyyah" p. 190, "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 4/589. Issue: Abu Isa Al-Tirmidhi (724) said: Whoever breaks the fast intentionally by eating or drinking, the people of knowledge have differed regarding that. Some of them said: He must make up for it and perform expiation (Kaffarah), and they likened eating and drinking to sexual intercourse, and this is the view of Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, and Ishaq. And some of them said: He must make up for it and there is no expiation upon him; because expiation was only mentioned from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding sexual intercourse, and it was not mentioned from him regarding eating and drinking. And they said: Eating and drinking do not resemble sexual intercourse, and this is the view of Al-Shafi'i and Ahmad.

text: 392 - What has been related regarding breaking the fast before the setting of the sun. Hadith of Asma bint Abi Bakr, may Allah be pleased with them both: We broke our fast during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, on a cloudy day, then the sun rose (1). Imam Ahmad said: This is a strange [Gharib] Hadith (2). 393 - What has been related regarding the fasting person inducing vomit intentionally. Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: "Whoever is overcome by vomit while fasting, there is no makeup upon him, and whoever induces vomit, he must make up" (3). Imam Ahmad said when asked what is the most authentic thing regarding it? Meaning regarding: "Whoever is overcome by vomit while fasting." He said: Nafi' from Ibn Umar (4). I said to him: The Hadith of Hisham from Muhammad bin Sirin from Abu Hurairah? He said: There is nothing of this; it is only: "Whoever ate forgetfully - meaning: while fasting (5) -
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ibn Majah (1674), he said: Narrated to us Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah and Ali bin Muhammad, they said: Narrated to us Abu Usamah from Hisham bin Urwah, from Fatimah bint Al-Mundhir, from Asma bint Abi Bakr... The Hadith. 
2. "Tarikh Baghdad" 9/82, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 10/420. 
3. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2380), he said: Narrated to us Musaddad, narrated to us Isa bin Yunus, narrated to us Hisham bin Hassan, from Muhammad bin Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
4. "Al-Muwatta" p. 126 number (358) narration of Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaybani, he said: Informed us Malik, informed us Nafi' that Ibn Umar used to say: Whoever induces vomit while fasting, he must make up... The Hadith is Mawquf (stopped) at Ibn Umar. 
5. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1933), he said: Narrated to us Abdan, informed us Yazid bin Zurai', narrated to us Hisham, narrated to us Ibn Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "If he forgets and eats and drinks..." The Hadith.

text: then Allah fed him and gave him drink" (1). And he said once: Denounced [Munkar]. And he said: Isa narrated it and it is not in his book; he erred in it, and it is not from his Hadith (2).
foot_note:

I say: There is an indication of Ahmad's statement quoted from Abu Dawood in "Al-Sunan", but it is not found in Al-Khattabi's copy in "Ma'alim al-Sunan", except in Awwamah's copy of "Sunan Abi Dawood". 
2. "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/189 (883). Benefit: Al-Khattabi said regarding Imam Ahmad's statement 'There is nothing of this': Meaning that it is not preserved. I say: Among those who also weakened the Hadith are Al-Bukhari, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Bayhaqi. Issue: Al-Tirmidhi said 3/90: And the practice according to the people of knowledge is upon the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, and Al-Thawri, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq say by it.

text: 394 - What has been related regarding the fasting person being overcome by vomit. Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: "Three do not break the fast of the fasting person: Cupping, Vomiting, and Wet dream" (1). Imam Ahmad said: They said about Yazid bin Ja'dabah: That he said: A man came here - meaning: Madinah - so he went - meaning: Zaid bin Aslam - until he heard it from him. Ahmad said: It does not resemble the Hadith of the people of Madinah (2). And once: Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal said: My father used to weaken Abd al-Rahman bin Zaid bin Aslam; and that is because he narrated this Hadith, from his father, from Ata', from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri raised (to the Prophet) with it (3). And once: Ahmad spoke about him (4).

text: 395 - What has been related regarding the dislike of cupping for the fasting person. There are five Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him: "The cupper and the cupped have broken the fast." Imam Ahmad said: The most authentic thing narrated is the Hadith of Thawban from the narration of Yahya bin Abi Kathir (1), from Abu Qilaba, from Abu Asma, from Thawban (2). And he said once: Authentic [Sahih] (3). And he said once: The most authentic is the Hadith of Ibn Jurayj (4) from Makhul, from a Sheikh of the tribe, from Thawban (5). And he said once: The most authentic Hadith is the Hadith of Thawban. It was said to him: Then the Hadith of Abu Asma or Ma'dan (6)? He said: Makhul from a Sheikh of
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood (2367), he said: Narrated to us Musaddad, narrated to us Yahya, from Hisham, H. And narrated to us Ahmad bin Hanbal, narrated to us Hasan bin Musa, narrated to us Shaiban, both from Yahya from Abu Qilaba, from Abu Asma - meaning: Al-Rahbi - from Thawban, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... The Hadith. 
2. "Sunan al-Bayhaqi" 4/267, "Masa'il Ibn Hani" (646), "Tabaqat al-Hanabilah" 1/224, "Nasb al-Rayah" 3/42, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/193, "Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir" by Al-Bukhari 2/180.

4. Narrated by Ahmad 5/282, he said: Narrated to us Abd al-Razzaq and Ibn Bakr, they said: Informed us Ibn Jurayj and Rawh. Narrated to us Ibn Jurayj, informed me Makhul that a Sheikh from the tribe informed him that Thawban... The Hadith. 
5. "Sunan al-Bayhaqi" 4/267. 
6. Narrated by Al-Siraj 1/98, he said: Informed us Bukair bin Abi Al-Samt, narrated to us Qatadah, from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd, from Ma'dan, from Makhul, from a Sheikh of the tribe, from Thawban, raised (to the Prophet) with it.

text: the tribe from Thawban? Then he said: Everything narrated from Thawban is authentic [Sahih]. Meaning: The Hadith of Makhul (1). Second: Hadith of Shaddad, may Allah be pleased with him, similar to it (2). Imam Ahmad said: Authentic [Sahih] (3). And he said once: The most authentic thing narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is the Hadith of Shaddad; because Shaiban (4) combined both Hadiths together. Meaning: The Hadith of Thawban and the Hadith of Shaddad. It was said to him: Shaiban did not connect the Hadith of Shaddad, meaning: he omitted a man from its chain. He said: Even if he did not connect it, the two Hadiths became authentic when he combined them (5). Third: Hadith of Rafi' bin Khadij, may Allah be pleased with him: Similar to it (6).

5. "Al-Masa'il" narration of Abdullah (682), "Tabaqat al-Hanabilah" 1/185, "Al-Mughni" 4/351. 
6. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (774), he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Yahya, Muhammad bin Rafi' Al-Naysaburi, Mahmud bin Ghaylan, and Yahya bin Musa, they said: Narrated to us Abd al-Razzaq, from Ma'mar, from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Qarizh, from Al-Sa'ib bin Yazid, from Rafi' bin Khadij raised (to the Prophet) with it.

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith

text: Imam Ahmad said: Ma'mar was alone in that (1). And he said once: The most authentic thing is the Hadith of Rafi' bin Khadij (2). And he said once: The chain of the Hadith of Rafi' is good [Jayyid] (3). And once: Abd al-Razzaq narrated it alone (4). Fourth: Hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him... similar to it (5). Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Bakr, from Abu Rafi', from Abu Musa is a mistake; no one raised it (to the Prophet); it is only Bakr from Abu Al-Aliyah (6). Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith: "The cupper and the cupped have broken the fast" strengthens each other, and I hold this view (7).
foot_note:

2. "Sunan al-Tirmidhi" (774), "Masa'il Abdullah" (682), "Nasb al-Rayah" 3/43, "Al-Talkhis al-Habir" 2/193, "Al-'Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" 2/52-53, "Al-Fatawa" 25/255, "Al-Tahqiq" by Ibn al-Jawzi 5/165, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/318.

The Hadith.

text: And he said once: All of them are good. And once: There is no established Hadith in it (1). And once: The two Hadiths are with him (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Zad al-Ma'ad" 2/63. 
2. "Al-'Ilal" by Ibn Abi Hatim number (732). I say: Perhaps it is: The two Hadiths are authentic [Sahih] with him, and the word: (Sahih) was dropped, and Allah knows best. I say: This Hadith is among those about which there has been much discussion. Al-Marwazi (87) quoted Yahya bin Ma'in saying about this Hadith: No report is established in it. Imam Ahmad said: This speech contains recklessness. Also, Ibn Abi Hatim quoted in "Al-'Ilal" number (732) from his father that he said: This Hadith to me is false [Batil]; perhaps he meant the path of Rafi' mentioned or the entire Hadith. And in "Masa'il Abu Dawood from Ahmad" (626), Abu Dawood said: Ahmad debated regarding cupping for the fasting person, so he argued with the reports of the Companions and did not argue with anything narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. And the statements of Imam Ahmad contradict each other regarding which is most authentic, and his contradiction regarding the Hadith of Rafi' bin Khadij. Al-Bukhari went to authenticating it as more than one quoted from him, then he turned away from it in his "Jami'" and did not include it in "Al-Sahih", and included the Hadith of Ibn Abbas which opposes it. Al-Tirmidhi quoted after (774) from Al-Shafi'i that he said: It has been narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, that he was cupped while fasting, and it has been narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, that he said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken the fast," and I do not know either of these two Hadiths to be established. And Al-Bukhari, Ali bin Al-Madini, Al-Darimi, Ibn Rahwayh, and others authenticated this Hadith. I say: Sometimes the Imams apply 'Authenticity' to the jurisprudential practice, as Ibn Abd al-Barr said regarding the Hadith: "Its water is purifying, its dead are lawful," and as Imam Ahmad said regarding the Hadith of the mouse falling into ghee; sometimes with the addition of detail if the ghee is solid or liquid, and sometimes without detail, he said: Both are authentic. As for the aspect of its Hadith narration, Ahmad does not accept such an addition, so his saying 'both are authentic' refers to the jurisprudential practice, and sometimes referring to a narrator in the chain, as Abu Hatim said in "Al-'Ilal" regarding the Hadith: "Whoever performs ablution, well and good, and whoever performs Ghusl, then Ghusl =

book_title: Al-Jami' li 'Ulum al-Imam Ahmad - 'Ilal al-Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: is better." Authentic despite it being from the path of Al-Hasan from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. And sometimes in other forms, and Allah knows best. Benefit: Al-Zayla'i said in "Nasb al-Rayah" 3/52-53: In summary, this Hadith - I mean the Hadith: "The cupper has broken the fast" - was narrated from many paths and with many different disturbed chains, and it is closer to weakness than to authenticity, along with its lack of safety from an opponent more authentic than it or abrogating it. Imam Ahmad goes to it and speaks by it, and did not commit to its authenticity. What was narrated from him as Ibn Adi narrated in "Al-Kamil" in the biography of Sulaiman Al-Ashdaq with his chain to Ahmad bin Hanbal is that he said: The Hadiths of: "The cupper and the cupped have broken the fast" strengthen each other, and I hold this view. If he had anything authentic from them, he would have stopped at it. And his saying: The most authentic thing in this chapter is the Hadith of Rafi' does not imply its authenticity; rather its meaning is that it is less weak than others. The author of "Al-Tanqih" 2/319 said: Yahya bin Ma'in weakened this Hadith and said: It is a disturbed Hadith with no established Hadith in it. He said: When this speech reached Ahmad bin Hanbal, he said: This is recklessness. And Ishaq bin Rahwayh said: It is established from five aspects. And some Hafizs said: It is Mutawatir (mass transmitted). Fifth: Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: Similar to it (1). Imam Ahmad said: (When asked about this Hadith of his) He is a Sheikh who narrated from Qatadah, and he has Mursal narrations (2).

2. "Su'alat Abu Dawood" (323).

text: 396 - What has been related regarding the concession for cupping for the fasting person. There are two Hadiths in it: First: Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, and it has paths: The First Path: From a man from him that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was cupped in Ramadan after he said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken the fast" (1). Imam Ahmad said: The man meant is: Aban bin Abi Ayyash. Meaning: And he is not used as proof (2). Second: From Al-Suddi from him that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was cupped while fasting (3). Imam Ahmad said: This is denounced [Munkar]. Then he said: Al-Suddi from Anas? It was said to him: Yes. So he was amazed by this (4). Third: From Al-A'mash from him: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sent for a cupper named Abu Taybah, so he cupped him after Asr in Ramadan (5). Imam Ahmad said: This is a denounced [Munkar] Hadith (6). Second: Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, and it has paths:
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Daraqutni 2/183, he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Abu Al-Qasim Al-Muharibi, narrated to us Abu Sa'id Al-Ashajj, narrated to us Waki', narrated to us Yasin - or Khalaf - from a man, from Anas... so he mentioned it. 
2. "Zad al-Ma'ad" 2/62-63. 
3. Mentioned by Al-Khatib in his "Tarikh" 3/272 via Abu Awanah, from Al-Suddi, raised (to the Prophet) with it. 
4. "Zad al-Ma'ad" 2/63, "Tarikh Baghdad" 3/272. 
5. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" 6/93, he said: Narrated to us Muhammad bin Yahya bin Al-Mundhir, he said: Narrated to us Hani' bin Yahya, narrated to us Al-Rabi' bin Badr, he said: Narrated to us Al-A'mash, from Anas... The Hadith. 
6. "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 2/143.

text: The First Path: The path of Maymun bin Mahran from him: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was fasting (1). Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic (Sahih), and Yahya bin Sa'id denied it from Al-Ansari. The Hadiths of Maymun bin Mahran from Ibn Abbas are only about fifteen Hadiths. In a narration, he weakened him and said: The books of Al-Ansari were lost during the days of Al-Muntasir, so he used to narrate from the books of his servant, and this was from those (2). He said once: Yahya bin Sa'id and Mu'adh bin Mu'adh denied it from Al-Ansari Muhammad Ibn Abdullah (3). And once: Maymun bin Mahran is more trustworthy than Ikrimah; Maymun is trustworthy (Thiqah). And he mentioned him with goodness (4). The Second: The path of Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was cupped while fasting and in Ihram (5). Imam Ahmad said: It is a mistake from the side of Qabisah.
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by At-Tirmidhi (776), he said: Abu Musa narrated to us, Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Ansari narrated to us, from Habib bin Ash-Shahid, from Maymun bin Mahran, from Ibn Abbas, raised (Marfu') with it.
2. "Al-Fatawa" 25/253, "Zad al-Ma'ad" 2/62, "Mizan al-I'tidal" 5/47 (7765), "Tahdhib al-Tahdhib" 3/15, "Du'afa al-Uqayli" 4/91, "Tahdhib al-Kamal" 25/54, "Tarikh Baghdad" 5/410, "Al-Frusiyyah" by Ibn al-Qayyim p. 196.

4. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (556).
5. Reported by An-Nasa'i in "Al-Kubra" 2/235, he said: Mahmud bin Ghailan narrated to us, he said: Qutaibah narrated to us, he said: Ath-Thawri narrated to us, from Hammad, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas, raised (Marfu') with it.

text: And he said: In the book of Al-Ashja'i from Sa'id bin Jubayr as Mursal (disconnected): That the Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was in Ihram, and he does not mention in it: fasting (1). The Third: The path of Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was in Ihram (2) and was cupped while he was fasting. Imam Ahmad said: It does not contain: fasting; rather it is (in Ihram). Sufyan mentioned it from Amr bin Dinar, from Tawus, from Ibn Abbas (3): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was cupped on his head while he was in Ihram. And Abdur-Razzaq narrated it, from Ma'mar, from Ibn Khuthaym, from Sa'id bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abbas: The Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was in Ihram. And Rawh, from Zakariya bin Ishaq, from Amr bin Dinar, from 'Ata and Tawus (4), from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was in Ihram. These are the companions of Ibn Abbas, they do not mention: fasting (5). Fourth: The path of Miqsam from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was cupped while he was fasting (6).

The Hadith. Then I heard him say: Tawus narrated to me, from Ibn Abbas. I said: Perhaps he heard it from both of them.

text: Imam Ahmad said when asked about the narration of Al-Hakam from Miqsam, he said: They say: [It is from a] book (1). And he said once: Shu'bah said: Al-Hakam did not hear from Miqsam, meaning the Hadith of cupping (2). And Imam Ahmad said: It is not authentic from him that he was cupped while he was fasting (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (2030).
2. "Masa'il Al-Baghawi" (22).
3. "Zad al-Ma'ad" 2/61, "Al-Frusiyyah" p. 196. Issue: Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Fatawa" 25/252: More than one of the Companions disliked cupping for the fasting person, and some of them would not get cupped except at night. The people of Basra used to close the cuppers' shops when the month of Ramadan entered. The opinion that cupping breaks the fast is the school of the majority of the jurists of Hadith; like Ahmad bin Hanbal, Ishaq bin Rahwayh, Ibn Khuzaimah, Ibn al-Mundhir, and others. Then Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Fatawa" 25/254: For this reason, Muslim turned away from the Hadith that mentioned the cupping of the fasting person and did not affirm anything except the cupping of the Muhrim (person in Ihram). They interpreted the Hadiths of cupping with weak interpretations, such as their saying: They were backbiting, or their saying: He broke his fast for another reason. The best that has been said is what Ash-Shafi'i and others mentioned, that this is abrogated, for this statement was in Ramadan, and his cupping while in Ihram was after that; because Ihram is after Ramadan. This is also weak; rather, he (prayers of Allah be upon him) entered Ihram in the year six, the year of Hudaibiyah, for Umrah in Dhul-Qi'dah, and he entered Ihram the following year for Umrah al-Qada in Dhul-Qi'dah, and he entered Ihram in the third year, the year of the Conquest from Al-Ji'ranah in Dhul-Qi'dah for Umrah, and he entered Ihram in the tenth year for the Farewell Hajj in Dhul-Qi'dah. So his cupping (peace be upon him) while he was a Muhrim and fasting was not clarified in which of the Ihrams it was. What strengthens [the view] that his Ihram in which he was cupped was before the Conquest of Mecca is his saying: "The cupper and the cupped have broken their fast," for it was during the year of the Conquest without a doubt, as it is in the best of Hadiths. End quote.

text: 397 - Regarding sexual intercourse during the day of Ramadan and its expiation (Kaffarah), there are two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: I had intercourse with my wife in Ramadan. He said: "Are you able to free a slave?" He said: No. He said: "Are you able to fast two consecutive months?" He said: No. He said: "Are you able to feed sixty poor people?" He said: No (1). Imam Ahmad said: They differed regarding the Hadith of Az-Zuhri. Malik (2) and Ibn Jurayj (3) said: From Az-Zuhri in the Hadith: Freeing a slave, or fasting two months, or feeding sixty poor people, by choice [Takhyeer]. Ibn Uyainah, Ibrahim (4) bin Sa'd and others opposed them, so they said: From Az-Zuhri in the Hadith: Upon him is freeing a slave; if he does not find one, then fasting two consecutive months; if he is unable to fast, then feeding sixty
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Al-Bukhari (6709), he said: Ali bin Abdullah narrated to us, Sufyan narrated to us, from Az-Zuhri, he said: I heard it from his mouth, from Humaid bin Abdur-Rahman, from Abu Hurairah, who said: A man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: I am ruined. He said: "What is your matter?" He said: I had intercourse with my wife in Ramadan... so he mentioned it.
2. "Al-Muwatta" p. 198, he said: Malik informed us, Az-Zuhri narrated to us, from Humaid bin Abdur-Rahman, from Abu Hurairah, raised (Marfu') with it. I say: Thus it is in "Al-Muwatta" based on choice, but in Muslim number (1111) from the path of Malik it is like the Hadith of Ibn Uyainah, so perhaps it is a delusion, and Allah knows best.
3. Reported by Muslim (1111), he said: Muhammad bin Rafi' narrated to me, Abdur-Razzaq narrated to us, Ibn Jurayj informed us, Ibn Shihab narrated to me, from Humaid bin Abdur-Rahman that Abu Hurairah narrated to him... The Hadith based on choice.
4. Reported by Al-Bukhari (5368), he said: Ahmad bin Yunus narrated to us, Ibrahim bin Sa'd narrated to us, from Az-Zuhri... then he mentioned it like the Hadith of Ibn Uyainah.

text: poor people - they opposed them. The precaution according to me is in what these people said. As for Malik and Ibn Jurayj, they are memorizers (Hafiz). And Ibn Jurayj heard it from Az-Zuhri directly (Sama'), saying: Ibn Shihab narrated to us. Malik and Ibn Jurayj are exceptions (1). The Second: The Hadith of Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib (may Allah be pleased with them both): I was afflicted in the month of Ramadan. He said: "Are you able to free a slave?" (2). Imam Ahmad said: When he was asked about this Hadith: I do not know who Muhammad bin Ubaid is (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Masa'il Al-Imam Ahmad" narration of Abdullah (709). I say: There was a difference regarding Az-Zuhri in this Hadith. Shu'aib, Ma'mar, Al-Awza'i, Ibrahim bin Sa'd, Al-Layth, Ibn Uyainah, and Mansur narrated it from Az-Zuhri based on order/gradation (Tadreej). Malik and Ibn Jurayj narrated it based on choice (Takhyeer). The apparent meaning of Imam Ahmad's speech from the Hadith perspective is favoring the narration of Malik and Ibn Jurayj, but from the Fiqh perspective, favoring the narration of Ibn Uyainah, Ma'mar, and others, and Allah knows best.
2. I did not find it, but Abdur-Razzaq narrated in his "Musannaf" 4/195 (7459) from the path of Ibn Jurayj: 'Ata Al-Khurasani informed me, he said: I heard Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib say: A Bedouin came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) beating his chest and pulling his hair and saying: The wretched one is ruined. So the Prophet (peace be upon him) said to him: "What is your matter?" He said: I was afflicted in the month of Ramadan. He said: "Are you able to free a slave?" He said: No. He said: "Then give a sacrificial animal." He said: Do you want a camel? He said: "It is nothing but that." He said: I do not find it. He said: "Then sit." He said: So he sat, and a man came with a basket containing twenty Sa' of dates or fifteen Sa'. So he said to the Bedouin: "Give this in charity." So he complained of need to him. He said: "Upon you and your family."
3. "Su'alat Abi Dawud" (539).

text: 398 - Regarding whoever had intercourse with his wife in Ramadan and the addition: "It is not for anyone after you." The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) in the story of the one who had intercourse in Ramadan. In it: Az-Zuhri added: This was a concession only for him specifically; so if a man were to do that today, there would be no escape for him from expiation (1). Imam Ahmad said when asked about this addition: Regarding the raising (Raf') - meaning: from the speech of the Messenger (peace be upon him) - he said: This is not a thing (2). Regarding the obligation of making up the fast for the voluntary faster if he breaks his fast, the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), she said: I woke up fasting, I and Hafsa, and food was gifted to us and we liked it, so we broke our fast. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered, and Hafsa hastened to him and asked him. He said: "Fast a day in its place" (3). Imam Ahmad denied it and said: Jarir used to narrate based on delusion/imagination (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Abu Dawud (2391), he said: Al-Hasan bin Ali narrated to us, Abdur-Razzaq narrated to us, Ma'mar informed us, from Az-Zuhri, from Humaid bin Abdur-Rahman, from Abu Hurairah... The Hadith.
2. "Masa'il Salih li-Imam Ahmad" (782).
3. Reported by An-Nasa'i in "Al-Kubra" 2/248-249, he said: Ahmad bin Isa informed us, from Ibn Wahb, from Jarir bin Hazim, from Yahya bin Sa'id, from Amrah, from Aisha... The Hadith.
4. "Sunan al-Bayhaqi" 4/281, "Sharh Ilal At-Tirmidhi" 2/409, "Mukhtasar Khilafiyyat al-Bayhaqi" 3/93, "Siyar A'lam al-Nubala" 7/103, "Tanqih al-Tahqiq" 2/354. I say: Opposing this Hadith regarding the lack of making up [the fast] is what Muslim reported (1154) from the path of =

text: 399 - What came regarding the virtue of fasting the Day of Arafah and Ashura, the Hadith of Abu Qatadah (may Allah be pleased with him): "Fasting Arafah expiates the year and the one that follows it, and fasting Ashura expiates a year" (1). Imam Ahmad said: Sufyan did not raise it (make it Marfu') for us, while it is raised (2).
foot_note:
1. = Aisha, she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to me one day: "O Aisha, do you have anything?" She said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah, we have nothing. He said: "Then I am fasting." She said: So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out, and a gift was gifted to us - or visitors came to us - She said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) returned, I said: O Messenger of Allah, a gift was gifted to us - or visitors came to us - and I have saved something for you. He said: "What is it?" I said: Hays (a dish of dates and ghee). He said: "Bring it." So I brought it and he ate. Then he said: "I had woken up fasting." Talhah said: So I narrated this Hadith to Mujahid, and he said: That is like the status of a man who takes out charity from his wealth; if he wishes, he executes it, and if he wishes, he withholds it. Issue: At-Tirmidhi said (732): And the practice is upon this according to some of the people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and others, that the voluntary faster, if he breaks his fast, has no make-up (Qada) upon him unless he loves to make it up. This is the saying of Sufyan Ath-Thawri, Ahmad, Ishaq, and Ash-Shafi'i. He also said (735): And a group of the people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and others went to the view that he owes a make-up if he breaks the fast, and it is the saying of Malik bin Anas.
1. "Musnad Ahmad" 5/296, he said: Sufyan narrated to us, he said: We heard it from Dawud bin Shabur, from Abu Qaza'ah, from Abu al-Jalil, from Abu Harmalah, from Abu Qatadah, stopped (Mawquf) upon him.
2. "Musnad Ahmad" 5/296. I say: The text has a witness in "Sahih Muslim" (1162) from the path of Abdullah bin Ma'bad Az-Zamani from Abu Qatadah, raised (Marfu') with it. I say: But Al-Bukhari said in "At-Tarikh Al-Kabir": 5/198: We do not know of his hearing from Abu Qatadah. Meaning: Abdullah bin Ma'bad Az-Zamani.

text: 400 - What came regarding the prohibition of fasting the Days of Tashriq, the Hadith of Abdullah bin Hudhafah (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade fasting the Days of Tashriq (1). Imam Ahmad said: Malik said regarding it: Sulayman bin Yasar: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) (2) sent Abdullah bin Hudhafah and Sufyan. He gave it an Isnad (chain). Ahmad said: It is Mursal (disconnected); Sulayman did not catch Abdullah bin Hudhafah. He said: And they used to be lenient between 'from Abdullah bin Hudhafah' and 'that the Prophet (peace be upon him) sent Abdullah bin Hudhafah', and it is Mursal (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Ahmad in "Al-Musnad" 3/450-451, he said: Abdur-Rahman narrated to us, from Sufyan, from Abdullah - meaning: Ibn Abi Bakr - and Salim Abu An-Nadr, from Sulayman bin Yasar, from Abdullah bin Hudhafah that the Prophet (peace be upon him) commanded him to call out during the Days of Tashriq that they are days of eating and drinking.
2. "Muwatta Malik" p. 245, he said: Abu An-Nadr, the Mawla of Umar bin Ubaidullah, narrated to us, from Sulayman bin Yasar that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... so he mentioned it. There is no mention of Abdullah bin Hudhafah in it.
3. "Sharh Ilal At-Tirmidhi" 1/283, "Jami' at-Tahsil" (263), "Al-Marasil" by Ibn Abi Hatim p. 81. And for the text, there is an authentic witness, for Muslim reported it in his "Sahih" (1141) from the path of Nubayshah Al-Hudhali, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "The Days of Tashriq are days of eating and drinking." Benefit: Regarding Imam Ahmad's statement on the hearings (sama'at), Ibn Rajab mentioned in "Sharh Ilal At-Tirmidhi" 1/381, he said: As for the narration of Urwah from Aisha from the Prophet (peace be upon him), and Urwah that Aisha said to the Prophet (peace be upon him)... Imam Ahmad denied equating them. Issue: At-Tirmidhi said in "Al-Sunan" after (773): The practice is upon this according to the people of knowledge; they dislike fasting the Days of Tashriq, except that a group of the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and others allowed the concession for the Mutamatti' (one performing Tamattu' Hajj) if he does not find a sacrificial animal and did not fast in the Ten [of Dhul-Hijjah], to fast the Days of Tashriq. And this is the saying of Malik, Ash-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq.

book_title: The Collection of Imam Ahmad's Sciences - Ills of Hadith
publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text: 401 - What came regarding fasting the Ten of Dhul-Hijjah, the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) fasting in the Ten ever (1). Imam Ahmad said: The opposite of this has been narrated. And he mentioned the Hadith of Hafsa (2). And he indicated that there was a difference in the chain of Aisha, for Al-A'mash connected it, and Mansur (3) narrated it from Ibrahim as Mursal (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Muslim (2846), he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah, Abu Kuraib, and Ishaq narrated to us. Ishaq said: We were informed, and the other two said: Abu Mu'awiyah narrated to us, from Al-A'mash, from Ibrahim, from Al-Aswad, from Aisha... The Hadith.
2. Reported by An-Nasa'i 4/220, he said: Abu Bakr bin Abi An-Nadr informed us, he said: Abu An-Nadr narrated to me, he said: Abu Ishaq Al-Ashja'i Al-Kufi narrated to us, from Amr bin Qais Al-Mula'i, from Al-Hurr bin As-Sayyah, from Hunaidah bin Khalid Al-Khuza'i, from Hafsa, she said: Four things the Prophet (peace be upon him) would not leave: Fasting Ashura, the Ten, three days from every month, and two Rak'ahs before the dawn (Ghadah).
3. Reported by Ibn Abi Shaybah 3/41, he said: Jarir narrated to us, from Mansur, from Ibrahim that the Prophet (peace be upon him)... The Hadith.
4. "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" p. 277-278. I say: The apparent meaning of Imam Ahmad's speech is preferring the narration of disconnection (Irsal), for Ibn Rajab narrated in "Sharh Ilal At-Tirmidhi" regarding the companions of Ibrahim 2/527-528 the saying of Imam Ahmad regarding the most firm of people in Ibrahim, so he prioritized Mansur and Al-Hakam, and it is the choice of Ali bin Al-Madini, Yahya bin Sa'id, and Yahya bin Ma'in. Benefit: Ad-Daraqutni followed Imam Ahmad on the Irsal in "Al-Ilzamat wa At-Tatabbu'" (194) and in "Al-Ilal" where he said: And the correct version is from Ath-Thawri, from Mansur, from Ibrahim, he said: I was told that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... And At-Tirmidhi went to preferring the narration of connection (Wasl) (756) where he said: They differed over Mansur in the Hadith, and the narration of Al-A'mash is more correct and more connected.

text: 402 - Regarding the desirability of fasting six days of Shawwal following Ramadan, there are three Hadiths: The First: From the Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him): "Whoever fasts Ramadan then follows it with six from Shawwal, it is like fasting the eternity (Dahr)" (1). Imam Ahmad leaned towards its being Mawquf (stopped at the Companion) (2). And he said once: It is from three modes (Wajh) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) (3). The Second: From the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both)... like it (4). Imam Ahmad said: Amr bin Jabir narrates Munkar (denounced) Hadiths from Jabir (5).
foot_note:
1. = Issue: Ibn Rajab reported in "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" p. 278 from Imam Ahmad that he said that Aisha meant that he did not fast the Ten completely, meaning, and Hafsa meant that he used to fast most of it, so it is appropriate that some of it be fasted and some of it not fasted. Ibn Rajab said: And this reconciliation is valid in the narration of whoever narrated 'I did not see him fasting the Ten,' but as for whoever narrated 'I did not see him fasting in the Ten,' this reconciliation is remote or impossible in it.
1. Reported by Muslim (1164), he said: Yahya bin Ayyub, Qutaibah bin Sa'id, and Ali bin Hajar all narrated to us from Isma'il. Ibn Ayyub said: Isma'il bin Ja'far narrated to us, Sa'd bin Sa'id bin Qais informed me, from Umar bin Thabit bin Al-Harith Al-Khazraji, from Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him), the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said... The Hadith.
2. "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" 232.
3. "Al-Mughni" 4/439.
4. "Musnad Ahmad" 3/344, he said: Abdullah bin Yazid narrated to us, Sa'id bin Abi Ayyub narrated to us, he said: Amr bin Jabir Al-Hadrami narrated to us, from Jabir... so he mentioned it.
5. Al-Uqayli in "Ad-Du'afa" 3/263.

text: The Third: From the Hadith of Thawban (may Allah be pleased with him): "Fasting Ramadan is like ten months, and fasting six days is like two months, so that is the fasting of a year" (1). Imam Ahmad said: There is nothing more authentic than the Hadith of Ar-Razi, and another narration stopped him [about it] (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Ibn Majah (1715), he said: Hisham bin Ammar narrated to us, Baqiyyah narrated to us, Sadaqah bin Khalid narrated to us, he said: Yahya bin Al-Harith narrated to me, that he heard Abu Asma' Ar-Rahabi narrating, from Thawban, the Mawla of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)... so he mentioned it.
2. "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" 234. I say: The Hadith of Abu Ayyub (may Allah be pleased with him) revolves around Sa'd bin Sa'id, and he is closer to weakness than to modification (Ta'dil), along with the dispute regarding its raising (Raf') and stopping (Waqf). Benefit: Ibn Rajab said in "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" 232: There was a difference regarding this Hadith and acting upon it. Some of them authenticated it, and some of them said: It is Mawquf, Ibn Uyainah and others said it, and Imam Ahmad leans towards it. And some of them spoke regarding its chain. As for acting upon it, most scholars recommended fasting six of Shawwal. Then Ibn Rajab said 234 regarding the Hadith of Thawban: Abu Hatim Ar-Razi authenticated it. I say: Ibn Abi Hatim mentioned in "Al-Ilal" (745), he said: My father was asked about a Hadith narrated by Marwan At-Tatari, from Yahya bin Hamzah, from Yahya bin Al-Harith, from Abu Al-Ash'ath As-San'ani, from Aws bin Aws, from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "Whoever fasts Ramadan and follows it with six of Shawwal," so I heard my father say: People narrate it from Yahya bin Al-Harith, from Abu Asma, from Thawban, from the Prophet (peace be upon him). I said to my father: Which of them is more correct? He said: Both are authentic (Sahih). I say: Whoever tracks the sayings of Abu Hatim in "Al-Ilal" finds that this Hadith was mentioned once by inserting Abu Al-Ash'ath between Yahya bin Al-Harith and Abu Asma Ar-Rahabi, so Abu Hatim deemed this narration a delusion and said: The correct version is without it. Meaning: He applied 'authenticity' here to the preserved narration only, without looking at its chain. At-Tabarani found a defect in it in "Al-Kabir" in his narration of this Hadith and included it in the strange ones (Ghara'ib), and also Muslim's turning away from it strengthens what I went to regarding Abu Hatim applying 'authenticity' to the preserved narration even if it is weak, and Allah knows best.

text: 403 - What came regarding the prohibition of fasting six days, the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): The Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade fasting six days (1) of the year: The Days of Tashriq, the Day of Sacrifice (Adha), the Day of Breaking the Fast (Fitr), and the last day of Sha'ban connected to Ramadan. Imam Ahmad said: It is not from Sa'id; rather, it is Abdullah bin Sa'id (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by Ibn Adi in "Al-Kamil" 5/269, he said: Husain bin Abdullah Al-Qattan narrated to us, Ayyub Al-Wazzan narrated to us, Marwan Al-Fazari narrated to us, Abdullah bin Sa'id narrated to us, from his grandfather, from Abu Hurairah, raised (Marfu') with it.
2. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1899), "Al-Kamil" by Ibn Adi 5/269.

text: 404 - What came regarding fasting Monday and Thursday, the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): He used to seek out fasting Monday and Thursday and he would fast Sha'ban (1). Imam Ahmad was asked about Sur [Thawr], the narrator in this Hadith, so he said: I do not know him (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by An-Nasa'i 4/203, he said: Ishaq bin Ibrahim informed us, he said: Ubaidullah bin Sa'id Al-Umawi informed us, he said: Sufyan narrated to us, from Thawr, from Khalid bin Ma'dan, from Aisha, with it.
2. "Masa'il Al-Imam Ahmad" narration of Ibn Hani (2102). I say: In "Sunan An-Nasa'i" it is (Thawr), and he is Ibn Yazid Al-Kala'i, and he is well-known. And in "Al-Masa'il" it is (Sur), so Allah knows best. And the Hadith has a witness for part of the text in "Sahih Muslim" (1162) from the path of Abdullah bin Ma'bad Az-Zamani from Abu Qatadah. And in it: And he was asked about fasting the day of Monday? He said: "That is a day in which I was born, and a day in which I was sent, or revelation was sent down to me in it." And in this Hadith from the narration of Shu'bah, he said: And he was asked about fasting Monday and Thursday? So we remained silent about mentioning Thursday because we see it as a delusion. And the speech of Al-Bukhari has preceded regarding the narration of Abu Ma'bad Az-Zamani, from Abu Qatadah.

text: 405 - The dislike of fasting in the second half of Sha'ban, the Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him), the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If half of Sha'ban remains, then do not fast" (1). Imam Ahmad said: This Hadith is not preserved (Mahfuz). He said: And I asked Ibn Mahdi about it; so he did not authenticate it and did not narrate it to me, and he used to avoid it. And he said: Al-A'la is trustworthy (Thiqah) and nothing is denied from his Hadith except this (2). And he said once: This is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith; this contradicts the Hadiths which were narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) (3). And he said once when Abu Dawud asked him about Abdur-Rahman not narrating it to him, he said: Because he held that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to connect Sha'ban with Ramadan. And he said: From the Prophet (peace be upon him) is its contrary (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Reported by At-Tirmidhi (738), he said: Qutaibah narrated to us, Abdul-Aziz bin Muhammad narrated to us, from Al-A'la bin Abdur-Rahman, from his father, from Abu Hurairah, who said... so he mentioned it.
2. "Ilal Ahmad" narration of Al-Marudhi (278), "Nasb al-Rayah" 2/441, "Al-Mughni" 4/327, "Tabaqat al-Hanabilah" 2/78, "Masa'il Harb" p. 461.
3. "Ilal Ahmad" narration of Al-Marudhi (278), "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" p. 142, "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (2052), "Al-Frusiyyah" by Ibn al-Qayyim p. 188, "Mukhtasar Khilafiyyat al-Bayhaqi" 3/34, "Masa'il Harb" p. 461.
4. "Sunan Abi Dawud" (2337), "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (2002), "Al-Frusiyyah" by Ibn al-Qayyim p. 188. Benefit: Ibn Rajab said in "Lata'if al-Ma'arif" p. 142 with modification: The scholars differed regarding the authenticity of this Hadith and then regarding acting upon it; as for its authentication, more than one authenticated it, among them =
