text:
And he said once: Abu Al-Mughirah narrated it to us, from Al-Awza'i, from Ata, as Mursal. The likes of this from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him? As if denying it to be (1).

515 - What has been reported regarding the prohibition of Shighar marriage (exchange marriage without dowry).

The Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: "There is no Shighar in Islam" (2).

Imam Ahmad said: This is a Munkar Hadith from the narration of Thabit (3). And he said once: This is the work of Aban, meaning: it is the Hadith of Aban, but Ma'mar... meaning: he practiced Tadlis (concealment) (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) "Mukhtasar Khilafiyat Al-Bayhaqi" 4/117-118.
2. Recorded by Ibn Majah (1885), he said: Al-Hussein bin Mahdi told us, Abd al-Razzaq informed us, Ma'mar informed us, from Thabit, from Anas bin Malik, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said... The Hadith.
3. "Ilal Al-Marwazi" (266).
4. "Sharh Ilal al-Tirmidhi" 393. I say: The text of the Hadith is established; Al-Bukhari recorded it (5112) from the Hadith of Nafi', from Ibn Umar: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade Shighar. Shighar is when a man marries his daughter to another on the condition that the other marries his daughter to him, with no dowry between them. Issue: Al-Khattabi said in "Ma'alim al-Sunan" 3/164: The interpretation of Shighar is what Nafi' explained. He said: If the marriage occurs with this description, is it void? Because the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade it, and the origin of private parts is prohibition, and prohibition is not lifted by prohibition, but is lifted by permission. The jurists did not disagree that the Prophet's prohibition of marrying a woman along with her paternal aunt or maternal aunt implies prohibition, and likewise his prohibition of Mut'ah marriage, so likewise this. Those who voided this marriage include Malik, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad bin Hanbal, Ishaq bin Rahwayh, and Abu Ubaid. The scholars of opinion (Ahnaf) and Sufyan Al-Thawri said: The marriage is valid and each of them gets a dowry of her like (Mahr al-Mithl), and the meaning of prohibition in this, according to them, is making the private part lawful without a dowry.

text:
516 - What has been reported regarding the prohibition of Mut'ah (temporary) marriage.

The Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade Mut'ah and the meat of domestic donkeys at the time of Khaybar (1).

Imam Ahmad said: It is actually Abdullah and Hasan, the sons of Ali, from their father, but Ma'mar said it thus (2).

517 - What has been reported regarding the prohibition of marrying a slave woman over a free woman.

The Hadith of Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with him: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade that a slave woman be married over a free woman (3).

Imam Ahmad said: The Hadith of Sufyan from Hisham bin Abi Abdullah is Gharib (strange); it was only narrated by Amr bin Ubaid, and it is Gharib from the narration of Amir Al-Ahwal (4) (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Recorded by Al-Bukhari (5115), he said: Malik bin Isma'il told us, Ibn Uyaynah told us that he heard Al-Zuhri saying: Al-Hasan bin Muhammad bin Ali and his brother Abdullah informed me from their father that Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said to Ibn Abbas... The Hadith.
2. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (3797) from the path of Isma'il bin Ulayyah, who said: Ma'mar told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali, from Ali that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace... so he mentioned it.
3. Recorded by Al-Tabarani 5/17, he said: Al-Muthanna told us, saying: Hibban bin Musa told us, saying: Ibn Al-Mubarak informed us, saying: Sufyan informed us, from Hisham, from Amir Al-Ahwal, from Al-Hasan, raised (Marfu') to the Prophet.
4. Recorded by Abd al-Razzaq in his "Musannaf" 7/264 from Al-Thawri, from Amr bin Ubaid, from Al-Hasan, raised (Marfu') to the Prophet.
5. "Al-Ilal" narration of Abdullah (4326).

publisher: Dar Al-Falah for Scientific Research and Heritage Verification, Fayoum - Arab Republic of Egypt
text:
518 - What has been reported regarding the prohibition of marriage for a Muhrim (pilgrim).

The Hadith of Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him: "A Muhrim does not marry, nor is he married off, nor does he propose" (1).

Imam Ahmad was asked: Did Aban hear from his father? He said: No, from where would he hear from him (2)?

519 - What has been reported regarding Azl (coitus interruptus) with a free woman.

The Hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him: "One does not perform Azl with a free woman except with her permission" (3).

Imam Ahmad said: I do not deny it (4)!
foot_note:
1. (1) Recorded by Muslim (1409), he said: Yahya bin Yahya told us, saying: I read to Malik, from Nafi', from Nabih bin Wahb that Umar bin Ubaidullah wanted to marry Talha bin Umar to the daughter of Shaybah bin Jubayr, so he sent for Aban bin Uthman to attend that, and he was the Amir of Hajj. Aban said: I heard Uthman say: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "A Muhrim does not marry..." The Hadith.
2. "Jami' al-Tahsil" 139.
3. Recorded by Ahmad 1/31, he said: Ishaq bin Isa told us, Ibn Lahi'ah told us, from Ja'far bin Rabi'ah, from Al-Zuhri, from Muharrir bin Abu Huraira, from his father, from Umar bin Al-Khattab, raised (Marfu') to the Prophet.
4. "Masa'il Abi Dawud" (1869), "Zad al-Ma'ad" 5/142. Issue: Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" 9/218-219 (adapted): Ibn Abd al-Barr said: There is no disagreement among scholars that one does not perform Azl with a free wife except with her permission; because intercourse is her right, and she has the right to demand it, and known intercourse is only that which is not followed by Azl. Ibn Hubayrah agreed with him on this consensus. It was critiqued that the well-known view among the Shafi'is is that the woman has no right to intercourse at all. However, the three schools agreed that a free woman is not subject to Azl except with her permission, and that a slave woman is subject to Azl without her permission.
